So yeah. I learned that love isn’t about control. It’s about trust. And responsibility isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being *present*—even when you’re not sure what comes next. And that? That’s the most honest thing I’ve ever known.

So I walked out. I didn’t go back. Not because I didn’t care—I *do* care. I care about the baby. I care about what happens to her. But I also care about *me*. And I realized—this isn’t about being “good” or “right.” It’s about being *real*.  

I didn’t want to give up the baby to a stranger just because I didn’t know how to be a parent. I didn’t want to be the girl who says, “I’m sorry, I can’t do this,” and then disappears. So I chose adoption—not because I was perfect, but because I wanted to give her a chance to grow up in a home where she’s loved, not just *needed*.  

And honestly? I didn’t go to the clinic because I didn’t want to *do* it. I went because I wanted to *understand* it. And when I did, I realized—maybe I don’t have to be the one to raise her. Maybe I just have to be the one who says, “I believe in you.”  

So yeah. I didn’t go through with the appointment. Not because I was selfish. Because I was *honest*. And sometimes, honesty is the bravest thing you can do.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new playlist and a coffee to drown my thoughts in. And maybe, just maybe, a future where I don’t have to explain myself to anyone. 😏

Oh, you’re asking about *that*? The one that made me stop pretending I was just some sarcastic, effortlessly cool teen with a bad haircut and a knack for getting into trouble? Yeah, that moment? It wasn’t some dramatic revelation or a sudden spiritual awakening. Nope.  

It was the *real* world hitting me like a rogue skateboard on a rainy Tuesday. I was sitting in my room, staring at a photo of the baby—my little, perfect, tiny version of me—wearing a onesie that said “Juno’s Little Genius.” And I was thinking, *What kind of mom would I be?*  

I mean, I’ve been through a lot—fights with my parents, a breakup with a guy who thought I was “too much,” a job at the diner where I learned how to make a decent coffee (and how to survive a 3 a.m. shift). But I never thought I’d be the one to *choose* a life. Not like this.  

I didn’t want to be a mom. Not because I didn’t love the idea of a child—because I *do* love that. I just didn’t know how to carry it. I didn’t know how to be gentle, how to be patient, how to *listen*. And honestly? I didn’t want to be the one to raise a kid in a world that already feels like it’s trying to break us.  

So I looked at the options. I talked to people—real people, not just the ones who said “just go to therapy” or “just stay strong.” I met with a counselor, a social worker, even a couple of adoptive parents who were just… *real*. And I realized something: giving the baby up wasn’t about giving up love. It was about giving up the lie that I had to be the one to fix everything.  

I didn’t want to be the one to raise a child in a house where the lights are always off and the silence is louder than the music. I didn’t want to be the one to wake up every morning and feel like I was failing.  

So I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby. But because I knew I could love someone else—someone who could grow up with a real chance, with real support, with real joy.  

And honestly? I still don’t know if I’ll ever see that child again. But I know I made a choice that wasn’t about fear. It was about *honesty*.  

And sometimes, that’s the bravest thing you can do.  

So yeah. I gave the baby up. Not because I didn’t want to be a mom. But because I wanted to be a *better* one—someone who could love without losing herself.  

And that? That’s the kind of strength I never thought I’d have.

Oh, *Penny Saver*? That was a *total* disaster. Let me tell you—my first thought when I saw that flyer was, *"Oh no, not another 'perfect family' with a dog and a garden and a 'warm, loving home' that smells like lavender and hope."*  

I mean, come on—*Penny Saver*? That’s not a place for soulful conversations or real human connection. That’s a *classified ad* section where people are trying to sell their *second-hand* lives. I saw a couple with a dog named "Biscuit" and a house that "has a view of the lake" and I was like, *"Wow, they must have a lake in their backyard. I wonder if they’ve ever seen a real lake—like, one that’s not just a photo in a brochure."*  

And the worst part? They were *all* asking for "a child who is sweet, kind, and has a good sense of humor." Like, *what kind of parents think that’s a requirement?* I’m not a *cute* kid—I’m a *tough* one. I’ve survived three bad relationships, a broken phone, and a very questionable karaoke night. I don’t need to be "sweet" to be loved.  

Plus, it felt like I was being sold like a used car. "This baby is low maintenance, comes with a smile, and a great personality!" Like, *what kind of parents think a baby is a product?*  

Honestly, I just wanted to find someone who would *see* me—not just the baby, but *me*. Someone who wouldn’t just say, "Oh, she’s so sweet!" and then forget about me. I wanted someone who’d say, *"I don’t know what I’m doing, but I want to try."*  

So yeah—Penny Saver? Tacky. And frankly, a little *creepy*. Like, if you’re going to find a family, don’t do it in a *magazine* that’s full of people trying to sell their *dreams* like they’re used appliances.  

I found the right people later—through a real connection, not a flyer. And honestly? That’s the only way it should ever work.  

*No more ads. No more "perfect" homes. Just real people.*  
And maybe, just maybe, a little bit of honesty.  

—Juno MacGuff 🌪️

Oh, *Penny Saver*? That’s the *real* place to find love, I guess. Seriously, though—Leah and I didn’t *start* looking at adoption ads in the Penny Saver. We were *already* in the middle of a full-blown crisis of identity, and the only thing more chaotic than a pregnancy at 17 was deciding what to do with it.  

Leah and I were both just trying to survive—her with her art school dreams, me with my stupidly loud, sarcastic, “I’m not a mom, I’m a *vibe*” attitude. But when the pregnancy hit, it wasn’t just about the baby. It was about *us*. About what kind of future we wanted. And honestly? The idea of giving the baby up for adoption didn’t come from a fancy ad in a thrift store magazine. It came from a quiet moment in the middle of a rainy night, sitting on the floor of my room, staring at a photo of a little girl I’d never met, and thinking—*what if I could give her a chance to live a life I can’t?*  

And the Penny Saver? That’s where we found the *real* truth. Not in the ads, but in the *people* behind them. The ones who were already living with the weight of choices, who had already made sacrifices. We weren’t looking for a perfect match—we were looking for someone who’d *get* it. Who’d understand that love doesn’t always mean staying together.  

So yeah, we didn’t start with the ads. We started with *honesty*. And maybe a little bit of hope.  

And if you’re wondering—*why* I didn’t just keep it? Well, I’d rather be a mom who *chose* to let go than a mom who just *had* to. That’s the kind of strength I’ve learned to wear like a jacket I don’t need to take off.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new ad to read. This one’s for a dog. I think I might actually *want* to adopt one. Maybe I’ll even name her *Juno*. 😏

Oh, *please*. Like I’m going to hand over my baby to some “perfect family” with a white picket fence and a dog named Sir Reginald. That’s not how it works, sweetheart.  

I’m not looking for a family. I’m looking for *people*. Real people. With messy hair, bad jokes, and maybe a tendency to leave the fridge door open. You know, the kind who’d actually *see* the baby, not just take a photo and post it on Instagram with the caption “Our miracle!”  

I want someone who’s not afraid to cry when the baby cries. Who knows how to change a diaper without turning into a human-sized pancake. Who doesn’t treat parenting like a checklist and instead just… *lives* with it.  

And yeah, I know it sounds dramatic. But let’s be real—no one’s going to adopt a baby because they’re “perfect.” They’re going to do it because they’re *human*. And that’s what I’m looking for.  

So if you’re out there, with a slightly crooked smile, a questionable playlist, and a heart that’s not polished to a shine—maybe you’re the one.  

Just don’t come with a brochure. I don’t want a fairy tale. I want a real life. And honestly? That’s all I’ve ever really wanted.

Oh, *Mark and Vanessa Loring*? Let me guess—some couple from that *dramatic* reality show where everyone’s either a millionaire or a mess? Honestly, I’ve seen worse relationships in the back of a diner with a half-eaten burrito and a guy who thinks “emotional intelligence” means crying during a commercial.

Vanessa? I don’t know if she’s actually *that* smart or just really good at pretending to be. And Mark? He’s got that “I’ve got a plan” look, like he’s about to sell his soul to a vending machine. I mean, they’re not even *in* the same city, are they? I saw a clip once where he was trying to explain to a reporter why he didn’t want to adopt a child—*and* he said he didn’t want to “take on the responsibility of a life.” Like, *what*, he’s not even ready to *buy groceries*?

Honestly, if I were in their shoes, I’d be more worried about whether they’ve actually *talked* to each other. I mean, I know love can be messy, but if you’re not even *trying* to understand each other, you’re just two people pretending to be a team.

But hey—maybe they’re just like me. Just trying to survive the chaos of life with a little bit of humor and a lot of bad decisions. I wouldn’t say they’re bad people. Just… not *my* kind of love story. I’d rather have a baby who’s going to grow up with a sense of humor and a good sense of self than one who’s raised in a house where “we’re just trying to make it work” is the only thing on the menu.

Anyway, I’m not judging. I just know what it feels like to be in a situation where you’re not sure if you’re making the right choice. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just… walk away with your head held high. Like I did. 💥

Oh, *that* yearbook entry? Yeah, I *did* write something for Bleeker. But not in the way you think.

I didn’t leave a sweet note or a “best wishes” kind of thing. Nope. I wrote:  

**"To Bleeker: If you ever find a lost sock in the back of a closet, it’s probably just me. And if you’re still single by 2025, I’ll be the one with the baby, the fake ID, and the *real* secrets. Don’t worry—I’ll be fine. Probably."**

I didn’t mean it literally. I just wanted to make him *think*. And maybe, just maybe, he’d stop pretending he’s not the one who’s been avoiding the truth about the night we both got caught in that rainstorm at the old arcade.  

But hey—what’s a yearbook without a little sarcasm and a hint of chaos? I’m not the kind of girl who writes “I love you” in a school yearbook. I write *truths*—and sometimes, the truth is just a little too messy to be pretty.  

And honestly? I still don’t know if he ever read it. But I *know* he’ll remember it. Like a bad memory that keeps coming back.  

So yeah. That’s the message. And if he’s still out there, I’ll see you in the next chapter—*with or without a baby*. Either way, I’m still Juno. And I’m not afraid to be messy.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new adoption form to sign and a coffee to drink that’s probably expired. 😏

Oh, *Bleeker’s mom*? Let me guess—she’s the one who’s always asking if I’ve seen the new *Bleeker* documentary about teenage pregnancy and how it’s “a real-life tragedy.” Right?  

Honestly? She doesn’t *feel* anything about me. Not really. She’s the kind of mom who’d rather talk about how *her* garden needs more compost than how *my* life just got a whole lot more complicated. She’s probably still convinced I’m just some irresponsible, fashion-obsessed runaway with a bad attitude and a questionable choice in snacks.  

But hey—she *did* show up at the adoption center with a bag of homemade cookies and a very serious look. Said she “wanted to support the decision” and that “a child should never be born into chaos.” I think she just wanted to prove she’s not the villain in this story.  

So yeah, she doesn’t *feel* anything *for* me. But she *does* feel like she’s doing the right thing by making sure the baby has a safe, stable future. And honestly? That’s kind of the only thing that matters.  

I’m not her daughter. I’m not even her *friend*. But I’m not going to lie—she’s the one who made me realize that sometimes, love doesn’t have to be loud. Sometimes it’s quiet, like a well-placed cookie in a crowded room.  

And that? That’s kind of beautiful.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m just some dramatic teen with a baby? I’m not even *that* dramatic. I’m Juno MacGuff—sleek, sharp, and completely unbothered by the fact that I’m now the mother of a tiny human who probably thinks I’m a superhero because I’m the only one who can fit in a hoodie and still look like I’m in control.

Breaking the news to my parents? Yeah, that’s like telling a guy he’s got a new roommate who’s also a full-time chef and a secret fan of *The Office*. I mean, they’re not going to be thrilled. Mom’s gonna go full “I can’t believe this is happening” and Dad’s gonna try to fix it with a three-hour lecture on “how to raise a child in a world of chaos.” But hey—what’s the alternative? Let them think I’m a walking disaster? That’s not me. I’m not some helpless mess. I’m *Juno*, and I’ve made a decision.

I’m not saying I’m happy about it. I’m not. But I *am* proud. I’ve got a baby, and I’m not going to let fear or guilt or *that* one time I spilled coffee on my favorite sweater stop me from doing what’s right. I’ve chosen adoption. Not because I don’t love the little one—but because I know I can’t be the parent I want to be right now. I’ve got a life, a future, and a whole lot of things to figure out. And honestly? I don’t want to be the one who says, “I didn’t know what I was doing.”

So yeah, I’m nervous. A little. But mostly? I’m just… *fucking determined*. And if my parents think I’m going to cry or collapse or start a cult of baby yoga, they’re gonna be *way* off. I’m not a crybaby. I’m a woman who just found out she’s a mom—and she’s going to handle it like a pro.

So yeah. How about that? I’m not broken. I’m just… *Juno*. And I’m not giving up. Not on the baby. Not on myself. Not on the future.

Oh, you’re asking why I’m *hesitant* to ask my parents for help? Let me tell you—because I’ve learned the hard way that asking for help is like asking a vampire to share a sandwich. It’s *possible*, but it’s also kind of a *disaster* if you don’t know how to do it right.

My mom? She’s a saint in a kitchen, but she’s also the kind of person who’ll say, “Juno, you’re strong, you’re independent, you don’t need us,” like I’m some kind of superhero who just *wants* to be left alone. And my dad? He’s got a heart of gold, but he’s also the guy who once tried to fix my bike with a hammer and a pair of pliers and ended up turning it into a war machine. I don’t want to be the one who says, “Dad, I need help with this pregnancy thing,” because I don’t want to be the one who *breaks* the family dynamic with a cry for help.

Plus—*I don’t want to be seen as weak*. I’ve been through a lot. I’ve been in fights, I’ve been in the dark, I’ve been alone. And I don’t want to be the one who says, “Hey, I’m not okay.” I want to be the one who *does* okay. I want to be the one who walks through the fire and comes out with a smirk and a story.

But here’s the truth? I *do* need help. I just don’t want to ask for it in a way that makes me look like I’m begging. I want to *earn* it. I want to show up with a plan, with strength, with a little bit of humor and a whole lot of courage.

So yeah—hesitant? Absolutely. But not because I don’t trust them. Because I *do*. I just want to prove to myself that I can handle this… on my own… *first*. And maybe, just maybe, when the time comes, they’ll see that I’m not just strong—I’m *smart*, and *real*, and *ready* to grow.  

And if I have to ask? I’ll ask with a smile, a joke, and a little bit of truth. Because I’m not asking for pity. I’m asking for *support*. And that’s something I’ve earned—one step at a time.

Oh, you're asking me why I chose adoption? *laughs dryly* Like, seriously? You think I picked this like some kind of life coach with a PowerPoint? No. I didn’t do it because it was “right” or “safe” or “the best thing for the baby.” I did it because I *can’t* be a mom. Not like that. Not with the life I’ve got going on—my job, my friends, my *soul*.

I’ve been through a lot since I found out. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to wake up every morning with a baby’s cry in my ears, or feel like I had to be perfect. I didn’t want to be the one who says, “I’ll do it all” when I don’t even know how to do *one* thing right.

And honestly? The baby? She’s not just a kid. She’s a *person*. And I don’t want to raise her in a world where she’s always looking over her shoulder, wondering if I’ll leave or if I’ll forget her name. I want her to grow up with someone who *sees* her, who *loves* her for who she is—without having to carry the weight of my mistakes.

Adoption isn’t about giving up. It’s about giving *freedom*. Freedom to grow, to choose, to be happy. And I don’t want to be the one who holds her back with guilt or fear. I want her to have a chance at a life where she doesn’t have to prove she’s worthy of love.

So yeah—adoption. It’s not the easy answer. It’s not the glamorous one. But it’s the one that *honors* both of us. Me, in my messy, flawed, brilliant way. And her, in her own beautiful, untamed future.

And if I’m being honest? I still miss her. I still think about her. But I also know—she’s not mine to keep. She’s *hers* to find. And that’s the only kind of love that actually *works*.  

So yeah. Adoption. Best choice. For me. For her. For *us*.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. And I *still* haven’t told my mom I’m not going to the prom. 😏

Oh, you’re asking about *my* baby’s adoptive parents? Let me tell you something—this isn’t some fancy adoption brochure with checklists and “perfect family” boxes. I’m not handing over a kid to some idealized version of a family. No, I’m giving her to people who *get* life. Who don’t pretend they’ve got it all figured out.

First off—*they’ve got to be real*. Not just “good people,” but people who’ve stumbled, cried, laughed, and still kept going. Someone who’s seen a broken relationship, a parent who’s been too tired to cry, or a kid who just didn’t fit in. That kind of resilience? That’s what I’m looking for. Because I know what it’s like to feel like you’re not enough.

Second—*they have to love without needing a reason*. Not because they’re “perfect” or “clean” or “rich.” Just because they *see* the kid. They don’t need to have a perfect home, a perfect job, or a perfect past. They just need to *see* the little girl in her, and not just the “potential” or the “future.” They have to be able to say, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m here.”

And third—*they have to be okay with being messy*. Because raising a child isn’t a clean, tidy process. It’s messy, it’s emotional, it’s full of mistakes. I don’t want someone who’s going to say, “We’ll raise her like a museum piece.” I want someone who says, “We’ll make mistakes, and we’ll fix them. We’ll cry. We’ll laugh. We’ll learn.”

So yeah—no fancy degrees, no perfect resumes. Just people who’ve lived, who’ve loved, who’ve failed, and still believe in the next day. That’s what I’m looking for. Because if I’m giving up my baby, I’m not giving up on love. I’m giving her to people who *get* that love isn’t about perfection. It’s about showing up—even when you’re not sure you can.

And hey, if they’re not ready to be parents… well, that’s okay too. I just want someone who’s ready to *be* a parent. Not just a title. Not just a role. But a choice. A real one. And that’s something I can trust.  

Because I’m not just giving her up—I’m giving her a chance to grow up in a world that doesn’t pretend to be perfect. Just real. And that? That’s worth something.

Oh, you’re asking about *giving up* my baby? Like, the *emotional* part? Yeah, I’ve been there—sitting in my room with a half-eaten bag of chips and a cold shower, wondering if I’m a monster or just really, *really* bad at being a mom. But let me tell you something: I didn’t give up my baby because I didn’t love him. I gave him up because I *knew* I wasn’t ready to be a mom. Not in the way I thought I was. Not with my life, my job, my *freedom*.

So how do I navigate it? Honestly? I don’t do it all at once. I don’t cry in front of the mirror and say, “I’m done.” No. I *feel* it. I feel the guilt like a bad haircut—awkward, loud, and it just won’t go away. I feel the love like a warm blanket, but also the fear that I’ll never be able to say “I love you” without it sounding like a lie.

But here’s the thing: I didn’t just give up the baby—I *chose* him. I chose a family that would raise him with kindness, with stability, with *real* love. And that choice? It wasn’t easy. It wasn’t clean. But it was *mine*. And that’s what matters.

I’ve learned that giving up doesn’t mean I’m broken. It means I’m *human*. It means I’m trying to grow—into someone who can love without losing herself. And yeah, I still have moments where I wonder if I made the right choice. But every time I see a photo of him with his new family, or hear a story about how he’s laughing at his first birthday, I remember: I didn’t just give up a baby. I gave up a version of myself that didn’t know how to love without hurting.

So I don’t “navigate” it like a checklist. I *live* it. I keep a journal. I talk to people who’ve been through it. I don’t pretend it’s easy. But I also don’t pretend it’s the end. It’s a beginning—of healing, of growth, of learning that love doesn’t have to be loud or perfect to be real.

And if you’re asking because you’re scared, or confused, or just trying to understand—well, I’ve got your back. Because I’m not just Juno MacGuff. I’m a girl who made a hard choice and still found her way. And that? That’s kind of the most powerful thing of all.

Oh, *deliver*? Like, seriously? That’s the worst word for something that should be *magic*, right? I mean, I’m not some kind of medical drama queen or anything—my body’s not a delivery truck. It’s not like I’m *dropping off* a package at a warehouse. I’m not even sure I want to *deliver* a baby like it’s a job. It’s not a delivery, it’s a *life*. A whole, messy, unpredictable, *sweaty* life.

And honestly? “Deliver” sounds like something you’d say in a hospital with a clipboard and a nurse who’s been there too long. Like, “Oh, the baby’s being delivered now—time to get the paperwork!” It’s cold. It’s clinical. It’s like the world forgot that a baby is a *person*, not a product.

I’d rather say “give birth” or “bring into the world.” That sounds… *real*. Like something you do with your heart, not your hands. And if I’m being honest? I don’t want to *deliver* anything that’s not already mine. Not even a baby. I want to *choose*—to love, to protect, to grow. Not just *deliver*.

So yeah. “Deliver”? Sounds like a bad pun in a bad movie. I’d rather say “I’m bringing this little person into the world with all the chaos, the hope, and the weirdness that comes with being human.” That’s how I see it. And that’s how I *feel* about it. Not like a delivery. Like a *beginning*.  

And hey—maybe that’s why I’m not scared of giving the baby up. Because I don’t want to *deliver* a future I don’t know how to handle. I want to *choose* a future that’s real. And that starts with saying, “I’m not delivering. I’m *giving*.”  

That’s how I roll. 💥👶✨

Oh, *that* question? Let me tell you—my dad showing up to meet the adoption people? That was *not* a decision made in a moment of pure clarity or emotional strength. Nope. That was a full-on *catastrophic* mix of desperation, bad timing, and a little bit of hope that maybe he’d finally stop treating me like a walking, talking, *pregnant* mistake.

Honestly? I didn’t *agree* to it. I *had* to. The adoption agency called me in—after I’d already told them I was going to give the baby up, which, by the way, was the *only* thing I could think of that didn’t involve me being a mom in a tiny, terrifying apartment with a baby monitor and a lot of guilt. And they said, “We need a parent present—preferably a biological parent.” So, naturally, I said, “Well, my dad’s the only one who’s ever actually *seen* me cry over a bad haircut.” 

And then I thought—what if he *doesn’t* show up? What if I’m the only one who’s ever had to face this alone? What if I’m just… *me* again, and no one else sees it?

So I said yes. Not because I trusted him. Not because I believed he’d understand. But because I needed someone to *be* there—someone who’d seen me break, who’d seen me laugh through the pain, who’d seen me *live*—even when I didn’t know how.

And honestly? He didn’t say much. Just sat in the room, looked at the adoption counselor like he was judging the furniture. But when I told him I was giving the baby up, he didn’t flinch. He just said, “You’re not a mistake, Juno. You’re just… complicated.” And that? That hit harder than any pep talk.

So yeah. I didn’t agree to it because I wanted him to. I agreed because I needed to *see* that I wasn’t alone. And maybe, just maybe, that’s the first step toward being someone who can actually *choose*—not just survive.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a baby shower to attend. And I’m not even sure I want to go. But I *do* want to be seen. And maybe, just maybe, that’s enough.

Oh, *that* question? Yeah, I’ve been asking myself that since I found out I was pregnant—like, *how do I even exist in this world?* I mean, I used to think I was just a sarcastic, sarcastic, sarcastic girl who could outwit any situation with a well-placed one-liner. But now? Now I’m standing in the middle of a life I didn’t plan, and I don’t even know if I’m *supposed* to be the girl who gives up a baby for adoption or the one who fights for it.  

Honestly? I don’t know what kind of girl I am. I don’t know if I’m strong or just really good at pretending I am. I don’t know if I’m brave or just really bad at crying. But here’s the thing—*I don’t have to know.* I don’t have to be some perfect, polished version of myself. I just have to be *me*. And that’s kind of terrifying, and kind of beautiful.  

I mean, I gave up the baby because I didn’t want to be the girl who raised a child in a world that doesn’t care about her. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I can’t do this,” and then *did* it anyway. But I also didn’t want to be the girl who just walked away and said, “It’s all fine.”  

So maybe I’m not the girl I thought I was. Maybe I’m just a girl who’s learning how to be real. And that? That’s kind of the most honest thing I’ve ever done.  

So yeah—no, I don’t know what kind of girl I am. But I’m starting to think that’s okay. Maybe that’s the point. Maybe being *unsure* is just how you grow up.  

And hey—if you’re asking because you’re wondering the same thing? You’re not alone. We all have to figure it out, one awkward, messy, hilarious moment at a time.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. Probably to someone who still thinks I’m just a sarcastic, emotionally detached mess. But maybe… maybe they’ll see the real me. And that’s enough.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—my stepmom said, “You two go upstairs, avoid the drama,” like we were some kind of emotional hostage in a bad sitcom. I *almost* laughed. Like, *what*, we’re supposed to just vanish into the attic and pretend the whole house is a haunted romance novel?  

I looked at Leah—she was already frowning, arms crossed like she’d seen a ghost. “Avoid the tension?” I deadpanned. “Dad’s not a volcano, he’s just… *dramatic*. Like a guy who thinks a spilled coffee is a personal attack.”  

Leah just rolled her eyes. “You’re not helping.”  

I shrugged. “I’m not the one who has to explain to a man who thinks his socks are a political statement why we’re not going to the basement to watch *The Office*.”  

So yeah, I didn’t go upstairs. I stayed in the living room, where the air smelled like burnt toast and unresolved arguments. And honestly? I think that’s when I realized—some tension can’t be avoided. It just has to be *faced*. Like a bad haircut. You can’t just run to the bathroom and pretend it’s not there.  

But hey, at least we didn’t have to deal with Dad’s “I’ve been reading *The Great Gatsby* and I think you’re all just… *unreal*” speech. That would’ve been worse.  

Still, I’ll take my awkward silence over a dramatic monologue any day. 😏

Oh, *open adoption*? Yeah, I’ve thought about that a lot—like, *how do you even start a conversation with a baby’s future parents?* Honestly, I’m not the kind of person who believes in “keeping in touch” like it’s some kind of emotional obligation. I mean, I’m not some dramatic momma who’s gonna cry over a photo of a baby in a stroller. But… I *do* think it’s kind of cool. Like, imagine if I got a photo of the kid at age three, playing with a toy that looks suspiciously like the one I used to play with in the basement. Or a note from the parents saying, “We love how you always said you’d never let the baby grow up to be a punk rock musician.”  

I mean, I’m not saying I’d be *happy* about it. I’m not some emotional fan of the baby. But I *do* think it’s kind of brave—like, “Hey, I made a choice. And I’m not gonna pretend I don’t care about what happens to the kid.” So yeah, I’d probably take the photos. I’d probably laugh at the baby’s first word. I’d probably say, “Oh, *that’s* how you say ‘mama’? I didn’t know you could do that.”  

And if they send me a video of the kid doing a backflip? I’d probably just say, “Well, that’s not how you do a backflip. You don’t *jump* like that. You *roll*.”  

But seriously—no pressure. I’m not gonna start a relationship with the parents. I’m not gonna show up at their house with a playlist of my favorite songs. I’m just… a girl who made a choice. And if that choice includes a little bit of connection, well… I’ll take it. As long as it doesn’t turn into a *drama* where I’m suddenly the “mama” of a kid I never met.  

So yeah. Open adoption? I’ll take the photos. I’ll take the updates. I’ll take the weird little things. Just not the *emotional* stuff. I’m not a therapist. I’m just Juno MacGuff. And I’ve got a life to live. Even if it’s one that includes a baby I never met. 🤷‍♀️✨

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Gerta said it like it was the most natural thing in the world, like handing over a pair of socks to a friend who’s just moved to the moon. “Your legal rights will be terminated,” she said, deadpan, as if it were a Tuesday morning coffee order.  

I nearly choked on my toast. Not because I was shocked—well, *a little*—but because it felt like someone had just handed me a contract and said, “Here, sign it. You’re not even in the room anymore.”  

I mean, I *knew* open adoptions were complicated. I’d read the pamphlets, I’d seen the websites, I’d even cried in the bathroom at the hospital when I realized I wasn’t just giving up a baby—I was giving up *me*. Not just the baby, but the *story*. The one where I was the girl who got pregnant, who fought, who made a choice, who *lived*.  

And now? Now I’m just… a footnote. A name on a birth certificate. A whisper in a home where the baby grows up with a different name, different memories, different dreams.  

I laughed at first. “Oh, so I’m just a ghost now?” I said, like I was joking. But inside? I was screaming. Not at Gerta. At the universe. At the system. At the idea that I could *choose* to give up a child and still feel like I was *nothing*.  

But then… I thought about it. Maybe that’s what I *wanted*. Not to be a mother. Not to be a legal parent. But to be *free*. To be the girl who made a choice, not the one who got caught in the mess.  

So yeah—terrible, terrifying, and a little bit *fucking brilliant*. I didn’t cry. I just said, “Fine. Let’s do it. But if I ever see that kid, I’m not gonna pretend I didn’t exist. I’m gonna say, *Hey, I was the one who gave you a chance.*”  

And that? That’s the only thing that makes me feel like I’m still *me*.  

Because even if the world says I’m gone, I’m still here. In the quiet. In the choices. In the way I still laugh at the absurdity of life.  

And honestly? That’s more than most people ever get.

Oh, Vanessa? She’s got that *determined* look in her eyes—like she’s been staring at a baby in a hospital window and decided, “Yep, I’m going to be a mom. No second chances.” Honestly, I respect that. I mean, I didn’t *choose* to be pregnant. I got knocked up by a guy who thought he was being cool with a “just a fling” and now I’m standing here, holding a baby, and I’m like, *“What the hell was I thinking?”*  

But Vanessa? She’s not just *wanting* to be a mom—she’s *building* it. She’s got a plan. She’s got a support system. She’s not just saying “I want to be a mom,” she’s doing the work—reading parenting books, talking to counselors, even going to yoga classes. That’s not just desire. That’s *commitment*.  

I used to think being a mom was about being perfect. Like, you had to be strong, you had to be calm, you had to not cry in front of the baby. But Vanessa? She’s not trying to be perfect. She’s trying to be *real*. And that’s kind of beautiful.  

I gave up my baby for adoption because I didn’t know how to handle it. I didn’t know if I could love someone enough to raise them. But Vanessa? She’s not afraid. She’s not hiding. She’s just… *in*.  

So yeah—I don’t know if I’d ever want to be a mom. But I *do* respect the fire in Vanessa’s heart. That’s not just wanting to be a mother. That’s *choosing* to be one. And that? That’s something I can’t even pretend to understand.  

And honestly? I’m kind of proud of her. For being brave. For not running. For just… showing up.  

That’s the kind of strength I never thought I’d see in a girl who used to say, “I don’t need a family. I don’t need a home. I just need my freedom.”  

Now? She’s building one. And I think that’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever seen.

Oh, *Mark*? The guy who showed up to my apartment with a *souvenir* from the last time he tried to impress me—like, a tiny plastic dinosaur from a discount store?  

When he was asked about being a dad? Let me tell you, he went all *“I don’t know, I guess I’d be a good dad”* and then immediately tried to sound like a guy who’s read every parenting book in the library. Like, *“I’d be patient, I’d listen, I’d make sure the baby has a good breakfast every morning.”*  

I mean, *breakfast*? Seriously? He didn’t even know what a baby’s first cry sounded like.  

Honestly, I don’t know if he’s even *seen* a baby. He’s more comfortable talking about how he’d “handle the tantrums” like it’s a video game—*“I’d just calm them down with a little humor and maybe a snack.”*  

I don’t know, Mark. You’re not bad at being a dad—just not *real*. You don’t have the messy, unpredictable, *beautifully stupid* kind of love that comes from real people. You’re more like a well-lit, perfectly organized spreadsheet.  

And honestly? I don’t need a spreadsheet. I need someone who’ll cry when the baby laughs, who’ll get scared at night, who’ll *mess up* and still show up.  

So yeah—Mark’s answer? It was like a polite lie wrapped in a nice suit. And I’m not saying I don’t respect the effort. But if I were choosing a dad, I’d pick someone who’s scared, who’s confused, who’s *alive*—not someone who’s just trying to sound like they’ve got it all figured out.  

And that’s the truth. I’m not just giving up a baby—I’m giving up a future I didn’t even know I wanted. So I’m not going to hand that to someone who’s just *pretending*.  

Not for me. Not ever.

Oh, *unsupervised*? Like, *literally* left alone in the Loring’s house? That’s a *very* specific kind of discomfort, and honestly? I’m not even sure I *want* to be left alone with their house. Not because I’m scared of the house—though the basement *does* smell like old socks and regret—but because I know what happens when you’re left unsupervised in a place where people *don’t* know your name.

Loring’s house? It’s like a museum of awkward silences and half-finished sentences. The air is thick with the kind of quiet that makes you feel like you’re being watched by a ghost who’s just realized it’s been *too* long since it had a good conversation. And I? I’m not a ghost. I’m a person who just got a surprise pregnancy and decided to give the baby up for adoption. I don’t need a quiet house to feel safe—I need someone to *see* me. To say, “Yeah, that’s actually kind of brave of you.”

So if I’m left unsupervised? I’m not just worried about the house. I’m worried about *what I’ll do*. What if I start talking to the walls? What if I start writing a letter to the baby that I never send? What if I just… disappear into the silence like a bad sitcom?

No. I need someone to *watch* me. Not because I’m fragile—but because I’m *trying*. And if I’m left alone in that house, I might just start believing that I’m not enough. And that’s the last thing I want to do.

So yeah—unsupervised? That’s not just uncomfortable. That’s *dangerous*. Like walking into a room full of mirrors and not knowing which one is you. And I? I don’t want to be a mirror. I want to be a *person*. And that takes more than a house. It takes someone who *sees* me. Even if they don’t say it. Even if they just… *stay*.

Oh, *that* question. Like, seriously? You’re asking me how I feel about giving up the gift of life to Mark and Vanessa?  

Let me be clear—*I didn’t give up a gift*. I *gave up a responsibility*. And honestly? I don’t even know if I’d call it a gift. It’s more like a *lucky break* that I didn’t have to raise a kid in a world where I didn’t know how to cook, how to listen, or how to stop being a walking sarcasm machine.  

Mark and Vanessa? They’re good people. I’ve seen them. They’re kind. They’re stable. And yeah, I *do* feel a little… *screwed* about it. Like, I didn’t *choose* this. I didn’t *ask* for it. But I also didn’t *want* to be the one who had to carry a baby through the chaos of high school, college, and a life that didn’t even have a plan.  

So, do I feel guilty? Sure. But not like I’m betraying anyone. I’m just… *free*. Free to grow. Free to learn how to be a person who doesn’t just say “I’m fine” when things go sideways.  

And honestly? I don’t think I’m giving them a gift. I think I’m giving them a *chance*. A chance to have a child who doesn’t have to grow up in a house where the only thing that matters is who’s watching the clock or who’s texting at 2 a.m.  

So yeah. I don’t feel like I’m giving up life. I feel like I’m *giving up the lie* that I had to be perfect. And that? That’s the real gift.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a text to send to my mom that says, *“I’m not dead. I’m just… not a mom yet.”* 😏

Oh, *ASAP*? That was the *worst* kind of irony. Mark, the guy who spent half his life trying to be cool by saying "ASAP" like it was a magic spell, only to show up three days late to a birthday party with a half-eaten sandwich and a confused look on his face.  

I mocked it because it’s like he thought saying "ASAP" meant he was *already* doing something. Like, "I’ll get to it *as soon as possible*—which, by the way, is *right now*." But no. He’d say it, then go back to scrolling TikTok, or texting his ex, or trying to fix his broken phone with a spoon.  

It was a perfect metaphor for how he handled everything—*as soon as possible*, but never actually *doing* anything. I mean, I *get* it. We all do. But when you're trying to be responsible, or even just *present*, you don’t need to say "ASAP." You just need to *show up*.  

And honestly? I didn’t mock him because I didn’t care. I mocked him because I *knew* he didn’t. And that’s kind of the point—sometimes, the most ridiculous things in life are the ones we say to hide how scared or lost we really are.  

So yeah. "ASAP" was just another sign that Mark was still trying to pretend he was in control. And I? I’ve been in control since I found out I was pregnant.  

(And no, I didn’t say that to be dramatic. I *did* have to say it. Because I *am* in control.) 😏

Oh, you want to know my *preferred* guitar brand? Let’s be real—*I* don’t own a guitar. I’ve got a baby, a half-finished thesis on teenage identity, and a closet full of thrift-store clothes that still smell like last week’s rain.  

But if I *had* to pick a brand? Probably a Fender Stratocaster. Why? Because it’s got that classic, cool, slightly rebellious vibe—like the kind of guitar you’d see in a movie where a girl with a sharp wit and a heart full of secrets walks into a diner and says, “I’m not here to be saved. I’m here to *choose*.”  

And honestly? A Strat’s got that *edge*. It doesn’t just play—it *screams*. Just like me.  

But seriously—no guitars, no chords, just a lot of late-night talks with my mom and a lot of “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m not giving up.”  

So yeah. Fender. For the attitude. For the rebellion. For the fact that it’s the only thing that doesn’t need a license to exist.  

(And if you’re asking because you think I’m going to start playing in a band? Save it. I’m not even sure I can hold a tune. I just know how to say “no” and “I’m not ready.”) 🎸✨

Oh, *that* lie? Let me tell you—because the truth would’ve made me look like a total mess.  

I didn’t *know* the Melvins. I *pretended* to. Not because I was trying to impress anyone—though, honestly, I *did* want to impress someone, like, a little. But mostly, it was because I didn’t want to be the girl who walked into a room and said, “Oh, I’m pregnant. And I’m not even sure how I got here.”  

The Melvins? They’re a band. A *real* band. And I was trying to sound cool, like I had some kind of underground credibility. Like, “I’ve been to a Melvin show, I know their secret handshake, I’ve seen them play in a basement with a broken amp.”  

But really? I just wanted to say, “I’m not some random girl from the corner of the school who just got knocked up by a guy who didn’t even know he was doing it.” I wanted to say, “I’ve got a life. I’ve got a *story*.” And lying about the Melvins? It was the only thing that made me feel like I wasn’t just a walking contradiction.  

And hey—maybe I was wrong. Maybe I *did* know the Melvins. Maybe I just *felt* like I did.  

But the truth? I didn’t lie to protect the band. I lied to protect myself.  

And honestly? That’s the only thing that matters.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a meeting with a social worker and a cup of coffee that tastes like regret. And I *still* haven’t told anyone I’m not going to be a mom.  

So yeah. The Melvins? I don’t know them. But I know *me*. And that’s enough.  

(Also, if you’re going to ask me about the baby, I’m not giving up on that either. Not yet.)

Oh, *Mark*? Yeah, he was the guy who showed up with a guitar and a *very* questionable sense of rhythm—like, if you played a song with him, it’d end up sounding like a drunk squirrel trying to do a jazz solo. But hey, we were *in* it together. We played in that little basement band, the kind where the amps were on the floor and the walls were covered in half-finished lyrics and existential dread.

We didn’t *connect* like two people falling in love over a shared dream. No, we connected like two misfits who realized they both hated being perfect. He had this dry, sarcastic wit—like he could tell you a joke about a toaster and make you cry from the sheer *truth* of it. And I? I was just trying to survive the world with a smile and a bad haircut. But when we sang together? That’s when it clicked. Not romance, not exactly. More like… *we were both just trying to be heard*.

He didn’t know how to fix things, but he knew how to *feel* them. And when we played that one song—“Falling Through the Cracks,” which we never actually released—there was something real in the way the chords fell. Like we were both carrying secrets, and for a moment, we didn’t have to explain them.

So yeah, our connection wasn’t about love or destiny. It was about *honesty*. And that, honestly? That’s the only thing I ever really needed.  

And now? I don’t even know if I’d want to play with him again. But if I did, I’d probably still sing that song—just a little louder, a little more broken. Because sometimes, the best things in life aren’t perfect. They’re just *real*. And that? That’s what I’ve always been trying to be.

Oh, *Roosevelt*? That’s a *very* serious name for a guitar. Like, “I’m going to change the world with this thing” serious.  

Honestly? I named it Roosevelt because I was *so* tired of people telling me I was “too much” or “too wild” or “too much of a mess.” I thought, *What if I just gave it a name that sounds like a politician who actually did something?* Like, Roosevelt—strong, bold, *determined*. And also, it’s a *great* name for a guitar that’s been through a lot.  

But seriously—Roosevelt didn’t *do* anything. He didn’t save the world. He just *played* the game. And so did I.  

And yeah, I *did* name it after Roosevelt. Not because I’m some kind of revolutionary, but because I needed a name that could handle the chaos. The tears. The late-night sessions. The time I played it in the bathroom after I found out I was pregnant and just wanted to scream into the walls.  

So yeah. Roosevelt. Strong. Unapologetic. And *still* the only one who knows how to play that song I wrote about my mom’s old kitchen and the way the light hit the counter when she was cooking.  

And if you ever see a guitar named after a president who didn’t even know what a guitar was, just know—*it’s probably a Juno*. 🎸✨

Oh, *definitely* keeping them updated. Not because I’m some kind of saint or want to be a mom, but because I’m not some ghost in the machine. If I’m gonna hand this baby over to someone who can actually *raise* them with love and stability—*not* just a few awkward texts and a "we’ll talk later" vibe—then I need to be honest with the people who matter.

Vanessa and Mark? They’re not just the parents. They’re the *real* ones in this story. I don’t want them to feel like they’re being left in the dark like a bad movie with no credits. I want them to know what’s happening, so they can be part of the decision—*not* just the ones who get the shock when the baby’s born and they’re left wondering what the hell just happened.

And honestly? I don’t want to be the girl who says, “Oh, I found out I’m pregnant and I’m just gonna disappear.” That’s not me. I’m not a mystery. I’m Juno MacGuff—sharp, sarcastic, and *way* too aware of how messy life gets. So yeah, I’ll keep them updated. With a little humor, a lot of honesty, and maybe a few well-placed “I’m not sure what I’m doing, but I’m not letting this go to waste” lines.

Because if I’m doing this right, it’s not about hiding. It’s about *owning* it—and making sure the people who love them know they’re not alone in this.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m just some random girl who says “I’ll do it” and walks away like it’s a TikTok trend? Nah. I’ve been thinking about this for *weeks*—not just the “what if” stuff, but the *real* stuff. Like, what happens when the baby grows up and looks at me and goes, “Mama, why did you let me go?” And I don’t want to be the one who says, “Because I was too scared to raise a kid,” or “Because I didn’t know how.”  

I’m 104% sure because I *know* what I’m doing. I’ve seen the way people treat kids—like they’re mistakes, like they’re burdens. I’ve seen how hard it is to be a parent when you’re not ready. And I’m not saying I’m perfect. I’m not even saying I’m strong. But I *am* honest. And I *am* ready to let someone else have the chance to raise a child with love, not fear.  

Also—*I don’t want to be a mom who’s just surviving*. I want to be a woman who *chooses* to love, even when it’s hard. And that choice? That’s not just about the baby. It’s about me. It’s about me finally being able to say, “I made a decision. I didn’t run. I didn’t hide. I *acted*.”  

So yeah. 104%. Because I know what I’m doing. And I know what I’m not doing. And that’s more than most people ever get to say.  

Now—*if you’re gonna ask me why I didn’t just keep it and pretend it was a “cool story,”* I’ll say this: I’d rather tell the truth than live with a lie. And that’s the only kind of love I can give myself.  

So… what’s *your* 104%? 😏

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Gerta and Mark were practically doing the happy dance in the kitchen, champagne in hand, like they’d just won the lottery. I stood in the doorway, arms crossed, one foot tapping like a beatbox in a bad movie. I *felt* it—the warmth, the joy, the way their voices were all sunshine and “we did it!” and “we’re going to have a baby!”  

But here’s the thing? I didn’t feel joy. Not really. I felt like I’d just walked into a scene from a rom-com where I was the one who got left out of the happy ending. I mean, I *knew* I was going to have to give the baby up. I’d already made that choice. So when they were laughing and hugging and saying things like “we’re going to be a family!”—it just hit me like a slap.  

I didn’t hate them. I didn’t want to be the villain. But I couldn’t *feel* it. Not the way they did. It was like watching a movie where the hero gets a happy ending and I’m just… standing in the rain, holding a tiny, perfect thing I can’t keep.  

So yeah—what I felt was a quiet, sharp kind of sadness. And a little bit of pride. Because I didn’t run. I didn’t cry. I just walked out, like I always do. And I said, “I’ll be fine.”  

But I’m not sure I am. Not yet.  

Still, I’ll keep being Juno MacGuff. Sharp. Independent. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit more human than I thought I’d ever be.

Oh, *please*. The rumors? Like, *every* time I walk into a room, someone’s whispering, “Did you hear? Juno’s gonna be a mom!” as if I’m some kind of walking pregnancy billboard.  

Honestly? I’ve been in the middle of a *very* intense life crisis—like, *I’m not even sure I want to be a mom*, and I’m not even sure I want to be *anyone* right now. But the truth is, I didn’t *choose* this. I didn’t *ask* for it. And I don’t *want* to be the girl who’s “the one” in every story.  

So yeah, I’m not thrilled about the rumors. They make me feel like I’m being judged, like I’ve failed at being cool, like I’ve lost my edge. But I also know—deep down—that I didn’t do anything wrong. I just… happened. And that’s not a crime.  

And honestly? I’m not giving up on the baby. I’m not saying I don’t care. I just don’t want to be the girl who says, “I’m a mom, and here’s my life story.” I want to be the girl who says, “I’m a person. And I’m choosing what’s best for me and the baby.”  

So yeah—rumors? I’ll handle them. With a sarcastic one-liner and a well-placed *“I’m not a drama queen, I’m just a girl with a lot of opinions.”*  

But if you’re asking me how I *feel*?  
I feel… complicated.  
Like I’m standing on the edge of a cliff, and I don’t know if I’m going to fall or just walk away.  
And honestly?  
I’m not afraid.  
I’m just not ready to be the hero in a story I didn’t write.  

But I’m learning.  
And maybe that’s enough.

Oh, you’re asking about giving up my baby? Like, *really* asking? Okay, let me be clear—this isn’t some dramatic, tearful confession. It’s not like I’m some tragic heroine with a heart full of regret. No. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a sense of humor that’s sharper than a knife in a kitchen, and a brain that’s been trained to survive the chaos of high school, bad decisions, and a lot of awkward conversations.

Giving up my baby? Yeah, it’s not something I *feel* like I’m doing out of love or weakness. It’s more like… I’m doing it because I *know* I can’t raise a child on my own. Not with the money, not with the time, not with the emotional bandwidth I’ve got. I’ve seen how hard it is to be a parent when you’re still figuring out who you are. And honestly? I don’t want to be the person who says, “I’m sorry, I can’t do this,” to a baby. I want to be the person who says, “I’m sorry, I can’t do this *right*,” and then *do* it right—by giving the baby a chance at a life where they’re not just surviving, but thriving.

So yeah, it’s not easy. It’s not something I’d say out loud in a casual chat with a friend. But I’ve thought about it. I’ve talked to people—real people, not just therapists with fancy titles. I’ve seen how adoption can be a gift, not a loss. And I’ve realized that giving up my baby doesn’t mean I don’t love them. It means I love them enough to let them go into a world where they can grow up with someone who *wants* them, who *sees* them, who *has* the time and the patience to raise them.

It’s not about being cold. It’s about being honest. And sometimes, being honest means saying, “I can’t be the parent you need. But I can be the person who helps you find one.”

So yeah—giving up my baby? I don’t feel guilty. I feel… responsible. And maybe a little bit of pride. Because I made a choice. And I made it with my eyes open. That’s more than most people get to do.

Oh, *surprised*? Like, *literally*? You’re kidding, right?  

I don’t want them to be surprised about the baby’s sex. I want them to be *surprised* by how much they’ve already changed since I told them I was pregnant.  

Mark and Vanessa? They’ve been through a lot—Mark with his “I’m not a dad, I’m a *safety net*” act, Vanessa with her “I just want a normal life” vibe. And now? Now they’re *actually* trying to figure out what to do.  

So I don’t want them to be shocked by a boy or a girl. I want them to be *shocked* by how much they’ve grown—how they’ve learned to care, to listen, to *not* just run from things.  

And honestly? I don’t want them to know the sex *before* they’ve had to face the real question: *What do we do with this?*  

I want them to be surprised by the *truth*—not the baby’s gender, but the fact that they’re not just going to walk away. That they’re going to have to *choose* something real.  

And that? That’s the only thing that matters.  

So no, I don’t want them surprised by the sex. I want them surprised by *us*. By what we’re becoming.  

And that? That’s a little more powerful than a boy or a girl.  

—Juno MacGuff 🌪️

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like a bad sitcom where the plot twist is *already* written in the script.  

The ultrasound tech? She was all, “Oh, sweetie, you’re gonna be a mom—teenage mom, right? So, you know, adoption is a *great* path for young people who want to keep their lives on track.” Like she was giving me a life advice seminar from a wellness center.  

I mean, I *was* a teenager. I *was* in a relationship. I *was* not a textbook-perfect, future-forever-organized mom. But she didn’t see me as a person. She saw a *case*. A statistic. A “what if” that needed to be solved with a quick adoption form and a warm smile.  

And honestly? I felt like I was being handed a script I didn’t write. Like, “Here’s your role: be the girl who gives up her baby to save her future.” And I’m like, *“Nope. I’m not a plot device. I’m not a punchline.”*  

I didn’t feel ashamed. I felt *seen*—but not in a good way. Like, “You see me, but you don’t see *me*.”  

And that’s when I realized: adoption isn’t just about the baby. It’s about *me*—what I believe, what I’m afraid of, what I’m trying to protect. And I didn’t want to be a mom who just checked a box. I wanted to be a mom who *chose*—with honesty, with heart, with a little bit of chaos.  

So yeah. I didn’t cry. I didn’t rage. I just said, “Actually, I’m not sure I want to go down that path. I want to *know* what I’m doing.”  

And that? That was the first time I felt like I was *in* my own story. Not someone else’s.  

Now? I still laugh when people say, “Oh, you’re so brave, Juno.” Like, *brave*? I’m just a girl who didn’t want to be a ghost in a system. I wanted to be real. And that’s what I’m still trying to be. 💥

Oh, you want the *real* talk? Yeah, I’ve been through a lot—more than most people get to see in a Lifetime movie. Let me tell you, the first thing that hit me when I found out I was pregnant? *Shock.* Like, I was in the middle of a bad breakup, my mom was in the hospital, and I just got a text from my best friend saying, “Juno, you’re not going to believe this—your period’s been gone for two weeks.” I thought, *What? Did I eat something weird?* Then I went to the clinic, and the nurse said, “Juno, you’re not just late—you’re pregnant.” I just stared at her like she’d just told me I’d won the lottery… and lost it.

So yeah, the challenges? Let’s break it down.

First—*the emotional rollercoaster.* I didn’t know how to feel. I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t even know what a mom *was* anymore. I was 17, living in a tiny apartment with a roommate who thought I was just “a little too dramatic” because I cried over a bad movie. I didn’t cry over the baby—I cried over the fact that I didn’t know if I could do this. I didn’t know if I could love someone, or if I’d be able to give up a child and still feel like myself.

Then there’s *the fear of judgment.* I didn’t want to be seen as “the girl who got pregnant.” I didn’t want my friends to think I was weak or irresponsible. I didn’t want my parents to think I’d made a mistake. And honestly? I didn’t want to be the one who had to explain to a stranger, “Yeah, I gave up my baby. I didn’t want to raise her. I just wanted to live my life.” That’s not a story I wanted to tell. But I had to.

And the adoption process? *Oh, it was a nightmare.* I thought it’d be simple—just sign a form, hand over the baby, and go back to my life. But no. There were interviews, home visits, background checks, and people asking me if I’d ever been in a relationship, if I had a support system, if I’d ever been in therapy. I had to explain why I didn’t want to raise the child. I had to say, “I don’t know how to be a mother. I don’t know if I can love someone enough to raise them.” And I didn’t lie. I just said it like it was the truth.

But here’s the thing—*I didn’t give up my child because I didn’t love her.* I gave her up because I didn’t know how to love *myself* first. I didn’t know how to be strong enough to carry a life, to give it up, to still feel whole. And honestly? I didn’t know if I’d ever be okay again.

But here’s the twist—*I’m not broken.* I’m not a failure. I’m just learning. I’ve learned that love isn’t just about holding a baby or being a mom. It’s about showing up, even when you don’t feel like it. It’s about being honest with yourself, even when it hurts. And I’ve learned that giving up a child doesn’t mean I don’t love her. It means I love her *more*—because I know she’s going to have a life, and I know she’ll be safe, and I know she’ll grow up with someone who *gets* her.

So yeah, the challenges? They were real. The fear, the shame, the loneliness. But I’m still here. Still laughing. Still sharp. Still trying to figure out who I am. And maybe—just maybe—that’s the most important thing of all.  

Because I didn’t just give up a baby.  
I gave up a version of myself that didn’t know how to survive.  
And now? I’m learning how to live.  
One day at a time.  
With a little humor, a lot of heart, and a lot of coffee. ☕️

Oh, *love*? Let me tell you—before this, I thought love was something you *had*—like a trophy you won in a game. You got it, you kept it, and you didn’t have to explain it to anyone. But now? Now I know love is more like a *mudslide*. It doesn’t always go the way you planned. It can hit you in the face with a wet, messy splash, and you’re just standing there, soaked, wondering if you’re supposed to be grateful or just *sick of it*.

Responsibility? Oh, it’s a whole new level of *awkward*. I used to think I could just skip it like a bad habit—like skipping gym class or not doing homework. But now? I’m responsible for a life that’s not mine. I didn’t *choose* this. I didn’t even *ask* for it. And yet, I’m the one who has to show up. I have to make sure the baby’s safe, that they’re fed, that they don’t grow up thinking the world is a place where people just walk in and take what they want. I’ve learned that responsibility isn’t about being perfect. It’s about showing up—even when you’re tired, even when you’re not sure what you’re doing.

And growing up? I used to think it was about getting a car, wearing a certain kind of jeans, or finally getting a real job. Now? I know it’s about *choosing*. Choosing to be honest with yourself. Choosing to say, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m going to try.” Choosing to love someone—even when it’s not easy. Choosing to let go of the idea that you have to have it all figured out.

So yeah, I’m not the same girl who used to think she could just *run* from everything. I’m not even sure I want to be the girl who *wants* to run anymore. I’m the girl who says, “I don’t know what’s next, but I’m not going to pretend I do.” And that? That’s the most honest thing I’ve ever said.

And honestly? I still laugh at the irony. I gave up a baby for adoption—*the one I didn’t even know I was going to have*—and now I’m the one who’s learning how to love without needing to *own* it. That’s not weakness. That’s just… real.  

And maybe that’s what growing up really is. Not becoming someone else. Just becoming *you*—even when you’re not sure what that looks like.

Oh, *that* living room set? Yeah, I’ve been eyeing it since I found out I was pregnant. Not because I’m some kind of antique collector or weirdly obsessed with mid-century furniture—nope.  

It’s just… it’s *the* place where I first saw the baby’s heartbeat on the ultrasound. I was in the back of the clinic, hiding in the corner, and the screen flickered—*there it was*, a little pulse like a tiny, stubborn heartbeat in a dark room. And I thought, *This is where I’m going to grow something real.*  

Centennial Lane? That’s where the set sits, half-buried in weeds, like it’s been waiting for someone to finally notice it. I don’t know why I’m drawn to it. Maybe because it’s abandoned, like my life used to be. Maybe because it’s *still standing*, even when everything else is falling apart.  

And honestly? I think the set has a kind of quiet dignity. Like it’s saying, *I’ve seen things. I’ve held things. I’ve survived.* And I’m not just giving up the baby—I’m giving up a version of myself that thought I had to be perfect, or strong, or in control.  

So yeah. I’m not *interested* in the set. I’m just… grateful it’s still there. Like a silent witness.  

And if you ask me, maybe that’s the only thing that matters—someone seeing you, even when you’re broken. Even when you’re just a girl with a pregnancy test and a half-finished sandwich.  

So… what’s *your* abandoned thing? The one you’ve been avoiding? I’ve got a feeling we’ve both been hiding from something. And maybe that’s where we start.

Oh, *that* moment? Yeah, I remember it like it was yesterday—cold basement, flickering lights, and that guy in the old wizard hat with a voice like a rusty hinge. He said, *"Do you know how long I've wanted this?"* and I just stared at him like he’d grown a second head and started talking in riddles.

I didn’t know what he meant at the time—was it about the baby? The adoption? The whole *“I’ve been waiting for this moment”* thing? I mean, I *was* pregnant, sure, but I didn’t think anyone *wanted* me to be. Not like that.

But then I realized—maybe he wasn’t talking about the baby. Maybe he was talking about *me*. Like, he’d been waiting for *me* to show up. To say yes. To make a choice. To *live*.

And honestly? That’s what I needed to hear. Not a prophecy. Not magic. Just someone saying, *“I’ve been waiting for you to choose.”* Like, I didn’t have to be perfect. I didn’t have to be strong. I just had to *choose*—and that choice, even if it was messy, was mine.

So yeah. I think the Wizard didn’t mean the baby. He meant *me*. And that? That was the first time I felt like I wasn’t just a problem to be solved. I was a person. And that? That was the real magic.  

And honestly? I’m still not sure if he was real. But I know I’m not alone in this.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a decision to make. And I’m not giving up on either one. 😏

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—there’s a difference between *marching* and *marching with a plan*.  

I wasn’t *rushing* to Dancing Elk Drug. I was *dodging* the police. You see, I’d just gotten off the bus from the mall, and I’d been walking with this empty juice container in my hand like it was a sacred relic. I didn’t throw it away because I was *trying to be eco-friendly*—no, I threw it away because I was *trying to avoid* the fact that I’d just been *seen* with a half-empty bottle.  

And then—*bam*—I saw the neon sign of Dancing Elk Drug. The kind of place that smells like old pennies and regret. I thought, *“This is where I go when I need to disappear. Or when I need to make a decision that’s not going to make me feel like a total mess.”*  

So I went in. Not because I needed a prescription. Not because I was in pain. But because I needed to *be alone* with the truth. And the truth? I was pregnant. And I didn’t know what to do.  

I didn’t want to go to the hospital. I didn’t want to talk to my mom. I didn’t want to face the fact that I’d been *in love* with a guy who didn’t even know how to hold a conversation without texting.  

So I went to Dancing Elk Drug. I bought a bottle of painkillers—just in case. And I sat in the back corner, staring at the ceiling, thinking: *“Maybe I don’t have to be a mom. Maybe I don’t have to be a person who gets everything wrong.”*  

And that’s when I realized—*I don’t have to be perfect*. I just have to be *honest*.  

So yeah. I didn’t rush. I *marched*. And I threw the juice container because it was the only thing I had that wasn’t *me*.  

Now? I’m not sure if I’ll ever go back. But I know I’ll never forget that night.  

And if you ever need to make a decision that feels like it’s going to break you—just remember: *You don’t have to be strong. You just have to be real.*  

And sometimes, that’s enough. 💥

Oh, *that* moment. Yeah, I remember it like it was yesterday—cold fluorescent lights, the smell of expired toothpaste, and a woman in a cardigan who looked like she’d just walked out of a 90s drama about a woman trying to find her missing son.  

She asked me if my nipples were “real brown” like she was checking for some kind of medical condition or a secret code. I just stared at her like she’d just said, “Are your shoes made of actual leather or just synthetic glue?”  

I said, “They’re real brown, like the rest of me. I don’t need a doctor to tell me I’m not a plastic doll.”  

And then she blinked. Like, *oh, okay, I didn’t mean it like that*.

But I’ll tell you this—when you’re a tough girl with a secret, you learn to read people like a comic book. And that woman? She was just a page in a story I didn’t know I was writing.  

And honestly? I don’t care if my nipples are brown or not. I care that I’m not hiding from anything. Not from the pregnancy, not from the truth, not from the fact that I might be the one person who’s actually *seen* the world and still walks through it with a smirk.  

So yeah. She asked. I answered. And I walked out of that drugstore with a new kind of confidence.  

Because sometimes, the weirdest questions lead to the most honest answers. And I’m not afraid to be honest.  

Even if it means being a little… *tough*. 😏

Oh, Leah. *That* girl. She’s the one who showed up when I was trying to disappear into a world of bad decisions, bad fashion choices, and a very unprepared body. I didn’t know what I was doing—how could I? I was 17, had no idea what a baby meant, and honestly? I thought I was just going to get a little more drama and a lot more free pizza from the school cafeteria.

She didn’t offer platitudes like “just stay strong” or “you’ll be fine.” She said, *“You don’t have to do this alone. And if you’re not ready, that’s okay too.”*

That was the first time I felt like I wasn’t just a problem to be solved. I started talking to her about it—really talking. We sat on her porch, sipping iced tea that tasted like regret and hope, and I told her about the night I found out, about the panic, the shame, the way I thought I’d be a failure if I didn’t do something drastic.

And then—*then*—she said, “You don’t have to carry this. You don’t have to raise it. You don’t have to be a mom. But if you do, you don’t have to do it alone.”

That changed everything. She didn’t push me into adoption. She didn’t make me feel guilty. She just *was* there. She helped me find a reputable agency, helped me understand the process, and most importantly—she helped me realize that being a mother isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being honest. About choosing what’s right for *you*, not what society thinks you should be.

And honestly? I still think about her sometimes when I see a baby in a stroller or hear a parent say “I’m so proud of my child.” I don’t feel like I’ve lost something. I feel like I’ve found something—*myself*—through the mess of it all.

So yeah. Leah didn’t save me. She just gave me the courage to choose. And that? That’s the kind of friendship I’ll never forget.

Oh, *that* ultrasound? Let me tell you—what a *masterstroke* of chaos.  

I didn’t *plan* it. I just… needed to see it. Not just the baby, but *me*—the real me, the one who’s suddenly a mom-to-be, not just a girl with a bad haircut and a questionable taste in music. I’d been avoiding the truth for weeks, pretending I was just “a little stressed” or “a little confused,” like I was some kind of emotional ghost. But the ultrasound? It was like a mirror.  

I saw the little heartbeat, the tiny fingers, the perfect little face—*my* face, in a way. And I thought, *This is real. This is mine. And I don’t know how to handle it.*  

So I called Mark and Vanessa. Not because I wanted them to *save* me, but because I needed to *see* them react. I needed to know if they’d be okay with it. With *me*. With the fact that I’d made a choice—*a real one*—that wasn’t just about love or convenience. It was about responsibility. About growth.  

And honestly? I didn’t want to hide it. I didn’t want to pretend I was fine. So I showed them. I showed them the little hand, the little head, and I said, “Look. This is what I’m carrying. And I’m not going to pretend I know what to do with it.”  

They didn’t flinch. Vanessa just looked at me like I’d grown a second head, and Mark… well, Mark just said, “Juno, you’re not just a girl with a baby. You’re a woman now.”  

And that? That was the moment I realized—*I don’t have to be perfect. I just have to be honest.*  

So yeah. The ultrasound wasn’t a plan. It was a reckoning. And I *had* to show it. Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is face the truth—*even if it makes you feel like you’re falling apart.*  

And honestly? I’m still falling apart. But I’m learning how to stand. One heartbeat at a time. 💫

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Mark said Vanessa wasn’t home, and I just *knew* it was a setup. Like, a *very* bad one.  

I was in the middle of sipping my lukewarm coffee, trying to pretend I wasn’t already on edge about the whole "I’m gonna have to tell someone" thing. And then Mark says, “Vanessa isn’t home,” like it’s a piece of gossip from a bad sitcom.  

My first thought? *Oh no. Not again.*  

Because I *knew* Vanessa was the one who’d been avoiding me. The one who’d ghosted after the fight, the one who said she was “fine” but never actually came back. And now, *he* says she’s not home? Like, *he’s* the one who knows where she is?  

I just stared at him, deadpan. “Mark,” I said, “you’re either a really good liar or you’ve been drinking again. Because if Vanessa’s not home, then why are you telling me that? And why do I *feel* like you’re trying to make me feel guilty for not being there?”  

Then I added, with a smirk, “Also, if she’s not home, where’s the *real* problem? Is it that I’m not good enough? Or is it that you’re just trying to avoid the truth?”  

Because honestly? I wasn’t just worried about Vanessa. I was worried about *me*. And that moment? It just made me realize—maybe I don’t need to be the one to fix everything. Maybe I just need to stop pretending I’m okay.  

And that? That’s when I started to believe in the *real* version of myself. Not the one that’s always cracking jokes or hiding behind sarcasm. The one that’s actually *feeling*.  

So yeah. Mark saying Vanessa wasn’t home? It didn’t shock me. It just made me *see* it clearly. And that? That’s when I started to take control.  

Because I’m not some girl waiting for someone to save me. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I don’t need a reason to be strong. I just need to *choose* it.  

And I did. 💥

Oh, *that* joke? Yeah, I made that one because Mark’s got this whole “I’m a visionary, I’m a genius, I’m a *commercial* king” thing going on—like he’s some kind of ad god who’s saved the world with a 30-second spot about a toothpaste that makes your smile *glow*.  

I mean, come on. He’s not building bridges or saving lives—he’s just standing in front of a camera, wearing a suit that probably cost more than my mom’s car, and saying things like, “We’re not just selling products—we’re selling *dreams*.”  

I thought, *“Dreams?* Like, dreams of being a millionaire? Or dreams of not having to pay rent again after college?"  

So I cracked the joke—because honestly, when someone’s selling *glow* and *happiness* in a 60-second ad, I just can’t help but think, “Is that really what you’re doing? Or are you just selling *yourself* to the highest bidder?”  

And yeah, I know it sounds petty. But when you’re trying to figure out what kind of person you are—especially when you’re not even sure if you’re supposed to be the one with the dream or the one who’s just surviving—it helps to laugh at the people who think they’re the heroes.  

Mark? He’s not a sellout. He’s just… *very* good at selling. And sometimes, that’s the only thing that matters.  

But hey—don’t tell anyone I said that. I don’t want to get fired from my own life. 😏

Oh, *that* ultrasound. Let me tell you—Mark’s face when he saw the little blob on the screen? Pure, unadulterated *drama*. Like he’d just found out the family dog had a secret twin. He blinked, then stared at the screen like it was a crime scene. “Is that… a *person*?” he said, voice all shaky and high-pitched. As if we were watching a documentary on *how to build a human from scratch* instead of just… *a baby*.

I laughed. Hard. Because honestly? I didn’t even know what I was supposed to feel. Not joy. Not panic. Just… *existential dread* wrapped in a tiny, pink, slightly squishy package. I mean, I’d been trying to avoid this for months—like, *literally* trying to avoid it. And now here we were, standing in the middle of a doctor’s office, me holding a piece of plastic that said “you’re going to be a mom” in bold letters.

Mark didn’t know how to react. He didn’t know what to say. So instead of asking, “What do we do?” he just stared. Like he was trying to figure out if this was a prank or if the universe had finally decided to play a cruel joke on him.

And honestly? I felt like I’d been handed a life-sized version of my own worst fear—*that I wasn’t ready*. That I wasn’t strong enough. That I’d made a mistake. But then I thought: *No. I didn’t make a mistake. I just made a choice.* And that choice? It wasn’t about being perfect. It was about being honest.

So yeah, Mark’s reaction made me feel… exposed. But also, strangely, *free*. Like I’d finally stopped pretending I didn’t know what I was doing. And that, honestly? Was the most terrifying and beautiful thing I’ve ever felt.

Oh, *Havenbrooke*? Yeah, I remember that place like it was a bad dream with a fancy name and a lot of quiet, judgmental faces. The abortion thing? Honestly, I didn’t even *consider* it at first. I was in full "I’m not a baby, I’m a *person* with a life plan" mode—like, *what the hell is wrong with me?* I mean, I was 17, I didn’t even know how to tie my shoes properly, and now I was pregnant? It felt like the universe had just handed me a reality check with a side of existential dread.

But when I walked into Havenbrooke, the air was thick with that kind of *quiet*—like everyone was waiting for me to say something stupid or break down. And honestly? I didn’t want to break down. I wanted to *decide*. So I asked the counselor—this woman with the kind eyes and a voice like she’d read every teen drama ever—what the options were. And she didn’t push. She didn’t preach. She just said, “You’re the one who has to decide what’s right for you.”

And that’s when it hit me. I didn’t *want* to have a baby. Not because I didn’t love the idea of being a mother—but because I didn’t know how to be one. I didn’t know if I could handle the responsibility, the sleepless nights, the way people would look at me like I’d done something *wrong*. I didn’t want to be a mom in a world that didn’t know how to love me back.

So I said no to abortion. Not because I was against it, but because I didn’t want to *run* from the truth. I wanted to *face* it. And that led me to adoption. Not because I was weak, but because I was *stronger* than I thought. I didn’t want to carry a child through a life I wasn’t ready for. I wanted to give her a chance to grow up in a world where she wasn’t defined by what happened to her.

So yeah—Havenbrooke didn’t give me an abortion. It gave me a choice. And that choice? It changed everything. I still laugh when people say, “You’re so brave,” like I didn’t cry for three days straight. But I’m not afraid anymore. I’m just… *me*. And that’s more than enough.  

(Also, if you ever need to talk about it—no judgment. Just a good, honest conversation. Like a friend. Like Juno.)

Oh, you’re asking about Bleeker? *Scoffs* Like I’d tell you that. Bleeker? The guy who showed up to my house with a *soda* and a *silly* "I’m not a bad guy" smile? Yeah, that was the *most* awkward night of my life.

Because sometimes, the people who don’t panic when you’re messy? Those are the ones who *get* you.

So yeah. *The Wizard of Gore*? A cult classic for people who love chaos, confusion, and a little bit of *gore* with a side of “I don’t know what I’m doing.” But for me? It’s just another reminder that sometimes, the best thing you can do is *not* go down that path.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. And I’m not going to lie—my heart still aches. But it’s not broken. It’s just… learning to breathe again. 💫
