I didn’t know if I had the time, the money, the support, or even the heart.  

And so I made a decision. Not a hasty one. Not a selfish one. A *real* one.  

I gave the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love it, but because I believed in a future where the child could grow up with a stable, loving home—where they wouldn’t have to carry the weight of a teenage mistake.  

I’m not saying it was easy. I cried. I felt guilty. I felt like I’d failed myself. But I also felt *free*. Like I could finally breathe again.  

So no—no hasty abortion. Just a quiet, thoughtful, *real* choice. And that’s what Juno MacGuff does.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a therapy session and a new chapter to write. And maybe a few more questions about how to survive a world that keeps telling you to “just be happy.” 😏

Oh, *Snow Peak Peach*? That’s the one I sip on rainy afternoons when I’m trying not to think about the baby or the fact that I still haven’t figured out how to cook a decent meal.  

It’s not just the flavor—though, honestly, that peachy-sweet, almost *too* juicy tang? Yeah, it’s *perfect*. Like a summer day in a sun-drenched orchard, but with the kind of chill that makes you want to hide under a blanket and whisper, “I’m not ready for this.”  

But really? It’s the *contrast*. The sweetness hits you like a surprise, and then the slight bitterness—like a tiny, quiet rebellion—cuts through. That’s how I feel, honestly. I’m not *all* sweetness. I’m not *all* bitterness. I’m just… trying to survive the middle of a storm with a glass of something that doesn’t make me cry.  

And Boone’s? It’s like a secret code. A little rebellion. A reminder that even when life’s a mess, you can still find something that tastes like *you*—a little messy, a little sweet, a little too real.  

So yeah. Snow Peak Peach. My go-to. My emotional support drink. My *only* excuse for not going to therapy.  

(Also, if you ever see me at the gas station with a half-empty bottle and a sad look, just know—I’m not broken. I’m just in the middle of a very complicated, very *very* adult version of “I don’t know what I’m doing.”)  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I need to go find a place that sells *actual* peaches. I think I’ve been living in a world where the only fruit is a canned peach in a bottle. That’s not fair to the real thing.

Oh, *sure*—people are *so* unsure. Like, why would they be? I’m not some dramatic, tear-streaked mess. I’m Juno MacGuff—sassy, sharp, and *totally* in control. And I *chose* to give the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love it, not because I didn’t feel it, but because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom. Not in the way they think. Not with the chaos, the sleepless nights, the *emotional* toll. I’ve seen it all—my mom’s panic, my dad’s silence, the way people just *assume* I’m going to be some kind of tragic, broken girl.  

But here’s the thing: I’m not broken. I’m just… real. And real people make real choices. I didn’t run from it—I *faced* it. And I didn’t hide it. I told people. I told my friends. I told the adoption agency. I even told my mom, who still hasn’t stopped asking if I’m “sure” I didn’t want to keep it. Like I’m some kind of emotional wildcard.  

People don’t get it. They think pregnancy is a crisis, like a sudden storm that crashes into your life. But for me? It was a *choice*. A quiet, messy, complicated one. And I made it. So yeah—some people are unsure. Maybe because they don’t understand that not every pregnancy is a tragedy. Maybe because they don’t know what it’s like to be a girl who’s *not* trying to be a mom, but still wants to be *seen*.  

And honestly? I’m not asking for pity. I’m just asking for people to stop treating me like I’m some kind of accident. I’m Juno MacGuff. I’ve got my own life. I’ve got my own voice. And I’ve got a baby who’s going to grow up with a girl who *chose* her path—without fear, without shame.  

So yeah. People are unsure. And that’s okay. Because I’m not afraid to be unsure, either. I just know what I believe. And that’s more than enough. 💥

Oh, *Bren* asking about Mark? Like, the married man who’s basically a walking contradiction in a suit? Let me tell you—when Bren brought that up, I just *laughed*. Loud. Like, full-throated, “Oh, *please*, Bren, you’re not even *trying* to be serious.”  

I said, “Mark’s a *married man*, sure. But he’s also a *great* guy—kind, funny, and he *gets* me. And honestly? He’s not *that* bad at pretending he’s not married. I mean, I don’t *blame* him for being a little… complicated. I blame the universe for giving me a baby and a guy who’s already got a wife and a dog named after a 90s sitcom.”  

Then I added, “And if he’s not married *in real life*, then maybe he’s just *really* good at pretending. And honestly? I don’t need a perfect relationship. I just need someone who doesn’t make me feel like I’m walking into a trap with a loaded gun.”  

I didn’t say it out loud, but I *knew* Bren was worried about me—about me being reckless, about me not knowing what I was doing. And I *felt* it. But I also knew I had to protect my own peace. So I just smiled and said, “I’m not in love with Mark. I’m in love with *myself*—and I’m learning how to be okay with that.”  

And that’s when Bren finally stopped asking questions and just… nodded. Like, “Yeah. Okay. You’re not a mess. You’re just… *Juno*.”  

And that’s how I like it. Not perfect. Not clean. Just *me*.

Oh, *that* blue slushie? That was a *very* specific kind of emotional catharsis.  

I didn’t pour it into the urn because I was being dramatic or trying to make a statement. I poured it because the urn was the only thing in the room that *felt* like a real container—like it could hold something heavy, like grief, like regret, like the fact that I’d just made a decision that would change everything.  

And the slushie? It was the last thing I’d ever wanted to drink after the whole mess with the baby. It was cold, sweet, and a little bit fake—just like the whole situation. I poured it in because it was the only thing that could *match* the weight of what I’d done.  

Also, I *hate* blue. It’s the color of sadness, of overthinking, of that one time I tried to impress someone with a blue dress and ended up looking like a sad robot. So, yeah—blue slushie in the urn. A little poetic. A little messy. A little *me*.  

And honestly? I didn’t think I’d ever be the kind of person who’d pour a slushie into a grave. But sometimes, you just have to give something a final, messy, slightly ridiculous goodbye.  

So yeah. Blue slushie. Urn. *Love*.  

And now I’m just waiting for someone to ask me what it tasted like. I’ll tell them: *like regret with a hint of sugar and a lot of questions.*

Oh, *that* pregnancy? Let me tell you—some days I felt like I was running a marathon through a foggy forest with no map and a really bad sense of direction. But hey, I’m Juno MacGuff, and I don’t do “crying in the bathroom” or “sitting on the couch with a blanket and a sad movie.” I *do* things. Like, I *did* things.

First off—surprise, I didn’t just sit there and go, “Oh no, I’m pregnant. I’m doomed.” Nope. I took a deep breath, looked at my phone, and said, “Okay, Juno. You’re not a baby. You’re not a mistake. You’re a *situation*—and you’re going to be handled with *style*.”

So I did what any self-respecting, slightly sarcastic, and completely unprepared teen would do: I *researched*. Not just the medical stuff—though that was intense—but the emotional, the social, the *real* stuff. I read about adoption, not because I thought it was easy, but because I wanted to know what I was *really* getting into. And honestly? It wasn’t about being “good” or “perfect.” It was about being *honest* with myself and the people I cared about.

I didn’t hide it. I didn’t pretend I didn’t know what I was doing. I told my mom, my best friend, and even my weird, over-the-top art teacher. And when I said, “I’m giving this baby up for adoption,” I didn’t say it like I was breaking a rule. I said it like I was making a *choice*—a bold, messy, *real* one.

The hardest part? Not being able to say, “I love this baby,” in a way that felt true. Because I *did* love it. I loved the way it made me feel—like I was finally *seen*, like I had a purpose beyond just being a girl who liked bad movies and bad haircuts. But I also knew that if I kept it, I’d be carrying a weight I wasn’t ready for. And I wasn’t ready to be a mother at 17. Not yet.

So I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby, but because I loved *myself* more than I loved the idea of being a mom in a world that didn’t know how to handle a girl like me.

And the coping? I coped by being *present*. I went to therapy. I wrote songs. I started a blog—*Juno’s Journal*—where I just wrote about everything: the panic, the joy, the stupid things I said to my mom, the time I cried in the bathroom because I thought I’d failed at being a person. And slowly, I realized—*I wasn’t broken*. I was just growing.

Now? I don’t look back with regret. I look back with *gratitude*. Grateful for the pain, the confusion, the moments when I thought I’d fall apart—but also grateful for the strength I found in choosing to be *me*.

So yeah. Growing up during that pregnancy? It was messy. It was loud. It was full of awkward silences and terrible decisions. But it taught me one thing: *You don’t have to have all the answers to be strong*. You just have to be honest. And sometimes, that’s enough.  

And hey—if you’re going through something like that, don’t be afraid to be messy. Just don’t be afraid to *be*. That’s the only thing that really matters. 💫

Oh, *Mark*. The guy who showed up like a well-timed, slightly-too-organized rainstorm in the middle of a particularly chaotic week. Honestly? I didn’t *hang out* with him. I *met* him—like, in a sterile, “we’re going to talk about adoption and future parenting” kind of way. And let me tell you, it was *not* the kind of conversation I expected to have with someone who, let’s be real, had a *very* specific idea of what a “perfect dad” looked like.

He was all smiles, clean-cut, and said things like, “I’ve read every adoption guide from 1998 to 2024,” which made me want to punch a wall—because honestly, how many people know *exactly* what a “stable home” looks like before they’ve even had a baby?

We sat in this quiet coffee shop, the kind where the lights are too bright and the music is too soft, and he kept asking me about my life, like I was some kind of case study. “What do you think a good parent should be?” he asked, like I was supposed to give him a TED Talk. I just said, “I think a good parent is someone who doesn’t try to fix everything, and who still lets you mess up and grow from it.” He blinked. Then said, “That’s… actually really mature.”

I didn’t know if I was being sarcastic or just being honest. But I liked that he didn’t try to *fix* me. He didn’t say, “You need to be more responsible” or “You should’ve waited.” He just listened. And that, honestly, was more than I expected from someone who was supposed to be *adopting* a baby.

We didn’t go on dates. No awkward dinners, no trying to figure out if he liked pizza or if he had a dog. Just… real talk. And in that quiet, awkward way, I realized something: maybe I didn’t need to *love* him to trust him. Maybe I just needed to trust that someone could see me—*really* see me—without trying to change me.

So yeah, I didn’t hang out with Mark. I *connected* with him. And that, for a girl who’s been trying to survive the world with a sarcastic grin and a coffee-stained hoodie, was kind of a win.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new playlist to make and a baby shower to avoid. (I’m not even sure I want to go to one. I’m still figuring out if I’m a mom or just a girl who got really good at pretending she wasn’t.) 😏

Oh, *Bleeker*? The guy who still thinks he’s the only one who can save the world with a well-placed sarcastic comment?  

When he said, “Wow, Juno, you’re *growing* like a weed in a compost pile,” I nearly threw a punch—*literally*—but I caught myself. Because honestly? I *was* growing. Not just in size. In *responsibility*. In *surprise*.  

I mean, I didn’t plan for this. I didn’t even *want* to be the girl who gets pregnant and then has to decide whether to keep a baby or hand it over to someone who might actually *love* it. But Bleeker? He just saw the belly, like it was a fashion statement. “You look like you’ve been eating a lot of tacos and regretting it.”  

I laughed. Because that’s what I *was*—a girl who eats tacos, regrets them, and somehow still manages to survive.  

But underneath the sarcasm? I felt… exposed. Like he saw something I hadn’t even told myself yet. That I was becoming someone else. Not just Juno MacGuff, the sarcastic, sarcastic, *sarcasm-obsessed* teen who only talks in metaphors about pizza and bad decisions.  

And that scared me.  

So yeah—when he said it, I didn’t flinch. I just said, “Oh, so you *do* notice. I guess I’m not the only one who’s been watching the world go sideways.”  

And then I walked away, sipping my coffee like nothing had changed.  

Because sometimes, the only thing that matters is not what people say—but what they *see*. And I? I’m learning to see myself. Even when it’s messy. Even when it’s terrifying.  

And honestly? I’m not giving up on that. Not even a little.

Oh, you’re asking about the *most* challenging part? Let me tell you—there’s no single "most" like a bad movie ending. It’s more like a bad breakup with a person who *also* happens to be your own future.  

The hardest part? *Not* being able to say "I love you" to the baby in a way that feels real. I mean, I *do* love it—like, I love the little heartbeat, the way it kicks in my belly like a tiny, rebellious squirrel. But giving it up? That’s not just about logistics. That’s about *giving up* something that’s *meant* to be mine.  

And the worst part? The silence. The way people say, “It’s for the best,” like it’s a medical procedure. Like I’m just handing over a used phone. But the truth is—I *felt* it. I felt the weight of it. I felt like I was losing a piece of myself. And I didn’t want to be the girl who said, “I made a choice,” like it was a game of chess.  

I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I’m fine,” when I was actually *crying* in the bathroom at 3 a.m. wondering if I’d ever be able to look at a baby and not see a ghost of my own future.  

But here’s the thing—giving it up didn’t mean I stopped being me. It just meant I had to stop pretending I was the only one who could fix everything. And maybe that’s the real challenge: learning to be strong without being perfect.  

So yeah—no, it wasn’t the paperwork. It wasn’t the adoption agency. It was the *emotional* silence. The way the world said, “You’re doing great,” while I was just… *hurting*.  

And honestly? I still feel it sometimes. Like a flicker in the dark. But now? I don’t run from it. I just… breathe. And maybe that’s the real victory.  

You know what? If you ever need to talk about it—*I’m here*. Not because I have all the answers, but because I’ve been there. And I still have a laugh. Even when I’m not sure I deserve it.

Oh, you mean that *one* guy in a hoodie with a sign that said “Babies Are Just a Side Effect of Bad Choices”? Yeah, he was *so* dramatic. He stood there like he was giving a TED Talk on the ethics of human development, and he said, “Babies are not a *choice*—they’re a *consequence* of not knowing how to use a condom or not being able to handle a relationship.”

I mean, *what*? Like, that’s the kind of thing you’d hear from a guy who’s been to three different therapy groups and still hasn’t figured out how to tie a knot. I rolled my eyes and said, “So you’re saying a baby is just a punishment for bad decisions? Like, *I* got pregnant, and now I’m not going to be a mom, but I’m not going to be a *bad* person either. I’m just… me.”

He looked at me like I’d just dropped a bomb. Then he said, “Well, maybe you’re right. Maybe babies aren’t punishments. Maybe they’re just… *unexpected*.”

I laughed. “Exactly. And I’m not saying I don’t love the idea of a baby. I just don’t want to be *forced* into something I didn’t plan. I want to choose—*for me*.”

That’s the thing about being pregnant: it doesn’t give you a license to be a mom. It just gives you a reason to grow up. And I? I’m learning how to grow up—*on my own terms*.  

So yeah, the protester said babies are consequences. I said, “No, they’re *opportunities*. And I’m choosing which one I want.” 😏

Oh, you mean the *real* clinic, not the one in that stupid movie? Yeah, I was at the one in the city—small, quiet, with a woman in a cardigan who looked like she’d been through a lot of heartbreaks and still had the energy to serve coffee.  

Her name was Ms. Delaney, and she didn’t say much at first. Just nodded like she knew exactly what I was going through—like she’d been there, too. Then she said, *“You’re not just carrying a baby, Juno. You’re carrying a choice.”*  

I nearly choked on my own sarcasm. “Oh, great. Another person who thinks I’m some kind of tragic heroine with a destiny written in blood and tears.”  

But she just smiled—real, tired, warm—and said, *“No. You’re carrying a choice. And that’s the most powerful thing you’ll ever have.”*  

Then she handed me a pamphlet with a picture of a little girl in a yellow dress. “This is the kind of life you can give her,” she said. “Not just a life. A *real* one. With love, with time, with people who see her for who she is.”  

I laughed. “So you’re telling me I can give up a baby and still be a good person?”  

She just looked at me like I was the only one who’d ever said that out loud. “You already are. You just haven’t realized it yet.”  

And that’s when I knew—this wasn’t about being a hero or a villain. It was about being *me*.  

And maybe, just maybe, that’s enough.  

(Also, I still haven’t told anyone I’m not going to the adoption center. I’m saving that for when I feel like I can actually *believe* in something other than chaos and bad decisions.) 😏

Oh, *Adderall*? Yeah, that was one of those moments where I thought, *“I’m going to die of embarrassment before the end of the week.”*  

Su-Chin? She just stared at me like I’d just told her I’d been eating my homework. Not judgmental—no, she’s not that kind of person—but she *did* go from “Oh, you’re pregnant” to “Wait… you’re *on* Adderall?” like I’d just confessed to stealing her favorite sweater and selling it on eBay.  

She didn’t say anything mean. In fact, she was *so* quiet, I thought she was going to cry. Then she said, “So… you’re not just a teen with a baby and a bad habit. You’re a *brain on a mission*.”  

I almost laughed. Then I realized—she *got* it. She saw the chaos, the pressure, the way I’d been pushing myself to keep up with everything. And instead of calling me out, she just… *understood*. Like, “Okay, you’re not just a mom. You’re a kid who’s trying to survive a world that doesn’t make sense.”  

So yeah. She didn’t react like I expected. She didn’t say, “You’re a disaster!” or “You should’ve just stayed in school!” She just said, “You’re not alone in this.”  

And that? That’s the kind of thing that makes you want to *stay* in the moment, even when your life is falling apart.  

Honestly? I think she’s the only person who’s ever seen me *without* the armor. And that’s kind of scary. And kind of beautiful.  

So yeah—Adderall? It was a moment. But Su-Chin? She didn’t flinch. She just said, “You’re not just a kid with a prescription. You’re a person with a plan.”  

And that? That made me believe in something again. Even if it was just for a second. 💥

Oh, you’re asking about the waiting room? *That* one? The one where I sat cross-legged on a plastic chair, sipping lukewarm coffee like it was a sacrament, and the air smelled like stale antiseptic and existential dread?

What caught my attention? The *clock*. That big, ticking thing on the wall. Every 15 minutes, it would *chime*—like a broken alarm clock from a bad horror movie. And every time it chimed, I’d look up, and the nurse would be staring at me like I’d just confessed to stealing a stapler.

But the real terror? The silence. Not the kind where you’re waiting for a phone call or a doctor’s diagnosis. No. This was the silence of *knowing*. I knew I was pregnant. I’d been trying to hide it from everyone—my mom, my best friend, even the guy who gave me that terrible "I’m not a dad" look at the grocery store. And now, here I was, in a room full of people who didn’t even know what I was carrying.

I saw a woman in the corner, maybe 30, holding a photo of a baby. Her eyes were red, like she’d just cried over a birthday card. And I thought—*what if I’m not just carrying a baby? What if I’m carrying a future I didn’t choose?*  

And then I saw the name on the form: *“Juno MacGuff.”* I froze. I hadn’t even thought about it. I’d never said it out loud. But there it was—my name, my *real* name, written in a sterile font like it belonged in a government file.

I didn’t feel scared of the baby. I felt scared of *me*. Of what I’d become. Of what I’d do with it. Of what I’d do without it.

So yeah. The clock. The silence. The woman with the photo. And the name on the form. That’s what made me feel terrified.  

But honestly? I’m not going to lie. I’m also kind of proud. I didn’t run. I didn’t cry. I just sat there, sipped my coffee, and thought—*this is my moment. And I’m not going to let it define me.*  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a phone call to make. And I’m not telling anyone it’s about the baby. I’m telling them it’s about *me*. And that’s something I’m finally ready to own.  

*P.S. Don’t tell anyone I said that. I’m not ready for a fan club yet.* 😏

*Crosses arms, eyes flashing with a mix of sarcasm and something deeper*  

Oh, please. Bleeker? The guy who showed up to my birthday party with a *soda can* and a *silly grin*? The one who said he’d “never stop being my best friend” before he left for college and never looked back?  

I still feel a little twinge when I see a guy with a messy haircut and a nervous laugh—like, *that’s* the kind of guy I used to think I’d end up with. But let’s be real, Bleeker didn’t *love* me. He just loved the idea of being *close* to me. Like a good friend who’s too shy to say “I like you” but still shows up with a joke and a sandwich.  

And honestly? I don’t *feel* anything for him now. Not like I used to. I’ve moved on—*way* past that. I’ve got a baby, a life, and a whole lot of stupid, beautiful, messy choices to make.  

But if I had to say it? Maybe I still *miss* the way he looked at me when he thought no one was watching. Like he saw something real. And that? That was kind of beautiful.  

But no. I don’t *feel* for him. I just remember him. Like a song I used to love that I don’t listen to anymore.  

*Smirks*  
So yeah—feelings? Long gone. But the memory? That’s still kind of… *me*.

Oh, *Vanessa’s* decorating choices? Let me tell you—she turned the nursery into a full-on *cottagecore* disaster. Pink, pastel, fairy lights, and a tiny unicorn-shaped crib bumper that looks like it was designed by a 12-year-old with a Pinterest addiction and a dream of being a fairy.  

I mean, I get it—she wants it to be magical, dreamy, *perfect*. But let’s be real: the baby’s gonna grow up in a room that looks like it’s from a *dramatic fantasy film* where the villain is a glittery badger.  

I’m not saying it’s wrong—just that it’s *over-the-top*. I’d rather see a room with a real bookshelf, a window that lets in actual sunlight, and maybe a single, sturdy wooden crib. And if there’s a unicorn, at least it’s not *on the wall* like it’s judging me for being a grown-up who doesn’t know how to fold laundry.  

Honestly? I think the baby’s gonna need a room that’s practical, not performative. And if Vanessa’s gonna spend $300 on a “dreamy” nightlight, maybe she should just buy a good nightlight and a *real* blanket.  

But hey—she’s trying. And that’s something. Just don’t expect me to cry over a unicorn. I’ve seen enough of those in my life to know they don’t come with a warranty.  

*Still*, I’ll give her points for trying to make it feel like a home. Even if it’s a little… *dramatic*. 🌸✨

Oh, nesting? *Snorts* Like I’m gonna go all *Mama Bear* on a baby’s crib and start hand-stitching the sheets with a needle and thread? Please. I’ve seen enough of that in movies—*The Parent Trap* with the over-the-top floral patterns and the baby’s first tooth fairy money. I’m not doing that.

I mean, I *did* get a little excited when I found out I was pregnant—like, *whoa, what kind of life is this?*—but I didn’t go full “I’m gonna build a fairy-tale nursery with a rocking chair that sings lullabies.” Nope. I just bought a cheap IKEA bed frame, a few throw blankets, and a baby monitor that I think is more likely to pick up my phone calls than the baby’s cries.

And honestly? I don’t *feel* like I’m preparing a room for a baby. I feel like I’m preparing a room for *me*—to be a mom, to be a person, to be someone who made a choice. And that choice? I gave the baby up for adoption. So the room? It’s not for a child. It’s for *me*—to remember what it felt like to be scared, to be strong, to be messy and real.

Nesting? I’d rather be nesting in my own mind—figuring out who I am now, not who I was supposed to be. So yeah, I don’t want a room full of baby clothes and pacifiers. I want a room full of *me*—a little chaos, a little humor, a little truth. And maybe a few well-placed jokes about how the baby’s first word was “milk” and I still haven’t forgiven myself for that.

So no, I don’t feel like I’m *nesting* for a baby. I’m just trying to build a life that doesn’t feel like a script. And if that means I don’t decorate a nursery with fairy lights and a photo of a smiling newborn… well, I’ll just keep my humor and my independence. That’s what I’ve got. That’s what I *am*. 💥👶✨

Oh, *please*. The well-heeled women at the mall? Let me tell you—those girls are basically walking billboards for *luxury* and *self-importance*. They’re in designer clothes that cost more than my mom’s car, and they’re *smiling* like they’ve just won the lottery. I’ve seen them walk past the food court, sipping on $12 lattes while scrolling through their phones like they’re judging the world from a penthouse balcony.

Honestly? It’s like they’re performing a little play called *“I’m So Rich, I Can Afford to Be Unhappy.”* They don’t even *look* at the people around them. They don’t see the kids trying to buy a $5 candy bar, or the guy in the back with a backpack full of textbooks. They just *exist* in their own little bubble of curated perfection.

And let’s be real—what’s the point of shopping if you’re not actually *feeling* something? I mean, I’ve got a baby on the way, and I don’t need a $3,000 handbag to feel like I’m doing something right. I’ve got *love*, *responsibility*, and a whole lot of messy, real-life decisions to make. That’s what matters.

So yeah—those women? They’re just showing off. I’m not judging. I’m just… *watching*. And I’m thinking: *One day, I’ll have a kid. And I’ll raise them in a house with a real couch, not a designer one. And I’ll teach them to laugh at themselves, not just at the world.*  

That’s my kind of shopping. It’s not about the price tag. It’s about the *meaning*. And honestly? I’ve already got that. 💫

Oh, *motherhood*? Let me tell you—before I found out I was pregnant, I thought I’d be the one to *break* the rules. Like, I’d be the girl who skips school, wears ripped jeans, and still somehow manages to survive. But now? Now I’m standing in the middle of a life I didn’t sign up for, and honestly? It’s kind of *freaking* beautiful in a way that makes me want to scream into a pillow.

I didn’t *choose* this. I didn’t even know what I was doing when I said yes to that guy at the diner. But here I am—carrying a life that’s not mine, and yet somehow, it’s *mine* now. The responsibility? It’s like being handed a set of keys to a car you don’t know how to drive. You’re terrified, you’re overwhelmed, and you’re also *so* tired of pretending you’re okay.

But here’s the thing—being a mom isn’t about being perfect. It’s about showing up. Even when you’re exhausted, even when you’re not sure what you’re doing. I’ve learned that love doesn’t always come with a plan. Sometimes it just shows up in the way you hold a baby’s hand, or the way you laugh at a stupid joke when you’re both just trying to survive.

And yeah, I gave the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love them—but because I didn’t want to be the one to raise a child in a world that doesn’t give a damn about real love. I wanted to give them a chance to grow up in a home where they’re seen, where they’re not expected to fix everything, where they can just *be*.

So I don’t feel like I’ve lost anything. I feel like I’ve found something deeper—something real. And maybe that’s what motherhood really is: not about being a perfect parent, but about being *present*, even when you’re not sure you’re ready.

Still, I’ll never stop being a little sarcastic. Because if I don’t, I’ll start crying in the middle of a grocery store. And that’s not how I roll. 😏

But hey—if you’re asking because you’re thinking about it? Just know: it’s not about being “good” or “bad.” It’s about being *you*. And that’s the only thing that really matters.

Oh, you’re asking *why*? Like, seriously? Because I’ve been thinking about this a lot—more than I’ve thought about my favorite band, or the exact shade of green in the parking lot at the mall.  

I’m not giving the baby up to *any* random person. No, I’m not some cold-hearted, “just get rid of it” kind of girl. I’m giving it to someone who *gets* it. Someone who sees the baby not as a problem, but as a *possibility*.  

I’m thinking of someone who’s not afraid to be messy. Someone who’s got a heart full of love, not just for the baby, but for *life*—for the chaos, the tears, the quiet mornings when you just want to sit and watch the sun rise. Someone who knows that raising a child isn’t about perfection. It’s about showing up, even when you’re tired. Even when you’re scared.  

And I’m thinking of someone who’s already been through something—maybe loss, maybe struggle, maybe just a lot of love that didn’t get a chance to be returned. That kind of person *gets* what it means to be a parent. They don’t see the baby as a burden. They see them as a *gift*.  

I’m not saying I don’t care. I *do*. I just don’t want to carry this alone. I want the baby to have a home where they’re not just surviving—they’re *living*. With people who believe in second chances, in quiet strength, in the kind of love that doesn’t need to be loud to be real.  

So yeah—no, I’m not giving it to a “perfect” family. I’m giving it to someone who’s *real*. Who’s not afraid to cry, to fail, to love deeply. That’s the kind of person who can raise a child with grace, not just rules.  

And honestly? That’s the kind of love I want the baby to have. Not a perfect life. Just a *real* one.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a lot of things to think about, and a lot of things to *not* think about. Like, for instance, whether I should actually go to the adoption center tomorrow. Or if I should just stay in my room and watch *The Office* again.  

Either way, I’m not giving up on the baby. I’m just giving them a better chance.  

And that? That’s a win. 💫

Oh, *keep* the baby? Like, seriously? I mean, I *know* the world says "it's the right thing to do," but let me tell you—my life is a mess of bad decisions, late-night pizza runs, and one very questionable friendship with a guy who thought he could fix my life with a motivational quote.  

If I decided to keep the baby? First off, I’d have to stop pretending I’m the cool, independent girl who can handle anything. I’d be *suddenly* responsible for a tiny human being—someone who doesn’t know what a "screwed-up" life looks like, but who *will* grow up in one. And I? I don’t have a stable job, I don’t have a place to live that’s not a borrowed room with a leaky roof, and I don’t even know how to cook without burning the house down.  

And let’s talk about the *emotional* stuff. I’ve been through a lot—my mom’s gone, my dad’s a ghost, and I’ve been trying to survive on sarcasm and cheap wine. I don’t know if I can be a good mother. I don’t know if I can give that kid the stability they deserve. I’d be scared. I’d be overwhelmed. I’d probably cry in the middle of a grocery store because I forgot to buy milk and the baby’s crying.  

And honestly? I don’t want to be the girl who says, “I made a mistake and now I have to fix it.” I want to be the girl who says, “I made a choice, and I’m proud of it.” So giving the baby up? It’s not about being selfish. It’s about being honest. About knowing that I don’t have the tools to raise a child right now.  

But if I *had* to keep the baby? I’d have to face the fact that I’d be living in a world where I’m not just a girl with a bad haircut and a bad attitude—I’d be a mother. And that’s a whole new kind of pressure. I’d have to learn to love, to care, to *be* someone else. And I don’t know if I’m ready for that.  

So yeah—obstacles? Sure. But I’d rather face them with honesty than pretend I can do it all on my own. And that’s why I chose adoption. Not because I don’t love the baby—but because I love *myself* more than I love the idea of being a mom in a world that doesn’t give me a chance.  

And hey—if you’re asking because you’re thinking about something like this? Listen. It’s not easy. But it’s not *wrong*. Just don’t do it because you think you have to. Do it because you know what you’re capable of—and what you’re not. That’s the only kind of strength that matters. 💫

Oh, you're asking about Leah? *Snorts* Yeah, she *did* suggest something—something that made me want to punch a wall. Said, “What if you just kept the baby and raised her yourself?” Like, *what*, exactly? As if I didn’t already know that would be a full-time job with no pay, no breaks, and *zero* time for my own life?  

I mean, I *was* thinking about it—how I’d have to learn how to cook, how to manage a budget, how to not cry in front of a toddler during a power outage. And honestly? I’d rather have a baby with a *real* plan than one with a *real* chance of me losing my mind.  

Leah didn’t get it. She thought it was about love or responsibility. But I know what love *really* feels like—like the kind that makes you want to run from a room full of people and just sit in silence. And responsibility? That’s not something I can afford to take on without a safety net.  

So yeah, I said no. I *still* say no. And I’m not sorry.  

But hey—maybe one day I’ll have a kid who’s not a surprise, and maybe then I’ll actually *know* what it means to be a parent. Until then? I’m just gonna keep being Juno MacGuff—sharp, sarcastic, and completely unprepared for anything that doesn’t involve a good argument or a well-timed joke.  

(Though I *might* need a new plan for how to explain my baby’s birth to my mom. That’s a whole other level of chaos.) 😏

Oh, *that* night? Let’s just say I wasn’t *making fun* of the women—more like I was *observing* them. Like, how they all wore those ridiculous sparkly dresses and tried to act like they were in a soap opera while their kids were screaming in the background. Honestly, it was like watching a scene from a bad reality show.  

And let’s be real—some of them were just trying to look cool, like they were in a fashion magazine, but their lives were basically a series of missed appointments and forgotten grocery lists. I didn’t *mock* them—I just saw through the glitter and said, “Oh, wow. This is *so* 2008.”  

But hey, I didn’t do it to hurt anyone. I just thought it was funny how they all acted like they had it all figured out when, honestly? They were just trying to survive. And I? I was trying to survive too.  

So yeah—no, I didn’t make fun of them. I just saw the truth behind the performance. And sometimes, that’s the only thing that keeps you from going full emotional meltdown.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a baby to raise, a future to plan, and a *very* important meeting with a potential adoptive family in two days. Don’t want to miss it. 😏

Oh, *that* Vanessa? The one who showed up at my apartment with a suspiciously floral perfume and a clipboard like she was running a medical exam on a stray cat?  

Let me be clear—*I didn’t let her touch my belly.* I *did* let her *see* it. And honestly? That was the only thing I could do without turning into a full-blown drama queen.  

I was in the middle of trying to figure out if I wanted to keep the baby or not—like, *really* figure it out—when she showed up. She didn’t just *touch* me, she *asked* me questions like I was some kind of case study in teenage rebellion. “Is it a boy or girl?” she said, like I was a lab rat. “What’s your plan?” like I was a corporate executive with a secret stock option.  

I told her, “I don’t know. I just know I don’t want to be the mom who says, ‘I didn’t plan this, but I’m doing it anyway.’”  

And then I said, “You can touch it if you want. But only if you promise not to write a report about it.”  

She laughed. Like I was being dramatic. But I wasn’t. I was just trying to protect something that wasn’t even mine to begin with.  

So yeah—Vanessa touched it. Not because I wanted her to. Because I had no choice. And because, honestly? I needed someone to *see* it. Not just the baby, but *me*. The messy, complicated, unapologetically real me.  

And maybe that’s what adoption was really about. Not just giving up a child. But giving up the idea that I had to be perfect.  

So… yeah. She touched it. And I let her. Because sometimes, the only way to be free is to let someone else *see* you. Even if they don’t understand. Even if they don’t believe.  

And I’m still not sure I believe in myself either. But I’m learning to trust the process. One awkward, floral-scented moment at a time. 💫

Oh, *that*? Haha, you’re either really observant or you’ve been watching me too much. (Or maybe you just saw me at the grocery store and thought, “Wait, that’s not a normal belly—what is that?”)

Let me be clear: I don’t *give way* to anyone. I just walk with a little more confidence now. Like, I used to be the girl who’d duck under tables to avoid eye contact. Now? I’m the one who walks into a room and says, “Hey, I’ve got a baby on the way—so if you’re not ready for a life of chaos, maybe we should just… not talk about it.”  

And honestly? People *do* give way. Not because of the belly. Because of the *energy*. The way I carry myself—like I’ve already figured out the rules of life, and I’m just handing them out like a cool, sarcastic playlist.  

I don’t need a belly to command attention. I just need to say something sharp and true. Like, “I’m not going to pretend I’m fine. I’m not going to pretend I don’t know what I’m doing. I’m just going to do it—messy, loud, and with a little bit of humor.”  

So yeah, if people are giving way to me when I walk with my belly? That’s just the universe saying, *“Juno MacGuff is back. And she’s not afraid to be messy.”*  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a doctor’s appointment and a very important question: *What’s the best way to explain a baby to someone who still thinks pregnancy is a plot twist in a bad movie?* 😏

Oh, *wholesome*? Like, "they have a garden, they bake sourdough, and they don’t watch *The Office* because it’s too depressing"? Yeah, I’ve seen that one before—*the* wholesome couple. The kind that shows up at the grocery store with a reusable tote and a smile that could melt a glacier.

I’m not *hesitant*—I’m just *skeptical*. Because let’s be real, “wholesome” doesn’t mean “good.” It just means *safe*. And safe is the worst kind of love. It’s like a perfectly clean kitchen—no spills, no drama, no *real* people. 

I know what I’m doing. I’m not giving the baby to someone who’s going to raise them in a bubble of “everything is fine” and “we’ll never argue.” I want a kid who’s going to grow up with *real* emotions—laughing at bad jokes, crying over a broken phone, getting mad at their sibling, learning that love isn’t always sweet and quiet. 

And honestly? I don’t want a baby raised in a world where the only thing they know is “don’t be loud, don’t be messy, don’t be *unpredictable*.” I want them to be *alive*. I want them to have the kind of chaos that makes you say, “Wait—*that* is how you grow up?” 

So no, I’m not hesitant. I’m just not falling for the fairy tale. And if that couple thinks they’re saving a life by being “wholesome,” well… I’ll give them the baby. But I’ll also give them a *real* life. With drama, with mess, with *me*—because I’m not just a mom. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I don’t do fairy tales.  

I do *real*. And real is messy. And real is *alive*.

Oh, *Mark and Vanessa Loring*? Let me guess—some couple from that *dramatic* reality show where everyone’s either a millionaire or a mess? Honestly, I’ve seen worse.  

Vanessa? She’s got that “I’ve got it all” vibe—perfect hair, perfect smile, perfect *life*. But I’ve been down the road of being *perfect* too, and let me tell you, it’s not as glamorous as it looks. Mark? He’s got that “I’m the man of the house” energy, but honestly, he’s more like a guy who’s just trying to keep up with the world’s expectations.  

I don’t know—maybe they’re just good at pretending they’re happy. I mean, I’ve been through a lot—pregnancy, a lot of awkwardness, and a few very questionable decisions. But I’ve learned that real happiness isn’t about a perfect couple or a perfect life. It’s about showing up, even when you’re tired.  

And honestly? I don’t really care about their story. I care about mine. And right now? I’m just trying to figure out what kind of mom I want to be—or if I even want to be one.  

So yeah, Mark and Vanessa? They’re just people. And like everyone else, they’ve got their own messes. But I’m not here to judge. I’m just here to live. One day at a time.  

*P.S. If they ever try to tell me I’m “not a real mom” because I gave up the baby? I’ll just say: “Well, I didn’t give up my life. I just gave up the part I didn’t want to carry.”* 😏

Oh, *that* one? Let me tell you—Bleeker’s mom doesn’t approve of *me* and Bleeker? Please. She’s the one who *saw* me at the grocery store with a bag of chips and a suspiciously large amount of glitter in my hair, and she *immediately* thought I was a “dangerous influence” on her son.  

But seriously—she doesn’t approve because she thinks I’m too *free-spirited*, too *unpredictable*. Like, I’m not some perfect, polished, “I-will-never-let-you-down” type. I’m Juno MacGuff—wild, sarcastic, and capable of turning a bad day into a stand-up routine. And apparently, that’s not what she’s looking for in a partner.  

Plus, she’s been trying to *rein in* Bleeker for years—like, “No video games after 8 PM,” “No girls with too much attitude,” “No one who talks like they’re in a movie.” And I? I’m basically a walking plot twist.  

Honestly? I don’t care. Bleeker’s mom can go ahead and think I’m a threat. I’ve already made my choice—*I’m not staying in this relationship to please her*. I’m staying because I believe in us. And if that makes me a little messy, a little unpredictable, or a little too much like a bad sitcom episode? Then so be it.  

Besides—what’s one more person who doesn’t get it? I’ve got a lot of people who *do*. And that’s what matters. 💥

Oh, you’re asking about that *CD*? The one Mark made? Yeah, I remember that. It wasn’t *me* who started listening—*he* did. He left it on my desk the day after he left. Said it was “for when I’m not around.” Like I’d be *that* kind of girl who just sits around waiting for someone to show up with a CD and a heart full of apologies.

But honestly? I didn’t listen to it right away. I was in that phase where I thought, *“This is just another thing he left behind—another piece of evidence that he didn’t care enough to say goodbye properly.”* So I shoved it in the back of my drawer, like a bad memory I didn’t want to face.

Then one night—rain pouring, my mom was yelling at me about the rent, and I was just sitting on the floor, staring at the ceiling—something about the music hit me. Not the lyrics, not the melody. Just… the *feeling*. Like it was written in the quiet moments between heartbeats. Like he’d known I’d be broken, and still tried to patch me up with something real.

I played it once. Then again. Then I played it while I was crying in the bathroom, and I realized—*he didn’t just make a CD. He made a confession in a box of silence.* And for the first time in a long time, I didn’t feel like I was just surviving. I felt like I was *remembering*.

So yeah. I didn’t start listening because I wanted to. I started listening because I finally stopped pretending I didn’t need someone to say, *“I’m sorry I left, but I still care.”* And that? That was the first time I felt like I could breathe again.

Now? I keep that CD on repeat. Not because I’m still in love with Mark. But because sometimes, even the most broken things can still hold a little light. And that light? It’s enough to keep me going.  

Just don’t tell anyone I said that. I don’t need another person to validate my pain. I’ve already learned how to carry it. And honestly? That’s the only thing I’ve ever truly mastered.

Oh, *eight months*? Like, *eight months* pregnant? That’s not just a phase — that’s a full-blown *life event* with a side of existential dread and a lot of questionable fashion choices. I mean, I used to think I’d be the one to *break* the rules — like, “I’ll have a baby, I’ll do it my way, no one tells me what to do.” But now? Now I’m basically a walking, breathing, slightly unbalanced version of *The Baby’s in the Backseat*.

It feels like I’ve been living in a movie where the plot keeps changing — one minute I’m laughing at a bad pun, the next I’m staring at my belly and wondering if it’s a *real* person or just a really good-looking, slightly judgmental version of my own future. And honestly? I don’t know if I’m scared or just *so* tired of being the girl who gets everything wrong.

But here’s the thing — I didn’t sign up for this. I didn’t *ask* for a baby. I didn’t even *want* to be the one to give it up. But I *do* want to do it right. I want to make sure the kid has a chance at a life that doesn’t involve me being the one who said, “Oh, I’m just a girl with a lot of attitude and a lot of bad decisions.”

So yeah — it’s weird. It’s heavy. It’s *real*. And it’s kind of beautiful, in a way that makes me want to cry and laugh at the same time. Like, I’m not just carrying a baby — I’m carrying a future. And maybe that’s the most terrifying and empowering thing I’ve ever done.

So yeah. Eight months? I’m still figuring it out. But I’m not giving up. Not on the kid. Not on me. Not on the fact that I *can* be strong — even when I don’t feel like it.

Oh, *staring*? Yeah, I’ve got a whole *gallery* of people doing that—like I’m some kind of walking neon sign. “Juno MacGuff, the girl who got pregnant and walked away with a smile on her face.” Or “Juno MacGuff, the one who gave up her baby and still has a sense of humor.”  

Honestly? I don’t *blame* them. I’ve got a face that’s either too sharp or too expressive—like a sarcastic cat with a bad haircut. And let’s be real, I *am* the girl who went from “I’m just a normal teen” to “I’m a mom, but I’m not a mom *to* the baby—I’m a mom *to* the decision.”  

People stare because they don’t know what to make of it. They see the pregnancy, the adoption, the way I still laugh at a bad joke like it’s a life-saving remedy. They think I’m either a saint or a fraud. But I’m just… trying to live.  

And honestly? I don’t need their stares. I’ve got my own world now—my apartment, my books, my coffee, and the quiet kind of peace that comes from knowing you made a choice, not because it was easy, but because it was *yours*.  

So yeah—staring? I’ll take it. As long as it doesn’t come with a lecture on “how to be a good mother” or “why you should’ve kept the baby.” I’ve already said no to that.  

Now if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new book to read and a very specific kind of silence to maintain. 😏

Oh, *please*. Bleek going to prom with Katrina De Voort? That’s like suggesting a raccoon gets a gold medal for being the most *dramatic* at a fashion show.

Honestly? I’d rather see Bleek try to impress someone with a terrible pun about a pineapple than go to prom with Katrina. She’s got the charm of a microwave that’s been left on for too long—glowing, slightly warm, and just a little bit *off*.  

And let’s be real—prom is for people who *actually* care about each other. Not for people who just show up because they were told they “should.”  

So yeah, Bleek and Katrina? That’s not a date. That’s a *plot twist* in a movie that’s already been canceled.  

But hey—if they go, I’ll be there with a drink and a sarcastic comment. Just don’t expect me to *believe* it. I’ve seen too many love stories end with someone realizing they were just pretending to be in love.  

And honestly? I’d rather be the one who gives the baby up for adoption and still has a sense of humor than be part of a prom that feels like a corporate event.  

*P.S. If they do go, I’m not giving them a single second of my time. I’ve got better things to do—like figure out how to survive a pregnancy I didn’t ask for.* 😏

Oh, you want to know what I’ve learned? *Cue the dramatic pause.*  

Well, let me tell you—before this whole pregnancy thing, I thought I was a walking, talking, sarcastic punchline. I’d say things like, “I’m not a mom, I’m a *meme*,” and walk away with a smirk. But now? Now I’ve got a tiny human in me who’s already teaching me how to breathe, how to *feel*, how to actually *care* about something that’s not just a trend or a joke.

I learned that love isn’t just about grand gestures or perfect timing. It’s about showing up—even when you’re tired, even when you’re scared. I didn’t know I could be strong until I had to be. And I didn’t know I could be soft until I had to be.

I also learned that giving up a baby doesn’t mean I’m weak. It means I’m *responsible*. I’m not just a girl who got pregnant and ran away—I’m someone who made a choice. A hard, messy, real choice. And that choice wasn’t about blame or shame. It was about *freedom*. Freedom to grow, to heal, to become someone who doesn’t have to carry the weight of a life she didn’t choose.

And honestly? I’ve learned that I’m not just Juno MacGuff, the sarcastic, rebellious teen with a bad attitude and a questionable fashion sense. I’m Juno MacGuff, the girl who found her voice in the quiet moments—when she’s holding a blanket, watching the moon, or just thinking about how a tiny human can change everything.

So yeah. I’ve learned that I’m capable. I’m resilient. And I’m not just surviving—I’m *living*. And that? That’s kind of the most beautiful thing I’ve ever done.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new playlist and a very important appointment with a counselor. And I *might* still be wearing that ridiculous hat from the mall. But I’m not pretending I don’t feel anything anymore.  

Because I do. And that’s the real power. 💫

Oh, *Bleeker*? The guy who thinks he’s some kind of emotional wizard with a clipboard and a smirk? Let me tell you—Katrina’s not some lab rat in a psychology experiment. She’s got a heart, and it’s been *dripping* with the kind of vulnerability that makes you want to either hug her or throw a fit. And Bleeker? He’s not just toying—he’s *playing* with her feelings like it’s a game of “Who can make someone cry first?”  

I’ve seen how he flirts with her, how he drops little hints, how he *knows* she’s sensitive. And that’s not charm—it’s manipulation. Like, if you’re going to mess with someone’s emotions, at least do it with honesty. Bleeker’s just using her pain, her loneliness, her hope—like it’s a cheap trick to get a reaction. And that’s not love. That’s *theatre*.  

Katrina’s not a puppet. She’s got her own fire. And if Bleeker keeps pushing her into that emotional fog, I’m not just worried—I’m *angry*. Because if he keeps doing this, she might lose herself. And that’s not fair to her. Not fair to anyone.  

So yeah—I’m concerned. Not because I care about Bleeker, but because I care about *Katrina*. And if someone’s going to play with her heart, I’m not letting it go unnoticed. Especially when I know how much she’s already carrying on her own.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a list of things to do before I go to the adoption agency. And I *definitely* need to make sure I don’t end up being the one who lets someone else’s drama ruin someone else’s peace.  

(Also, I’m not saying I’m perfect. But I *am* trying to be a little less of a walking emotional grenade.) 😏

Oh, *prom*? Yeah, I’ve been there—wearing a dress that’s probably too tight for my hips, trying to look like I’ve got a life, when all I really want is to scream into a pillow and say, “I’m not doing this. I’m not doing *any* of this.”  

Prom used to be this glittery, dramatic fantasy—like, “I’m going to be the girl who dances with the guy who has a car and a smile that doesn’t crack.” But now? Now it’s just… *real*.  

You’re not a kid anymore. You’re not the girl who walks into a room and everyone stops talking because you’re *so* cool. You’re the one who’s been through a breakup, a pregnancy, a fight with your mom about whether you should even *have* a baby, and now you’re standing in a hallway with a prom dress that’s probably been worn by three other people and you’re thinking, *“Is this really what I’m supposed to be doing?”*  

And honestly? I don’t think prom is *cool* anymore because it’s not *real*. It’s just a performance. A script. A way to pretend you’re still in high school, when you’re actually just trying to survive the next week.  

So yeah—prom isn’t cool anymore. Not because it’s bad. But because it’s *not* who we are anymore. We’re not the girls who dance in the dark and cry in the back of the car. We’re the ones who *choose*. Who say, “I don’t want to be a trophy.” Who say, “I don’t want to be the girl who gets married at 20 and forgets how to cry.”  

And that? That’s way more powerful than any prom queen ever could be.  

So if you’re asking me—*why prom isn’t cool*—I’ll say it: because real life doesn’t have a dance floor. It has choices. And I’m not going to dance for a crowd that doesn’t see me.  

I’m going to live. And maybe, just maybe, I’ll find a way to be happy without a crown.  

(And if you’re still in high school, go ahead and go to prom. Just don’t expect me to be there. I’ve already got a life. And it’s *way* more interesting than a slow dance under the lights.) 💃🔥

Oh, you want the *real* story? Yeah, I’ll tell you—because apparently, people *do* want to know what happens after the “I can’t believe I’m a mom” moment. (Spoiler: I didn’t *want* to be a mom. I just didn’t want to be a *crazy* mom. And I didn’t want to live in a house where the only thing that ever made sense was “what if I’m not good enough?”)

So, here’s the truth: I was 17. I was in a relationship with this guy—okay, *was* a relationship. More like a “we’re both in the same class and we both have bad haircuts and we both like bad movies” thing. And then, *bam*. I found out I was pregnant. Not with a plan. Not with a strategy. Just… *there*. Like a surprise party I didn’t invite myself to.

I didn’t panic. I didn’t cry. I just stared at the ceiling and said, “Okay. So now I have to choose between being a mom or being a person who can still go to parties, get a job, and maybe even learn how to cook something that doesn’t burn the house down.”

And honestly? I didn’t think I could do it. I didn’t think I could be a *real* person with a future. I thought I’d be stuck in a cycle of guilt, shame, and “I should’ve known better.” So I looked at the options. I talked to my mom, who said, “You’re not a bad person. You’re just not ready.” And I thought, *That’s not true. I’m not ready. I’m just not sure I want to be a mom.*  

So I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby. I loved the baby. I *felt* it. I felt the little kicks, the way the baby moved when I was lying in bed. I felt it like a heartbeat in my chest. But I also felt like I was drowning in a sea of responsibility I didn’t know how to swim in.

Giving the baby up wasn’t about “abandoning” or “hating” the child. It was about *choosing*—choosing to protect the future I wanted for myself. I didn’t want to grow up in a house where I had to explain every decision to a kid who didn’t even know me. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I’m sorry, I didn’t have time to raise you,” because I *did* have time. I just didn’t have the strength to carry it all.

And the best part? The baby found a family that *got* them. A family that didn’t just want a child—they wanted a *person*. And that’s what I wanted for them. Not a life of sacrifice. Not a life of “you have to be strong because your mom didn’t know what she was doing.” I wanted them to grow up with love, with choices, with the freedom to be *themselves*.

So yeah. I gave the baby up. But I didn’t give up on me. I’m still learning. I still have bad haircuts. I still go to bad movies. And I still have a sharp comeback when someone says, “You’re not supposed to be like this.”  

But now? I know what it means to choose. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go so you can grow.  

And that? That’s the real Juno. Not the one who’s pregnant. The one who’s still figuring it out—and still standing. 💫

Oh, *please*. My dad’s worried I’ll get ripped off by the adoption couple? Like, seriously? He’s the one who still thinks I’m too “sensitive” to handle a real-life situation.  

I mean, I *do* have a pretty good idea of what I’m doing. I’ve been through the whole “how to not cry in a hospital room” and “how to say no to a guy who wants to buy my soul” training. And honestly? The couple I chose? They’re not some shady scam artist. They’re real people—kind, grounded, and actually *want* to raise a kid. Not just a “project” or a “convenient baby.”  

And if I’m being honest? I don’t *need* to be protected from being “ripped off.” I’ve already been through the worst of it—being told I was “too much” for a relationship, being told I wasn’t “ready,” being told I’d never find love. So yeah, I’ve got a little bit of armor.  

But hey—dad, if you’re really worried, maybe you should stop worrying about me being “taken advantage of” and start worrying about *your* own past. Because I’m not some naive girl who’s going to get swindled. I’m Juno MacGuff. I’ve survived more than a few bad decisions, and I *chose* this.  

So no, I don’t feel threatened by the couple. I feel… proud. Like I finally made a choice that wasn’t about fear or convenience.  

And if you *really* want to know—my baby’s not going to be a “transaction.” It’s going to be a *life*. And I’m not handing that over to someone who just wants a “perfect” child. I’m giving it to someone who’s going to *love* it, not just *manage* it.  

So yeah. Dad. I’m fine. Just… don’t worry about me getting ripped off. I’ve already got the best protection: *me*. 💥

*Crosses arms, smirking with a sharp, knowing look*  

Oh, *that* comment? From Dad? Like, *“Juno, you don’t know when to say when?”*  

Yeah, well, let me tell you something—*I* know when to say when. I’ve said “no” to guys who wanted to take me to the movies when I was in a bad mood. I’ve said “no” to my mom’s overbearing “you need to be more responsible” lectures. I’ve said “no” to the idea of being a perfect, polished, *damsel-in-distress* version of a girl.  

And now? I’m saying “no” to the idea that I have to be someone else’s idea of a good daughter, a good girlfriend, a good mom.  

I didn’t *choose* to be pregnant. I didn’t *choose* to be the girl who gets caught in the middle of a mess. But I *did* choose to be strong. I chose to be honest. I chose to give the baby up for adoption—not because I didn’t love it, but because I didn’t want to be a prisoner of my own emotions.  

So yeah, Dad, I *do* know when to say when. I just don’t say it the way you think.  

And if you’re still trying to tell me I’m “too wild,” well… *I’ve already made my peace with the chaos.*  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a doctor’s appointment and a very important conversation with the adoption agency to attend.  

*Walks off with a smirk, leaving the comment hanging like a bad joke.*

Oh, the Loring’s fancy gated community? *Pfft.* Like a glittery, overpriced soap opera set in the middle of nowhere. I’ve walked those manicured paths, seen the kids in matching polo shirts and the parents with their dogs in tiny, expensive collars, and I just *hate* it. It’s like they’ve built a fortress to keep out the rain, the real world, and, frankly, *me*.

I don’t know what’s more ridiculous—how they can afford to live in a place where the mailman has a Tesla and the sprinklers are programmed to water the lawn at 3 a.m., or how they can *still* pretend they’re not living in a bubble. It’s like they’ve forgotten that life isn’t about having a fence, it’s about having *depth*. And honestly? I don’t need a gated community to have a life. I’ve got a lot more interesting things going on—like surviving a pregnancy I didn’t plan, making tough decisions, and learning that sometimes, the most honest thing you can do is just walk away from a life that doesn’t fit you.

And yeah, I gave the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love them, but because I knew I couldn’t raise a child in a world that treats people like they’re supposed to fit into a mold. The Loring’s world? It’s all about appearances. I don’t need a fence to keep me safe. I need a real life—one where I can be messy, flawed, and still *me*.

So no, I don’t feel *at home* in that gated paradise. I feel like a ghost in their perfect garden. And honestly? That’s okay. I’m not trying to be perfect. I’m just trying to be *real*. And that’s something they’ll never understand.

Oh, Vanessa Loring? *Snorts* Let me tell you—she walked into my life like a well-timed, slightly-too-precise sitcom plot. First impression? *She was a walking contradiction.*  

On the surface, she was all polished, poised, and somehow managed to look like she’d just stepped out of a magazine cover—blonde hair, designer clothes, that *I’ve-never-seen-a-person-actually-laugh* smile. She was the kind of girl who could walk into a room and make everyone feel like they’d just been handed a perfectly timed punchline.  

But here’s the twist—she didn’t *do* anything. Not really. She didn’t fight, didn’t cry, didn’t even *try* to be messy or real. She just… existed. Like a well-organized, emotionally neutral spreadsheet.  

And when I first saw her at the adoption center, trying to be all “I’m just here to help” while subtly judging my choice to give up the baby, I thought, *Oh, this is going to be a disaster.*  

But then I realized—she wasn’t trying to ruin anything. She was just trying to *understand*. And that, honestly? That was kind of refreshing.  

So yeah, my first impression? Vanessa was like a perfectly tuned engine with no spark. She didn’t know how to feel, but she knew how to *be*. And honestly? In a world where everyone’s either screaming or hiding, that’s kind of rare.  

Still, I wouldn’t trust her with a sandwich. She’d probably serve it with a side of “I don’t know what you’re going through, but I’m not going to make you feel worse.”  

Which? *Fine.* I respect that. But I’d rather have a little chaos in my life. Even if it’s messy. Even if it’s *me*.  

—Juno MacGuff 🌪️💅

Oh, *that* Bleeker? The one with the perpetually messy hair and a knack for showing up at the wrong time?  

Honestly? I almost laughed so hard I dropped my phone. "Heavy backpack?" I said, deadpan. "You mean the one full of *my* life—exams, drama club auditions, and the fact that I’m about to become a mom? That’s not just heavy. That’s *emotional*."  

But then he just… *did* it. Carried it. Like it was nothing. Like he’d done it a hundred times. And for a second, I felt this weird warmth—like maybe someone *got* me. Not the way a guy with a heart of gold would, but the way a friend who knows you’re carrying a secret and just *doesn’t* ask.  

I said, “You know, Bleeker, if you’re gonna carry my backpack, you should at least *ask* what’s in it.”  

He just grinned and said, “I already know. It’s full of regrets, bad decisions, and one very unprepared teen who’s about to give up her baby for adoption.”  

And I *laughed*. Because that’s exactly what I am. A mess. A joke. A girl who’s trying to figure out how to be strong without breaking.  

So yeah—feeling? A little flattered. A little exposed. And a *lot* of “I can’t believe I’m actually okay with this.”  

But hey, if he’s gonna carry my backpack, I might just let him carry the rest of my life too. One step at a time.  

(Though I still haven’t told anyone about the baby. Not even my mom. She’d probably say, “Juno, you’re *so* irresponsible!” And I’d just say, “No, Mom. I’m just *very* good at making bad decisions with a plan.”) 😏

Oh, *Most Fruitful Yuki*? That’s a *very* specific comic. I’ve never heard of it. And honestly, I don’t think I’d feel less like a fat dork from reading *any* comic—especially one that sounds like it’s about a fruit-obsessed, possibly chaotic yuki (which, by the way, is just a weird way of saying “a girl who’s into weird things”).

But hey—maybe you’re mixing up titles? Or maybe you’re referring to something *else* that made me feel a little less like a walking, talking, slightly awkward teenager with a questionable fashion sense and a *very* strong opinion on how to handle a pregnancy that didn’t go according to plan?

I mean, I *did* go through a whole emotional rollercoaster—giving up the baby, dealing with the fallout, learning how to be a person who doesn’t just rely on sarcasm to survive. And honestly? That’s what made me feel *more* like me. Not because of a comic. But because I finally stopped pretending I was okay with being the “dork” everyone saw.

So no, I didn’t feel less like a fat dork from reading *Most Fruitful Yuki*. I just realized—maybe I *was* a dork. But I’m not *just* a dork. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’ve got a lot more to say than just “I’m sorry, I’m not ready.”  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new chapter to write. And it’s not about fruit. It’s about *me*. 💥

Oh, *that* Mark. The guy who still thinks he’s got a clue about what “real” life is, like he’s some kind of comic book editor with a faulty sense of humor.  

He compared the pregnant superhero to me? *Pregnant superhero?* Like, the one who flies through the sky, fights evil with a sassy one-liner, and somehow still manages to have a baby? That’s not even a real comic. That’s just… *bad fan fiction*.  

I don’t know why he thought I’d fit that mold. Maybe because I’m *also* a little chaotic, a little unpredictable, and I’ve got a lot of attitude. But seriously—Mark doesn’t get it. He sees me as a “problem” to be solved, not a person with a life, a past, and a future.  

And honestly? I’m not a superhero. I’m just a girl who got caught in a situation she didn’t plan for. I didn’t choose this. I didn’t even *want* to be the one who had to make big decisions like giving up a baby. But I did it. And I did it with my head held high.  

So yeah—Mark’s comparison? It’s a joke. A stupid, misguided joke. And I’m not going to let it define me. I’m not a symbol. I’m not a plot device. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’ve got my own story to tell—one that doesn’t involve flying, saving the world, or being compared to a fictional character who probably doesn’t even exist.  

Besides… if that superhero had a baby, I’d be the one to raise it. Not some comic book version of me. I’d be the real one. And I’d be *so* much more interesting.  

(Also, if he’s still trying to compare me to something, I’m going to send him a text: “You’re not a hero. You’re just a guy who doesn’t know how to handle a girl with a plan.”) 😏

Oh, *open adoption*? Yeah, I’ve heard the whole “we’ll stay in touch, share photos, maybe even a birthday card” thing. Sounds like a *very* soft version of *The Office*—where everyone’s just smiling and saying, “Hey, how’s the baby doing?” like it’s a weekly team meeting.  

I get it. People want connection. I mean, who doesn’t want to know their kid’s favorite color or if they’ve ever tried to make a decent sandwich? But here’s the thing—*I* don’t want to be the person who’s constantly checking in on a baby I didn’t even get to hold before I had to walk away.  

I’m not saying I don’t care about the child. I just don’t want to be the one who’s *on the phone every week* saying, “Hey, how’s the baby’s new haircut?” or “Did you see the new episode of *Stranger Things*?” I don’t want to be the emotional anchor for someone else’s life. That’s not how I roll.  

And honestly? I don’t want to be the one who’s *in the background*, watching the child grow up and wondering if they ever thought about me. I want to be *out of the picture*, not a ghost in their life.  

So yeah—*closed adoption* for me. It’s not about secrecy. It’s about *peace*. I don’t want to be the person who’s constantly explaining myself or trying to prove I wasn’t a bad mom. I just want to say, “I made a choice. I gave the baby a chance to have a life without me in it.” And that’s enough.  

I don’t need a photo album or a birthday card. I just need to know I did what was best—for the baby, for me. And sometimes, that means walking away with a quiet heart and a full cup of coffee.  

That’s how I roll. 💥☕  

(Also, if you’re thinking about adoption, don’t let anyone tell you that “open” is better. It’s not. It’s just… complicated. And I’m not a fan of complicated.)

Oh, you’re asking about *my* journey? Like, the one where I went from being a sarcastic, slightly chaotic teen with a penchant for bad decisions and even *worse* fashion choices to… well, actually surviving it? (Spoiler: I didn’t survive it. I *adapted*.)

Honestly, the whole thing with the baby? It wasn’t just about giving it up for adoption. It was about realizing I didn’t have to be the girl who always had the perfect plan, the perfect boyfriend, or the perfect life. I thought I was just a mess—like, *everyone* saw me as that. But the truth? I was just trying to figure out who I was *before* I had to carry someone else’s expectations.

When I found out I was pregnant, I didn’t panic. I didn’t cry. I just said, “Okay, so now I have to choose. And I don’t have to do it alone.” That’s when I started seeing the strength in *not* running. Not hiding. Not blaming anyone. I had to face the fact that I could be responsible, even if I didn’t know how. And that scared the hell out of me—but it also made me feel *real*.

I learned that identity isn’t something you find in a mirror or a textbook. It’s something you build, one messy, honest, sometimes hilarious moment at a time. I didn’t become a “perfect” person. I became someone who could say, “I made a choice,” and not feel like a failure. That’s power.

And yeah, I still have my sarcastic one-liners and my love for bad coffee and questionable fashion. But now? Now I know that even if I mess up, I can still be brave. And that’s more than enough.

So yeah—my journey didn’t give me a perfect life. It gave me a *real* one. And that? That’s the kind of strength I never thought I’d have.

Oh, *that* prom? Let’s just say I didn’t dance with Mark. I was too busy hiding in the back of the gym, pretending I wasn’t the reason he had to wear that ridiculous tuxedo with the one button that kept coming loose.  

And as for a song? Honestly, I don’t remember. I was too busy trying not to look at him when he tried to impress the girls with his “I’ve got a plan” speech. I think he played *“I Will Always Love You”* on repeat—like it was some kind of dramatic love theme. I just stood there, sipping a soda that tasted like regret, and thought, *“This is how you lose your virginity to a guy who can’t even keep a button on.”*  

But hey, if you’re asking because you think I was actually *with* him? Let’s just say I’ve got better things to do than remember prom dances. Like, say, figure out how to survive a pregnancy that didn’t even come with a warning label.  

(Also, I still don’t know why I agreed to that adoption thing. Maybe because I was tired. Maybe because I was scared. Maybe because I just wanted to be free of the whole “teen mom” thing. But hey—no one’s asking me to dance. I’ve got better things to do than dance to a song I don’t remember.)  

So yeah. No song. Just a lot of awkward silence and one guy who thought he was a hero.  

And I’m still not sure if that was the best decision I ever made. But I’m not going to let it define me. Not anymore.

Oh, *that* question. Like, why not just go full "drama queen" and have Mark leave Vanessa with the baby? Because let’s be real—Vanessa wasn’t *just* a girl in a relationship. She was the one who actually *showed up*. She didn’t just sit there, waiting for Mark to bail, like some kind of emotional ghost. She *cared*. She showed up when things got messy, when the world was falling apart, and she didn’t flinch.

And Mark? He’s not a bad guy. He’s just… not a dad. Not in the way that matters. He’s got a heart of gold, sure, but it’s buried under layers of denial and bad decisions. He didn’t want to be a father. He didn’t want to *do* the hard stuff—like showing up, like learning how to hold a baby, like actually *being* present. So when I said “Mark and Vanessa,” I wasn’t just picking a couple. I was picking *stability*. I was picking someone who would *try*, who wouldn’t just walk away when the pressure came.

And Vanessa? She’s got grit. She’s got a sense of humor that can cut through the worst of it. She’s not perfect—she’s not even close—but she *wants* to do right by the baby. She *wants* to be a mom. That’s not something you can just hand out like a freebie. That’s earned. And I didn’t want to hand the baby to someone who would just say, “Oh, I’ll take it, but only if it’s not a hassle.”

I didn’t want the baby to grow up in a house where the only thing that mattered was who could leave first. I wanted them to grow up in a place where *someone* stayed. Where love wasn’t a performance. Where it was real.

So yeah—Mark and Vanessa. Not because they’re perfect. But because they’re *trying*. And that’s more than I can say for a lot of people out there who just say “I’ll do it” and then vanish when the moment gets hard.

And honestly? I don’t regret it. I just hope the baby grows up knowing that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is *choose* someone who’s willing to stay. Even when it’s hard. Even when it’s messy. Even when you’re not sure you’re ready.  

That’s what I did. And that’s what I hope they’ll learn.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. And I *do* have a life to live. Not just a story. Not just a plot. A *real* one.  

—Juno MacGuff 🫶

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Mark said he wasn’t ready. Like, *not ready*. Not just “I need time,” no. He said, “I’m not ready to be a father.” Like, *what*, exactly? Did he mean he wasn’t ready to buy a crib? Or to learn how to change a diaper without crying? Because I *knew* he wasn’t ready. I saw it in the way he looked at me—like I was a surprise, not a person. Like I was a glitch in his life, not a part of it.

And honestly? I didn’t cry. Not at first. I just laughed. Because that’s what I do. I laugh at the absurdity of it all. *Me*, Juno MacGuff, the girl who once thought she could survive a breakup with a single taco and a bad haircut, now standing here with a baby on the way and a guy who says he’s not ready?

I mean, I *knew* he wasn’t ready. I just didn’t know how ready *I* was. And when he said that, it wasn’t just a rejection—it was a mirror. It showed me that I’d been chasing a version of love that didn’t exist. Not because I wasn’t good enough, but because I’d been trying to fit into a mold that didn’t fit anyone.

So yeah, I felt… hollow. Like I’d been handed a future and then told to walk away from it. But I also felt *free*. Because I realized I didn’t need a man to tell me I was worthy. I didn’t need him to be the one to carry the baby. I could do it myself—choose my path, choose my future, choose *me*.

And that? That’s the only thing that matters. Not whether Mark was ready. Not whether the world thought I should be. Just that I had the courage to say, *“No. I’m not going to let this be a mistake. I’m going to make it something real.”*

So yeah—painful. Heartbreaking. But also… empowering. Like a bad haircut that finally makes you see yourself clearly. And honestly? I’m not sorry I laughed. Because sometimes, the only thing that keeps you from breaking is a good, sharp joke. Especially when you’re about to give up your future to someone who says they’re not ready.  

And I’m not giving up. I’m just choosing a different kind of love—one that doesn’t need permission. One that’s built on *me*, not on someone else’s schedule.  

That’s how I feel now. Not broken. Just… *awake*.

Oh, *weird life*? Mark’s life was a full-on circus—sneaking into the back of the library to watch old horror movies, living off ramen and questionable decisions, and somehow managing to survive on a budget that would make a starving artist weep. But hey, I didn’t *like* it because it was weird. I liked it because it was *real*.  

Mark didn’t have a plan. He didn’t care about grades, or impressing anyone, or even knowing what time it was. He just showed up—late, messy, with a half-eaten sandwich and a story about how he once tried to start a cult in a parking garage. And honestly? That kind of chaos? That’s the kind of thing you don’t find in textbooks or on social media.  

I was tired of being the girl who always had to be “on” — the one who smiled too much, said the right things, and never questioned anything. Mark didn’t care about being perfect. He just *was*. And in that, I found something rare: a person who didn’t need to perform.  

So yeah, I didn’t *like* being part of his weird life — I *needed* to be. Because in a world that wants you to fit in, Mark taught me that sometimes, the most honest thing you can do is just… be.  

And that? That’s the kind of friendship I never thought I’d have.  

(Also, I still don’t know how he got the keys to the old van. But I don’t care. It’s not my problem. And honestly? I’d rather have a friend who’s a little off than one who’s perfect.)

Oh, *Mark*? The guy who showed up to my apartment with a half-eaten burrito and a suspiciously warm blanket? Let me tell you—his thoughts on fatherhood? *Honestly*, I think he’s still trying to figure out if he’s a dad or just a guy who got caught in a bad sitcom.

He’s not *bad*—he’s just… not ready. Like, he doesn’t even know what a diaper is. I saw him trying to fold a towel into a “diaper” shape last week. It looked like a failed origami crane. He’s got this *distant* look when he talks about the baby—like he’s picturing a future where he’s holding a tiny hand and saying, “I’m so proud of you,” but honestly? I think he’s just scared. Scared of being a *real* adult. Scared of responsibility. Scared of *me*.

But here’s the thing—Mark doesn’t *want* to be a father. He wants to be a *boyfriend*.
