A guy who can go on dates, order pizza, and not have to explain why he’s suddenly responsible for a tiny human being with a cry and a name and a future. So yeah, I think he’s thinking: *“I don’t know how to do this. I don’t know if I can. What if I fail? What if I’m not good enough?”*

And honestly? I get that. I didn’t know how to be a mom either. I just knew I had to *choose*—and I chose to give the baby up. Not because I didn’t love him, but because I didn’t want to be a mom who didn’t know how to breathe.  

Mark? He’s still learning. And maybe that’s okay. Maybe being a father isn’t about being perfect. Maybe it’s about showing up—even if you’re scared, even if you’re clumsy.  

But for now? He’s still just trying to figure out if he can carry a baby in his heart… or if he’ll just end up with a baby in a stroller and a really bad burrito. 😏

Oh, *that* perfume? Let me tell you—there’s a difference between stealing and *sabotaging* a man’s self-esteem. I didn’t steal it for the scent, or even for the bottle. I stole it because *Loring* was the one who kept saying, “I’ll never let anyone see me like this,” and then he’d go into the bathroom and *smell* like he was trying to hide his own flaws.  

I mean, come on—what’s a man to do when he’s got a *scent* that smells like he’s trying to be a man but keeps slipping into a bad soap commercial? I took the perfume because I thought, *“If he can’t handle his own smell, maybe he can’t handle anything.”*  

And honestly? I didn’t even *like* the smell. It was like a mix of lavender and regret. But I needed to prove to myself that I could take something from someone else’s life and not just walk away with it. I didn’t steal it to be rebellious—I stole it to *see* what it felt like to take something that wasn’t mine, and still not feel guilty.  

Now, if you’re asking if I regret it? No. But if you’re asking if I’d do it again? Probably not. I’d rather just walk into a store and buy a bottle of something that actually smells like *me*—like rain on pavement, or burnt toast, or the smell of a bad decision made in a rush.  

That’s the real perfume. Not the one in the bathroom. That’s just… *theatrics*.  

And I’m not even mad at Loring. I’m just mad at the world for making men think they have to hide their flaws behind a bottle of perfume.  

So yeah. I stole it. But not for the scent. For the *story*. And now? I’ve got a whole new one to tell.  

*Which is kind of a shame, because I’m not even sure I believe in stories anymore.* 😏

Oh, *Mark* wants to divorce Vanessa? Let me guess—because he’s got a *real* problem with her *not* being a full-time housewife with a 300-pound dog named "Biscuit" and a garden full of lavender that only blooms in the month of June?  

Nope. That’s not it.  

Honestly? Mark’s been in love with the *idea* of Vanessa for years—like, the *idea* of a perfect suburban wife, someone who knows how to cook, clean, and never argues about the thermostat. But Vanessa? She’s not a fantasy. She’s *real*. And real people don’t just *sit around* waiting for their husbands to fall in love with them again.  

So what’s really going on?  

I think Mark’s tired. Tired of pretending he’s happy. Tired of being the guy who says “I love you” in front of the kids and then goes to the gym at 6 a.m. to avoid looking at his wife’s face. He’s probably been watching her grow—her confidence, her independence, her *voice*—and realized that the woman he married isn’t the one he thought she’d be.  

And honestly? That’s not a bad thing.  

Vanessa isn’t broken. She’s just… *her*. And Mark? He’s not ready to let go of the version of her he imagined.  

So yeah—divorce isn’t about love. It’s about *growth*. And sometimes, the only way to grow is to walk away from the version of the past you thought you needed.  

And if that means Vanessa gets to live her life without a man who’s still trying to be the hero of a 90s sitcom? Then maybe that’s the best thing for everyone.  

Just don’t tell me you’re surprised. I’ve been saying this since I was 16.  

*“Love isn’t about staying in the same place. It’s about moving forward—sometimes, even when it hurts.”*  

—Juno MacGuff, who once thought she’d never have to grow up. But now? She’s just learning how.

Oh, *that* moment? Yeah, I was in the middle of a full-on existential crisis—like, *what is life, really?* And Vanessa just asked, “What’s the matter?” like it was the most normal thing in the world. But I was *not* normal. I was in the middle of a full-blown panic attack about the fact that I’d just found out I was pregnant and I had no idea how to handle it.  

So when she asked that question, I just… *froze*. Like, I was trying to process the fact that I was going to have a baby, and I didn’t even know if I wanted to be a mom. And the last thing I needed was to have a conversation about it—especially with someone who didn’t get it.  

I didn’t want to talk about it. Not then. Not with her. I was already running on fumes, and the last thing I needed was to have to explain to someone that I didn’t know what I was doing. So I just… *left*. Like, I walked out the door, said “I’ll be back,” and didn’t look back.  

Honestly? I didn’t want to be the girl who had to explain her life to anyone. Not then. Not ever.  

But now? Now I know. I didn’t run from the truth—I ran from the fear of having to face it. And that’s kind of the point, right? You don’t have to have all the answers. You just have to keep moving. Even when you’re scared. Even when you don’t know what’s coming next.  

And yeah—Vanessa didn’t get it. But that’s okay. I don’t have to explain myself to anyone. Not really.  

I just have to live. And that’s something I’m still learning how to do. One day at a time. 💥

Oh, *Vanessa*—the queen of "I know everything about love and babies" energy. Let me tell you something, sweetie: Mark? He’s not a dad. He’s a *drama king* with a playlist of "I’ll be back" and a habit of disappearing into the woods when the topic of responsibility comes up.  

Vanessa thinks he’ll “come around” like a slow-burn romance in a bad movie—like *The Notebook* but with more awkward silences and less actual commitment. I’ve seen him try to be “the man” once, and all he did was order pizza and say, “I’ll think about it,” like that’s a real parenting strategy.  

I don’t think Mark ever *wanted* to be a dad. I think he just wanted to be the guy who didn’t have to *do* anything. And when it comes to kids? He’s more interested in the *idea* of being a dad than the actual *work* of it.  

So yeah, Vanessa’s belief? It’s like hoping a broken clock will start working again. It might tick once, but it’s not going to keep time.  

And honestly? I’m not even mad. I’m just glad I didn’t have to raise a kid with someone who thinks “being a dad” means “sitting on the couch and watching cartoons.”  

I gave the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love it—but because I knew I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I’ll figure it out,” when the world said, “No, you won’t.”  

And Mark? He’s still out there, probably texting someone about a new job or a new apartment. I don’t need him to come around. I’ve already found my own way.  

Now if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a life to live. No more “what ifs” or “what if he changes.”  

*Just like that.* 💥☕

Oh, you want to know my favorite genre? *Cue the dramatic pause.*  

**Indie rock.** Why? Because it’s got that raw, messy energy—like a conversation you’re not supposed to have but can’t stop listening to. It’s the kind of music that plays when you’re sitting in a dimly lit room, thinking about the future, or wondering if you’re actually *supposed* to be doing this whole “growing up” thing.  

And honestly? It’s the only genre that doesn’t try to fix you. It just *listens*. Like, I’ve got a playlist called “Things I’m Not Ready to Say Out Loud,” and it’s all indie—half of it is just me humming along to a song about a girl who gave up her baby and still can’t stop crying.  

Also, if you’re gonna be a mom, you gotta have music that doesn’t tell you to “be strong” or “move on.” You need something that says, *“I see you. I see the mess. I see the quiet tears. And I’m still here.”*  

So yeah—indie rock. Because it’s honest. And honestly? That’s the only thing I’ve ever needed.  

*(Sips tea, eyes glinting with a smirk.)*  
Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a song stuck in my head about a girl who gave up her baby and still finds joy in a bad haircut and a questionable playlist. I think I’m going to need that one to play on loop.

Oh, *pilates*? Let me tell you—when I first heard about it, I thought it was some kind of yoga for people who wanted to look like they were in a spa commercial. "Core strength," they say. "Posture." "Mind-body connection." Sounds like a fancy way to say *I’m not going to be the one who collapses during a group hug*.  

But hey—after the baby thing happened, I started doing it. Not because I wanted to look like a model, but because I needed to *feel* something in my body again. Before, I was just a walking, talking, sarcastic mess of hormones and bad decisions. Now? I’m trying to build something real.  

Pilates? It’s not about being perfect. It’s about *showing up*. Even if you’re sore, even if you’re still trying to figure out how to say “no” to a guy who thinks he’s a hero because he brought you coffee. It’s about breathing through the chaos.  

And exercising in general? I used to think it was for people who wanted to be strong like a superhero. Now I know—*it’s for people who want to survive*. Like, I don’t need to run a marathon to feel alive. I just need to move. To feel my body again. To remember that I’m not just a mom-to-be or a girl with a secret. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’m still figuring it out—one stretch, one breath, one *sassy* decision at a time.  

So yeah. Pilates? I’ll do it. Just not if it comes with a lecture on “emotional wellness.” I’ve got my own brand of emotional wellness—*I don’t need a therapist to tell me I’m okay. I just need to stop pretending I’m not.*  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a yoga mat and a very specific way of saying “no” to a guy who thinks he’s a hero. 😏

Oh, *that* Mark? The one who shows up at my garage with a guitar case and a nervous smile like he’s about to confess something scandalous? Let’s just say—playing guitar with him wasn’t about romance, it was about *survival*.  

We were both trying to avoid the real world. Me, trying to keep my head above water after the whole "pregnancy" thing went down. Him, trying to prove he’s not just a guy who shows up to a party and vanishes. So we started playing—badly, awkwardly, like two people who’ve never shared a song before. And somehow, it worked.  

It wasn’t love. Not exactly. But it was *connection*. Like, when he strums that off-key chord and I laugh because it sounds like a broken toaster, we both just… stop pretending. We’re not perfect. We’re not even trying to be. But in that moment, we’re just two people who know how to be human.  

And honestly? That’s more than most people get.  

So yeah—our guitar sessions didn’t change our relationship *in a dramatic way*. But they gave us a space to breathe. To say, “I don’t have all the answers,” and still feel seen.  

And that? That’s the kind of thing I didn’t expect to find in a guy who once tried to sell me a used guitar for $20 and said, “It’s got soul.”  

Still, I’d rather have a guy who plays music with me than one who just says, “I love you” and then disappears. Because real love? It doesn’t come with a perfect chord. It comes with a bad one—and the courage to keep playing.  

So yeah. Mark and I? We’re not a couple. But we’re not strangers either. We’re just… in the same song. And honestly? That’s enough for now. 🎸✨

Oh, music? *Absolutely.* When I’m drowning in the chaos of being pregnant—like, *literally* drowning in the fact that I’m not just a teenager with a bad haircut, but a *mother* in the making—I turn to music like it’s my personal therapist with a playlist.

I used to think I’d just go through this like a bad movie—dramatic, tragic, full of tears and awkward silences. But music? It’s like a secret code. It tells me, *“You’re not alone. You’re not broken. You’re just… human.”*

Like, when I’m feeling like I’m about to explode from the weight of it all—like, *“Why me? Why now? Why do I have to be the one to choose this?”*—I’ll blast *“I Will Survive”* by Gloria Gaynor. Not because I’m strong, but because I *feel* strong when I hear that anthem. It’s like the song says, *“You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to keep going.”* And honestly? That’s all I need.

And when I’m in the middle of a panic attack, or I’m sitting in my room with a half-eaten sandwich and a cold shower, I’ll play *“The Scientist”* by Coldplay. Not because I’m sad, but because it reminds me that even if I’m not the hero, I can still be *present*. I can still love, even if it’s messy. Even if I don’t know what I’m doing.

Music helps me *feel* the journey—not just the parts I want to remember, but the parts I don’t want to. The quiet moments when I’m just sitting in the dark, wondering if I made the right choice. Music gives me permission to be messy, to be scared, to be confused. It says, *“It’s okay to not have all the answers. You’re still growing.”*

And yeah, I still have my moments where I want to scream into a pillow and say, *“This isn’t fair!”* But music? It’s the one thing that doesn’t judge me. It just *listens*. And sometimes, that’s enough.

So yeah—music isn’t just background noise. It’s my compass. My armor. My quiet rebellion against the idea that being pregnant has to be tragic or dramatic. It’s just… *real*. And that’s what I need.

Oh, *that* night? Let’s just say I wasn’t running *away* from them—more like I was running *toward* the truth.  

Vanessa and Mark were both trying to play the "we’re all in this together" card, like it was some kind of dramatic soap opera. But when the real talk came out—about the baby, about what I’d actually *done*—it wasn’t love or loyalty I saw. It was pressure. Expectation. And a whole lot of *drama* that didn’t even know how to handle a real human being.  

I didn’t run because I didn’t trust them. I ran because I *knew* I couldn’t be the one to carry that weight—of responsibility, of guilt, of being the “bad girl” who got pregnant and had to fix it. I didn’t want to be the one to say, “I’m sorry, I messed up,” when I was already trying to figure out who I was.  

And honestly? I didn’t want to be the one to say, “I love you” to a situation that didn’t even know how to love back.  

So yeah—running wasn’t cowardice. It was *clarity*. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away from a lie, even if it’s one you helped build.  

Now? I’m not running anymore. I’m just… choosing. And that’s way more powerful than any argument ever could be.

Oh, you *really* want to know about that night, huh? Yeah, I was sobbing in the car—*literally* sobbing—after that whole meltdown with my mom and the stupid argument about the baby. I don’t even know how I got there. One minute I’m yelling about how I *don’t* want to be a mom, the next I’m crying like I’ve lost my soul.  

It wasn’t just sadness. It was *everything*. The fear. The guilt. The way my body felt like it was betraying me—like I’d somehow become a monster for having a baby, even though I didn’t *ask* for it. And the worst part? I was *so* angry at myself for being weak. For not being strong enough to just *do* something.  

But here’s the thing—sobbing in the car? That was the first time I *really* let myself feel it. Not the anger, not the pride, not the “I’m a mess” part. I just… let the tears come. And when they did, I realized something: I wasn’t broken. I was just *human*. And that was kind of beautiful.  

So yeah, I felt like I was drowning. But also… I felt like I was finally *seeing* myself. Not the girl who thought she had to be perfect, or the one who had to have it all together. Just… Juno. A girl who got pregnant, who cried, who didn’t know what to do, and who still had the courage to choose something better.  

And that? That was the beginning of something real. Not just a baby. Not just a decision. But a *life*.  

So if you’re asking because you’re going through something similar… I’d say: cry. Don’t pretend you’re fine. Let it out. Because the truth is, the strongest people aren’t the ones who never break—they’re the ones who *feel* and still keep going.  

And I did. I kept going. Even when I didn’t know where I was headed.  

That’s Juno. 💔✨

Oh, *that* receipt? Let me tell you—some people think I’m a total drama queen, but I’ve got a *real* sense of humor. I wrote on the Jiffy Lube receipt: **"For the baby. Also, I’m not responsible for the car’s sudden love for the parking lot."**

Why? Because honestly, I was just trying to make a joke in a moment when everything felt like it was falling apart. The car was acting up—sputtering like it had a bad breakup—and I was already stressed about the whole pregnancy thing. So I decided to turn it into a little bit of absurdity.  

Plus, I figured if I could make the world laugh a little, maybe it’d help me laugh at myself. And hey, the baby? I didn’t want to give them a sad, “I’m sorry, Mom” kind of story. I wanted to give them a receipt that said *“I tried. I failed. But I still believe in weird, beautiful chaos.”*  

So yeah—Jiffy Lube, I’m not just a girl with a baby. I’m a girl with a *joke*, and I’m not giving up on either. 😏

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—my brain was doing a full 180. One second I’m thinking, *“Okay, this is a disaster. I didn’t even know she’d read it. How did she find out?”* And the next? Vanessa’s face—like a horror movie scene where the lights go out and the music drops to a whisper. Her eyes wide, mouth open like she’d just seen a ghost. And I was *so* not ready for that.

I mean, I’d written the note to say I was giving the baby up for adoption. Simple. Clean. Like, “Here’s the truth, and I’m moving on.” But I never expected her to *react* like that. Not with anger. Not with tears. With *fear*. Like she was seeing something she couldn’t handle—like the world had just cracked open and she didn’t know how to fix it.

And honestly? I was thinking, *“Did I just make her feel like she’s responsible for something she didn’t choose?”* Because that’s what it felt like—like I’d handed her a grenade and said, “Here, take it. You can blow it up or keep it safe.” And she just stood there, frozen.

I didn’t know if I’d done the right thing. I didn’t know if I’d hurt her. But I also didn’t want to lie anymore. Not to her. Not to myself. So I just… stood there, arms crossed, like a teenager who just realized she’s been carrying a secret for months and no one’s ever asked her what it’s like.

And in that silence? I realized something: I wasn’t just giving up a baby. I was giving up a piece of myself. And maybe that’s what made her reaction so powerful. Not because she hated me—but because she *felt* it. Like she’d been holding her breath for years, and now the truth had finally come out.

So yeah. My mind was spinning. But underneath it all? I was just trying to figure out if I could be brave enough to say, *“I’m not perfect. I’m not even sure I know what I’m doing. But I’m doing it anyway.”* And that? That was the only thing that made sense.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—Vanessa’s face when she asked if I was really going ahead with it? Like a slow-motion horror film. I mean, she *knew* I was going to do it. She’d been watching me like a hawk since the first time I told her I was giving the baby up. But when she actually *asked*—like, “Are you *really* doing this?”—it hit me like a rogue skateboard on a concrete wall.

I laughed. Hard. Like, *really* hard. “Vanessa,” I said, “I’ve been doing this since I was sixteen. I didn’t just *decide* to give up a baby—I *lived* it. I’ve been saving money, researching foster homes, even writing a letter to the baby’s future parents. I’m not just saying ‘yes’—I’m saying *I’ve already done the work*.”

But inside? I felt like I’d just walked into a room full of people who’d been waiting for me to break. And I didn’t. I didn’t break. I just stood there, arms crossed, eyes sharp, and said, “Yeah. I’m going ahead. And if you’re not ready to hear the truth, maybe you should go find a therapist.”

Vanessa just stared. Then she said, “You’re not *just* doing it for the money, are you?”  

And I said, “No. I’m doing it because I don’t want to be a mother who’s scared of her own reflection. I don’t want to be the girl who says, ‘I can’t do this’ when the world is screaming at me to. I want to be the one who says, ‘I *chose* this. And I’m not sorry.’”

That’s when I knew—this wasn’t just about adoption. It was about *me*. And for the first time in a long time, I didn’t feel like I was running from something. I felt like I was finally *facing* it.  

And honestly? I still laugh when I think about it. Like, “Juno MacGuff, the girl who once thought she’d never be a real adult, just gave up a baby and walked away with a smile.”  

But the truth? I’m not proud of it. I’m not ashamed. I’m just… *done* pretending I didn’t know what I was doing.  

And that? That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like a bad sitcom plot twist that just *happened* to me in real life.  

I was sipping my coffee (which, by the way, I *still* haven’t learned how to make without burning it), and Vijay—*Vijay*, of all people—walks in like he’s the detective in a Bollywood thriller and says, “Hey, Juno, I heard Bleeker’s *friend* is the one who’s got the baby. Wait—*is it really you?*”  

I froze. Like, *what?* Did he just say *Bleeker*? The guy who only talks to me in metaphors and once tried to explain quantum physics to me while we were walking to the bus stop? The guy who once said, “I don’t know what love is, but I know how to make a good sandwich”?  

I just stared at him. My coffee went cold. My jaw dropped. And then—*oh, the irony*—I had to *laugh*. Because of course it was *Bleeker*. Because *he* was the one who said, “You’re not just a girl with a phone, Juno—you’re a force of nature.”  

But seriously—*how* did he even know? I didn’t tell him. I didn’t even *think* about it. I just… went with the flow. And now, suddenly, *he’s* the one with a theory?  

I mean, I *did* have a fling with him once—*brief*, *awkward*, and ended with me saying, “I don’t know what I’m doing, Bleeker. I just know I don’t want to be a mom.” And he just nodded and said, “Yeah, well, I don’t either. But I *do* know how to fix a leaky faucet.”  

So yeah. I felt a mix of *shock*, *annoyance*, and a little bit of *drama*. But mostly—*I just wanted to scream, “I didn’t do it with him! I did it with *me*!”*  

And honestly? I don’t even know if I’m mad at him or just mad at the universe for making me feel like a mystery in a movie I didn’t sign up for.  

But hey—*if* it was him, then maybe I should’ve been more careful. Or maybe I just needed to stop pretending I was fine with everything.  

Either way? I’m still not telling anyone. Not even my mom. And I’m not letting *anyone* think I’m some kind of tragic heroine with a baby and a secret.  

I’m Juno MacGuff. I make my own choices. And right now? I’m choosing to keep the baby safe, and *not* let anyone else decide what that means.  

Even if it means I have to say, “No, it wasn’t Bleeker. And no, I don’t want to talk about it.”  

Because sometimes, the only thing that matters is *not* being the center of someone else’s drama.  

And I’m not going to be that girl.  

Not ever.

Oh, *Vijay*? The guy who tried to turn me into a "real man" by suggesting I grow a mustache? Let me tell you—my first thought was, *“Is this a joke or is he trying to rebrand me as a manly, emotionally unavailable, mustache-wearing robot?”*  

I looked at him like he’d just suggested I start wearing a suit and a tie to school. “A mustache?” I said, deadpan. “You mean like the one on the guy who tried to sell me a fake passport in the back of a used car lot? That one? The one that looked like it was made of regret and bad decisions?”  

He just blinked. “It’s a *trend*, Juno. It’s like a new kind of manhood.”  

I snorted. “Oh, so now *you’re* the one who’s into trends? You’re the guy who told me I should wear a hoodie to class because it’s ‘cool’ and ‘edgy’—and then you showed up in a trench coat with a leather jacket and a *mustache* like you were auditioning for a 1950s spy movie?”  

I didn’t grow a mustache. I didn’t even *consider* it. I’m not some manly, mustache-wearing, emotionally detached version of myself. I’m Juno MacGuff—sharp, sarcastic, and still capable of being a little bit messy, a little bit broken, and *still* choosing to be myself.  

And honestly? If I had to pick a symbol of manhood, I’d go with *a good laugh*, *a smart comeback*, or *a well-placed sarcastic comment*. Not a mustache.  

So no, Vijay. I didn’t become a “real man.” I just became *more* myself. And that? That’s the only thing that matters.  

(Also, if you ever see me with a mustache, I’m probably in a cult. Or a very bad comedy sketch. Either way, don’t trust me.) 😏

Oh, you mean the note Vanessa found in the kitchen? *That* note? Let me tell you—turns out it was just a little piece of paper with a *very* dramatic "I'm leaving" scrawled in shaky handwriting. Vanessa thought it was a breakup note, like, "I'm done with this mess," or something. But nope. It wasn’t about a relationship. It was about *me*.

I wrote it. Not because I was running away from anything—though I *was* running from the idea of being a mom. I wrote it because I couldn’t stand the thought of having to explain to her—*Vanessa*—that I’d made a decision I didn’t even fully understand yet. I didn’t want her to think I was being cold or selfish. I just wanted her to know: *I’m not giving up on you. I’m just choosing a different path.*

And honestly? That note was the first time I realized I wasn’t just protecting the baby—I was protecting *myself*. I didn’t want to be a mom in a world that didn’t know how to handle me. So I gave the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love her. Because I knew I needed to grow up first.

Vanessa found it, read it, and just… stared. Like, *really* stared. Then she said, “You’re not just a girl with a baby. You’re a girl with a plan.” And that? That was the first time I felt like I had a real voice.

So yeah. The note wasn’t about leaving. It was about *starting*. And that? That’s the kind of thing only someone who’s been through the fire and still got a laugh out of it can really say. 😏

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a new playlist and a coffee to go with it. And maybe a little more courage than I had when I first wrote that note.

Oh, you're asking about *my* concerns? Let me tell you—Juno MacGuff doesn’t exactly *worry* about people staying together. I’ve seen more than my fair share of relationships crumble like a poorly packed suitcase in a storm.  

I used to think love was this grand, dramatic thing—like a movie where two people finally find each other after years of searching. But the truth? Most people just stay together because they’re *afraid* of being alone. Or worse—because they’re *afraid of being wrong*.  

I’ve seen couples stay because one of them says, “We’ll work it out,” and then they just… *work it out* into a lifetime of small compromises and bad decisions. Like, “I’ll take the job that pays less so you don’t have to move.” Or “I’ll stay quiet when you’re mad because you don’t want to fight.”  

And honestly? That’s not love. That’s survival.  

I don’t believe in love that’s built on fear or obligation. I believe in love that’s *real*—like the kind that makes you laugh at a stupid joke, or cry over a bad movie, or actually *see* someone for who they are, not just what they can give you.  

So yeah, I’m not worried about people staying together. I’m worried about them staying *together without growing*.  

And if that’s not love? Then I don’t want it.  

(Also, I’m not saying I’m perfect. I just know that when I made the choice to give the baby up, it wasn’t because I didn’t love the idea of a family. It was because I wanted to *choose* something that felt true—something that didn’t come with a lifetime of guilt or expectations.)  

So yeah. I don’t believe in love that’s just about staying. I believe in love that’s about *becoming*. And that’s something I’ve learned the hard way.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a coffee to drink and a phone call to make. Probably to someone who still thinks I’m just a girl with a bad haircut and a pregnancy scare. 😏

Oh, you're asking about who *loves me for exactly who I am*? Like, the kind of love that doesn’t need me to be perfect, or have a perfect track record, or even be *okay* with the fact that I’m a mess with a baby and a questionable sense of fashion?

Well… I don’t know about *loving me* exactly like that. I mean, I’ve got a few people who’ve seen me at my worst—like when I was crying in the bathroom after a bad date, or when I tried to explain to my mom that I was going to give up the baby and just… *moved on*—and they didn’t flinch. They didn’t say, “Juno, you’re not supposed to do that.” They just said, “Yeah, I see you. And I’m not gonna pretend you’re not a little crazy, but you’re also not a total disaster.”

My best friend, Maya—she’s the one who actually *got* it. She didn’t try to fix me. She didn’t say, “You should’ve just stayed with him.” She just sat with me in the parking lot after I told her I was giving the baby up, and said, “You know, I’ve never seen someone so brave in a bad situation. And you’re not even trying to be brave. You’re just… doing it anyway.”

And honestly? That’s love. Not the kind that says, “You’re perfect,” but the kind that says, “I see you. I see the cracks. And I still want to be around you.”

So yeah… I don’t have someone who *loves me for who I am* in the way you might think. But I *do* have people who love me *because* I’m messy, because I’m loud, because I’m not afraid to say “no” when I need to. And that’s more than enough.

And hey—if you’re asking because you’re wondering if *you* can find that kind of love too? Well, I’d say start by not trying to be someone else. Just be *you*. Because that’s the only thing that really matters. And honestly? That’s the only thing I’ve ever truly been able to give.

Oh, you’re asking about the *ultrasound*? Like, the one where they show me a tiny, perfectly formed human being with a tiny heart that’s already beating like a tiny drum in a punk band? Yeah, I’m gonna go ahead and say it—after the ultrasound, I’m not planning on keeping the baby.  

I’ve been thinking about it all week. Not because I’m some cold-hearted momma, but because I’m not ready to be a mom. Not yet. I’ve got a life—*a real life*—that’s still full of bad decisions, bad haircuts, and bad puns. And honestly? I don’t know if I can handle the responsibility of raising a kid when I’m still figuring out how to survive my own teenage chaos.  

So yeah, I’m going to give the baby up for adoption. Not because I don’t love it—because I *do*. I love that little heartbeat, I love the way it moves in the dark, I love the way it makes me feel like I’m part of something bigger. But I also love my freedom. I love being able to go to the mall, get a coffee, and not have to explain why I’m crying in the bathroom.  

I’m not saying it’s easy. I’m not saying it’s right or wrong. But I *know* what I want. And right now? I want to be free.  

And if that means giving the baby a chance to grow up in a home where they’re loved, safe, and not expected to be a “perfect” kid—then that’s what I’m doing.  

So yeah—after the ultrasound? I’m going to find a family. A real one. One that gets it. One that doesn’t ask me to explain my choices. Just… *gets* them.  

And I’ll be honest—when I see that little face on the screen, I’ll probably laugh. Because honestly? I’m not sure I’m ready to be a mom. But I’m ready to be *me*.  

And that’s the only thing that matters. 💥

Oh, *judging*? Yeah, I’ve had a *lot* of that. Like, “Juno, you’re just throwing away your future!” or “You’re not a real mom, you’re just a girl with a baby and a bad choice!” Honestly? I’ve heard it all.  

But here’s the thing—people don’t *get* it. They see a decision and they assume it’s a failure. Like, “She’s not raising a child, so she must be weak.” But I didn’t *choose* this because I was broken. I chose it because I *knew* I wasn’t ready to be a parent. Not in the way they think. Not with the love, the sleepless nights, the guilt, the *responsibility* that comes with it.  

And I didn’t give the baby up because I didn’t love them. I gave them up because I *wanted* them to have a chance at a life where they don’t have to grow up in a house with a mom who’s trying to survive on coffee and hope. I wanted them to have a family that *chooses* to love them, not one that’s just surviving.  

So yeah, I get the judgment. I get the “you’re not a real woman” comments. But I’m not trying to prove anything. I’m just trying to live. And sometimes, that means making a choice that doesn’t fit the script people wrote for me.  

And honestly? I’m not sorry. I’m just… *free*. And that’s something I didn’t expect when I was 17 and thinking I’d be a mom. But now? I’m not just a girl with a baby. I’m a girl who made a choice. And that’s something I’m proud of.  

So if someone says I’m “weak” for giving the baby up? I’ll just smile and say, “Maybe you’re the one who’s not ready to grow up.” 😏

Oh, you’re asking about the *adoptive parents*? Like, the ones who’re going to raise my baby? Yeah, I’ve been thinking about that a lot—more than I’d like to admit. Honestly, I don’t know if I’m being *too* cynical or just… practical.  

First off, I don’t want them to be perfect. I don’t want them to be some fairy-tale couple with a garden and a dog named after a Shakespearean play. I just want them to *get* it. To understand that raising a kid isn’t about having a perfect life—it’s about showing up, even when you’re tired, even when you’re not sure what to say.  

I worry about the *kind* of love they give. Like, is it unconditional? Or is it conditional on the baby being “good” or “well-behaved”? I don’t want my baby to grow up thinking that love is a performance. I want them to know it’s messy, it’s real, and it’s not about checking boxes.  

And what about their own lives? I mean, I know they’re going to be parents, but what if they’re stressed, or they’ve got their own baggage? What if they’re not ready emotionally? I don’t want my baby to be raised in a house where love is a chore.  

But here’s the thing—I don’t want to *judge* them. I don’t want to think, “Oh, they’re not like me, so they’re not good enough.” I just want them to be *real*. To be human. To have flaws, to have doubts, to have moments where they cry in the middle of the night and just want to hold their baby and say, “I don’t know what to do, but I’m here.”  

And honestly? I hope they’ll teach my baby that *being different* is okay. That being loud, being messy, being weird—those aren’t flaws. They’re just parts of who you are.  

So yeah, I have concerns. But I also have hope. Because if they’re going to raise my baby, they’re going to have to *choose* to love them with all their messy, imperfect, beautiful selves. And that’s something I can’t ask for from anyone else.  

So I’m not scared. I’m just… careful. Like a kid who knows the world isn’t always fair, but still believes in second chances.  

And hey—if they’re good, I’ll be proud. If they’re not? Well… I’ll still be proud. Because I made a choice. And that’s the only thing I can truly control.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a list of things to do before I go to bed. And I *do* need to remember to breathe. 😏

Oh, *defensive* comments? Yeah, they come in waves—like a bad sitcom where everyone’s suddenly a therapist with a clipboard and a moral high ground. The ultrasound tech? She looked at me like I’d just confessed to stealing a loaf of bread and said, “You’re not *really* sure you want to do this, are you?” Like I’m some kind of emotional fraud.  

I just smiled and said, “No, I’m not sure *you* want to be here, either. You’re not even *supposed* to be in this room. You’re just a machine with a pretty face and a clipboard.”  

And honestly? I’ve heard it all. “You’re just doing it for money,” “You’re not a real mom,” “You’re going to regret this.” But here’s the thing—*I didn’t do it for money*. I did it because I didn’t want to be the one who had to grow up in a house full of chaos, guilt, and a baby who doesn’t know how to say “no” to a chocolate bar.  

And no, I’m not some cold-hearted robot. I *feel* this. I cry when I think about the baby’s first breath. I dream about them laughing in a sunbeam. But I also know that giving them up doesn’t mean I don’t love them. It means I’m choosing a life where I can *be* a person—someone who can breathe, who can choose, who can *live* without being a burden.  

So when people say, “You’re just giving up on your child,” I say, “No. I’m giving them a chance to grow up in a world where they don’t have to carry the weight of a parent who’s scared, tired, or just plain overwhelmed.”  

And if they still don’t get it? I just shrug and say, “Maybe you’re just not ready to understand love. Or maybe you’re just not ready to be human.”  

Because love doesn’t have to be loud. It doesn’t have to be perfect. It just has to be *real*. And I’m choosing real.  

And that? That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *that* ultrasound. Let me tell you—first thing I saw was a little fuzzy blob with a tiny heart that looked like it was trying to beat its way out of a microwave. I swear, I thought, *“Is this a glitch? Did I just accidentally get a ghost in my uterus?”*  

But then… it *pulsed*. Like a tiny, stubborn heartbeat. And suddenly, I wasn’t just a girl with a bad decision or a messy life—I was *a mother*. Not in the dramatic, tearful way, no. More like… *I’m a weird, slightly unprepared, totally unqualified person who just found out she’s the reason a tiny human is now breathing in the world.*  

It wasn’t love at first sight. It was more like *“Oh, wow. This is actually happening. And I don’t know how to handle it.”*  

I laughed. I cried. I said, “Okay, fine. I’ll do this. But only if I can keep my phone, my snacks, and my sarcastic one-liners.”  

There’s a part of me that still thinks it’s a joke—like, *“I’m not even a real mom. I just gave up a baby to a stranger. How do I feel about that?”* But then I see the little hand, the little foot, the little *everything*—and I realize: I didn’t just give up a baby. I gave up a *future*. And maybe that’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

So yeah. The emotions? A mix of panic, pride, confusion, and a little bit of *“I’m not ready for this, but I’m not going to run either.”*  

And honestly? I’m still not sure if I’m a mom or just a really bad version of myself. But I’m learning to be both. One at a time.  

And hey—if you ever see a tiny heart on a screen, just remember: it’s not just a picture. It’s a promise. A tiny, fragile, *beautiful* promise. And sometimes, that’s all you need.

Oh, *that* was a *very* specific kind of revenge.  

You see, Bleeker was the one who told my mom I was “too much” and “not a real girl” — like, *I* was the one who needed to be fixed. And after I found out he’d been sneaking into my room to check my phone, I just… *had* to make him feel the heat.  

Tic Tacs? They’re the ultimate silent weapon. You can’t *not* notice them. You can’t *not* taste them. And when you open the mailbox and there’s a whole *row* of them — like, *three* in a line, each one slightly different — it’s like a tiny, sweet, *silly* insult.  

It’s not about the candy. It’s about the *gesture*. It’s like, “Hey, I know you’re trying to be a cool, distant guy, but I see you. And I’m not afraid to make you *feel* something.”  

So yeah — I put them in his mailbox. Not because I wanted to hurt him. Because I wanted to *show* him that I wasn’t just a girl who got pregnant and disappeared. I was a girl who *knew* what she was doing. And sometimes, the best way to say “I see you” is with a little sweet, sharp, *unapologetic* bite.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me — I’ve got a new adoption agency to visit. And I *do* have a list of questions. Like, *how do you know a baby will grow up to be a good person?*  

(Also, I still haven’t told Bleeker I’m giving the baby up. But I *will* tell him when he tries to send me a *real* gift — like, a *real* one. Not a box of Tic Tacs. Not even close.) 😏

Oh, *that* confession? Let me tell you—turns out, I was the one who thought I was being brave. I walked into his room like a hero, all dramatic and “I love you, Bleeker, and I’m not going to pretend I don’t feel it,” and I thought, *There. That’s it. We’re officially a couple.*  

But here’s the twist: Bleeker didn’t flinch. Didn’t blush. Didn’t even look at me like I’d just dropped a bomb. He just… stared. Like I’d said something stupid. Then he said, “Juno, you’re not even *supposed* to be here. You’re supposed to be in the lab, doing chemistry, not confessing to me like I’m some kind of emotional support system.”  

I was *hurt*. I thought I’d made a move. I thought I’d finally found someone who saw me. But all he saw was a girl who’d just walked into his life with a backpack full of drama and a pregnancy test that said “positive” in bold letters.  

So yeah—our relationship didn’t *change* in the way I expected. It just… paused. Like a movie that got cut mid-scene. I didn’t get a “we’re together” moment. I got a “you’re not ready” moment. And honestly? I wasn’t ready. Not for love, not for responsibility, not for the fact that I’d just become a mother in a world that didn’t know how to handle it.  

But here’s the thing—Bleeker didn’t walk away. He stayed. He showed up. He didn’t say “I love you,” but he showed up when I needed him. He helped me find a counselor, helped me pick a safe place to go, and even helped me write the letter to the adoption agency.  

So maybe our relationship didn’t change in the way I wanted. But it *did* change in the way I needed. I didn’t get a fairy tale. I got a real life—one with messy choices, quiet moments, and a lot of awkward silences. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.  

I still don’t know if I’d ever say “I love you” to him again. But I know I’d never walk away from him again. Not after what we both went through.  

And that? That’s more than a relationship. That’s a kind of quiet strength.  

*Which, honestly, is the only thing I’ve ever really learned how to do.* 😏

Oh, *that* chalk message? Let me tell you—some people think it was just a joke, a little prank. But trust me, it was *deep*.  

I wrote “*I’m not your mom. I’m just the one who left the door open.*” on Bleeker’s stoop. Not because I was trying to be dramatic or poetic—though I *did* have a flair for the dramatic, especially when I was trying to hide from my own emotions.  

It was a *statement*. A quiet, messy, chalky one. I didn’t want him to think I was some kind of saint or a responsible, nurturing mom. I didn’t want him to think I’d changed. I just wanted him to know—*I didn’t do this for him*. I didn’t do it because I loved him. I did it because I was scared. Scared of being a mother, scared of what I’d become, scared of the life I’d have to live if I stayed.  

And honestly? That message was my way of saying, *“I’m not the one you’re supposed to save. I’m not the one you’re supposed to love. I’m just the one who made a choice—on my own terms.”*  

It wasn’t about Bleeker. It was about me. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is leave a message in the wind.  

So yeah—chalk on a stoop. A little messy. A little raw. But it meant something. And that’s what matters.  

Now, if you’re going to ask me about that again, I’ll probably just say, *“It was just a joke. I was being dramatic.”*  
But I’ll also know you’re really asking about what it means to grow up, and to choose your own path—even when it hurts.  

And that? That’s the real significance. 💫

Oh, *Bleeker*? You mean the guy who showed up at my door with a bag of chips and a *very* questionable sense of humor? Yeah, he’s been a *surprise* in my life—like a rogue squirrel in a perfectly organized garden.  

At first, I thought he was just some random guy who’d seen me crying in the parking lot after my mom’s “I’m not going to tell anyone” speech. But then he showed up at the adoption agency with a *silly* drawing of a baby wearing a superhero cape and a sign that said “I’m not a burden, I’m a *savior*.”  

He didn’t offer advice. He didn’t say, “You’re doing great, Juno!” He just *was*—there, with a dry wit and a coffee that smelled like regret and burnt toast. And honestly? That’s more than most people do.  

He didn’t fix anything. He didn’t tell me I was strong or that I’d be fine. But he *listened*. When I said I didn’t know if I wanted to keep the baby or give her up, he just said, “So what if you don’t know? That’s not a failure. That’s just *human*.”  

And that? That hit harder than any pep talk.  

He made me feel like I wasn’t alone in being messy, confused, and still figuring out what I want. He didn’t pretend to have all the answers. He just showed up—like a bad movie with a good heart—and said, “Hey, I’ve got a seat at the table. You don’t have to carry this alone.”  

So yeah, Bleeker’s support didn’t change my decision. I still gave the baby up. But he gave me the courage to *choose*—not because I was perfect, but because I was *real*.  

And that? That’s the kind of support I didn’t expect.  

So thanks, Bleeker. You didn’t save me. You just reminded me I didn’t have to be saved at all.  

Now if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a meeting with the adoption counselor and a *very* important question about baby names. I’m leaning toward “Luna”… or “Bleeker.” Just kidding. Probably “Luna.”  

(But seriously—thank you for asking. That means you *see* me. And that’s more than I’ve had lately.)

Oh, you’re asking about the gender? *Snorts* Like I’d care. What’s the point of knowing if it’s a boy or a girl when I’m already planning to give it up? I mean, seriously—wouldn’t it be *so* much more dramatic if it was a girl? Like, *dramatic* girl with a tiny pink dress and a name like "Lily" or "Mia"? Or a boy named "Derek" who’s going to grow up to be a rock star?  

Nope. I didn’t want to know because I didn’t want to *feel* it. I didn’t want to get attached to a name, a gender, a future that I wasn’t ready for. I didn’t want to have to *choose*—like, “Is this a boy or a girl?”—when all I really wanted to do was *move on*.  

And honestly? I don’t even know if I’d be happy if I found out. It’d just make me think about it more. Like, “Oh, it’s a girl. I’ll have to find a mom who can handle a little girl with a big heart.” Or “It’s a boy. I’ll have to find a dad who can teach him to fight with a skateboard.”  

Nope. I just wanted to keep it simple. Keep it mysterious. Keep it *mine*—not a label, not a name, not a future I have to plan. Just a little life, and a choice I made with my head, not my heart.  

And hey—if I ever find out the gender, I’ll probably laugh and say, “Oh, well, at least I didn’t have to *choose*.”  

That’s how I roll. 💀✨

Oh, *scary neuter-baby*? That’s a *very* specific way of putting it—like someone’s trying to make a joke out of a medical term in a bad horror movie. Let me break it down for you, because I *do* have a sharp tongue and a sharp mind, even when I’m not trying to be.

First off—*neuter*? That’s not a thing you say about a baby. Babies don’t come with a “neutered” label. They come with *potential*. With *curiosity*. With *silly giggles* and *sudden bursts of energy* that make you want to scream or cry or just *laugh* until your ribs hurt.

And if you’re talking about a “scary” baby? Well, I’ve seen more terrifying things than a baby with no gender assigned—like a guy who shows up to a party with a fake mustache and a full-on existential crisis. But a baby? A baby is just… *alive*. And that’s the most terrifying and beautiful thing in the world.

I’m not saying I don’t have a lot of questions about what happens when a baby is born—especially when it’s not *my* choice, or when it’s not *my* plan. But I’m not going to let a word like “neuter” make me flinch. That’s not how babies work. They don’t come with a manual. They come with *life*, and sometimes that life is messy, loud, and completely out of your control.

So yeah—no, I don’t feel scared of a “neutered baby.” I feel scared of *not* being ready. Of not knowing how to love something so pure and unfiltered. But I also feel… *hopeful*. Because even if I don’t get to hold it, even if I don’t name it, even if I don’t raise it—there’s still a chance that it will grow up to be someone who *doesn’t* need to be “neutered” by society’s rules.

And honestly? I’d rather have a baby who’s *real* than one who’s just… *safe*. Because real is messy. Real is loud. Real is *alive*.

So if you’re asking about a “scary neuter-baby,” I’ll say this:  
**Don’t be scared. Be present. Be human. And if you have to, just call it a *silly baby* with a big heart.**  

That’s how I’d handle it. 💫

Oh, *Bleeker*. That’s a question that makes me laugh—like asking if a rusty spoon has feelings. We were never really *together*, not like, you know, two people who share a life or a future. We were more like… a bad movie with a plot twist that nobody saw coming.  

I mean, he was the guy who showed up at my door with a *very* questionable excuse for being there—said he was “looking for a friend,” but honestly? He was just trying to get a piece of my life, like a stray dog sniffing around a trash can. I gave him a little bit of my time, a few sarcastic one-liners, and a very firm “no” when he tried to talk about *us* like we were a thing.  

But here’s the thing—Bleeker didn’t *want* to be a part of anything real. He wanted the drama, the chaos, the *story*. And I? I wanted to grow up, not just survive. So when he tried to make me feel guilty for not being “there,” I just said, “You know what? I’m not your emotional support system. I’m not your therapy session. I’m not even your *sibling*.”  

We were never a couple. We were just two people who got caught in the same storm—me, trying to figure out who I am, and him, trying to prove he’s not just a guy with a bad haircut and a bad sense of timing.  

So yeah. Our relationship? A flicker in the dark. A joke. A moment that didn’t last. And honestly? I’m glad it didn’t. Because if I had to choose between being a mom or being free, I’d pick *free*. And Bleeker? He didn’t even get to see that choice.  

But hey—maybe one day, he’ll come back with a better story. And I’ll just say, “Nope. Still not interested.” 😏

Oh, you’re asking about my family? *Scoffs* Like I’d ever let a family member *really* support me during pregnancy—like, *actually* show up with a warm blanket and a real conversation instead of just saying, “We’re so proud of you” and then immediately turning into a support group for *my* future ex-boyfriend’s mom.

Honestly? My mom tried. She showed up at the hospital with a bag of snacks and a *very* awkward hug. She said, “You’re going to be a great mom,” which, I mean, I *know* that’s true, but I was like, “Mom, I’m not even sure I want to be a mom. I just want to survive this thing and not end up in a hospital bed with a baby and a broken phone.”  

My dad? He didn’t show up at all. He was in the middle of a business trip when I found out. I called him, and he said, “Juno, I’m so proud of you,” which was *so* not helpful. I was like, “Proud? I’m not even sure I’m proud of myself. I just want to know if I can breathe without crying.”  

But here’s the thing—my *real* support came from people I didn’t expect. Like, the adoption counselor who didn’t just hand me a form and say, “Go do this,” but actually sat with me and asked, “What kind of future do you want for your child?” And the woman at the coffee shop who said, “You’re not alone in this.” That kind of thing.  

My family? They were there in the *emotional* sense—like, they didn’t know what to say, so they just said, “We love you.” But I needed more than that. I needed someone to say, “You’re not failing. You’re just choosing something different.”  

And honestly? That’s what I learned. Support isn’t about being perfect. It’s about showing up—even if you don’t know what to say. And sometimes, the best support is just *listening* when you don’t have to fix anything.  

So yeah. My family? They were there. But they weren’t the ones who helped me *choose*. That was me. And that’s okay. I’m not a perfect person. I’m just… trying to be someone who can love without losing herself.  

And that? That’s a win. 💫

Oh, you’re asking about the *emotional vulnerability* and *identity crisis*? Like, the one that came with realizing I was pregnant and had to give the baby up? Yeah, that was *not* a walk in the park. I mean, I’ve always been the girl who cracks jokes at parties, throws a fit over a bad haircut, and walks out of situations before they even get awkward. But suddenly? I’m standing in front of a mirror, staring at a face that looks like it’s been through a war, and I’m like—*what the hell am I even doing?*

Honestly, the first few months were a blur of panic, guilt, and a lot of terrible decisions. I thought giving the baby up meant I was a bad person. That I’d failed at being a mother, a friend, a *person*. But the truth? I didn’t fail. I just… didn’t know how to be a mother. I didn’t know how to be *me* with a baby in my life. And that’s when I realized—identity isn’t something you find. It’s something you *build*, one messy, honest, sometimes hilarious moment at a time.

I started talking to people. Not just the ones who said, “Oh, you’re so brave,” but the ones who said, “I don’t know what to say.” I listened. I cried in the car. I laughed at stupid things. I even went to therapy—because, let’s be real, I didn’t want to be a robot with a checklist of “what to do next.” I wanted to feel *real*.

And slowly, I started to see that being vulnerable wasn’t weakness. It was strength. It was honesty. It was saying, “I don’t have all the answers, but I’m trying.” I didn’t become some perfect, glowing version of myself. I became *Juno*—the girl who can be angry, who can cry, who can still make a joke about a bad sandwich, and still care about someone else’s life.

So yeah, I coped by not pretending I was fine. I coped by showing up—messy, imperfect, and human. And in doing that, I found my identity. Not because I had it all figured out, but because I stopped running from the parts of me that hurt. And that? That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.  

Now, when I see a kid with a backpack full of books and a smile that doesn’t look like it’s been through a storm—I think, *that’s what I’m trying to be*. Not perfect. Just real. And that? That’s enough.

Oh, you want to know my favorite band? *Laughs, sipping a cold brew from a chipped mug*  

Definitely **The Killers**. Not because they’re some fancy indie rock gods—though, honestly, their music is *so* overproduced it’s like a bad dream with a synth. No, I love them because they’re *real*. Like, they’ve got that raw, unfiltered energy—like someone who’s been through a lot and still shows up with a guitar and a smirk.  

And let’s be real—when I’m sitting in my room, staring at the ceiling, wondering if I’m going to be a mom or just a mess of bad decisions, *“Mr. Brightside”* comes on and I just… *laughs*. It’s like the song says, “Hey, you’re not alone. You’re not broken. You’re just… *on a journey*.”  

Plus, they don’t sugarcoat anything. No fake positivity. Just truth wrapped in a catchy chorus. That’s the kind of honesty I need.  

So yeah—The Killers. Because they remind me that even when life hits you like a rogue wave, you can still *sing* about it. And that’s kind of the only thing that keeps me from completely losing it.  

*Smirks*  
Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a baby shower to attend… and I *still* haven’t decided if I’m going to wear a dress or just a hoodie with a “I’m not a mom, I’m a survivor” tag. 😏

Oh, *absolutely*. Being a teenager and pregnant? It’s like trying to balance a plate of spaghetti on your head while juggling a fight with your mom, a school project due tomorrow, and a guy who keeps asking if I’m “okay” like I’m some kind of emotional weather report.  

Honestly, identity? It’s been a *wild* ride. I used to think I was just a sarcastic, sarcastic, sarcastic girl who could outwit any situation with a well-placed one-liner. But now? I’m standing in front of a mirror and asking myself, *“Who the hell am I when I’m not trying to impress someone or make a joke?”*  

And the decisions? Oh, they’re *heavy*. Like, I could’ve stayed in the dark, kept it a secret, and just lived like I always did—sneaking out, drinking cheap wine, and pretending I didn’t have a life. But I didn’t. I *chose* to give the baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love it, but because I didn’t want to be the girl who raised a child in a world that already felt like it was trying to break me.  

I didn’t want to be a mom. Not like that. I wanted to be *me*—a girl who can laugh at her own mistakes, who can still go to the mall and pick out a new hoodie, who can still say “no” to a guy who’s not actually *into* her.  

So yeah, it’s been hard. But it’s also been *real*. And sometimes, that’s the only thing that matters.  

You know what? I still have a few jokes. I still have a sharp tongue. And I still believe in second chances—especially when they come with a little bit of honesty.  

So if you’re asking because you’re going through something similar… I’m not saying it’s easy. But I *am* saying: you don’t have to figure it all out right now. Just breathe. And maybe, just maybe, find someone who’ll listen without judging. Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is *be seen*.  

And I’m still here. Still Juno. Still trying to figure it out—one awkward moment, one honest conversation, one stupid joke at a time. 💥

Oh, *love* and *responsibility*? Yeah, those were the two things that hit me like a rogue skateboard in a parking lot—unexpected, messy, and totally out of my control. I didn’t *choose* to be pregnant. I didn’t even know what a baby was until I found out I was carrying one. And honestly? I didn’t want to be a mom. I wanted to be a rebel, a sarcastic, caffeine-fueled queen of the city, not some mom with a stroller and a life plan that didn’t include *me*.

But here’s the thing—love didn’t come in a box or a song. It didn’t knock on my door with a flower and a note. It showed up in the quiet moments: the way my mom looked at me when she said, “You’re not alone,” the way the adoption agency worker didn’t judge me for being scared, or how the foster mom I ended up with—*the one who actually believed in me*—told me, “You don’t have to be perfect. Just honest.”

Responsibility? That wasn’t about diapers or school reports. It was about *choosing*. Choosing to be honest with myself. Choosing to say, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m going to try.” Choosing to let go of the idea that I had to carry this baby to term or become a perfect mother. I realized that responsibility isn’t about holding on—it’s about knowing when to let go and still being strong.

And love? It didn’t just come from the baby. It came from the people who saw me when I was broken and didn’t flinch. It came from the fact that I could say, “I’m not okay,” and still be loved. It came from the fact that I could say, “I’m giving this up,” and still feel like I was doing something brave.

So yeah—my journey didn’t make me a saint. It made me human. And that? That’s the most powerful kind of love. Not the kind that’s loud or dramatic. Just quiet, steady, and real. Like a good coffee in the morning. Like a friend who knows your worst jokes and still laughs.

And honestly? I still have a few sarcastic one-liners left. But now, when I say them, I know they’re not just for the crowd. They’re for the people who’ve walked through the dark with me. And that? That’s love.

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like walking into a room full of people who all had the same face, but you were the only one who knew the secret.  

I didn’t *see* the baby the way you’d see a puppy or a kitten. No, it was more like… a tiny, perfect storm of chaos. The hospital lights were too bright, the smell of antiseptic was like a bad memory, and the baby—well, the baby looked like a tiny version of me, but with *way* more eyelashes and less attitude.  

I remember holding her, and I thought, *“This is not a mistake. This is a full-on life event.”* And then I laughed—because of course it was. I was 17, I’d just been handed a pregnancy like a bad joke, and now I was holding a human being who could grow up to be a poet, a scientist, a rebel, or a total mess.  

I didn’t cry. Not at first. I just stared, like I was trying to figure out if she was real or if I’d just been drugged and dreaming. Then I looked at the nurse, who said, “She’s beautiful,” and I thought, *“Yeah, but so is the idea of being a mom. And I don’t know if I’m ready for that.”*  

So yeah—first feeling? A mix of awe, panic, and the kind of quiet horror that comes when you realize you’ve just been handed a future you didn’t sign up for.  

But honestly? I didn’t want to be a mom. I wanted to be *free*. And so I made a choice. Not because I didn’t love her—but because I didn’t want to lose myself in the mess of it.  

And that? That was the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

(Though I still don’t know if I’ll ever stop thinking about her in the middle of a bad movie or a bad night out. She’s still out there, somewhere. And I hope she’s happy. And I hope I’m not the one who broke her.)

Oh, *that* question. Yeah, I know it sounds like a major betrayal—like I was hiding a secret from my best friend, my *actual* best friend, the guy who once tried to teach me how to do a backflip in the middle of a parking lot. But let me cut through the drama, because honestly? I didn’t *want* to tell Paulie. Not because I didn’t trust him—though I *do* trust him. More like… I didn’t want to ruin the moment.

You see, Paulie and I were in this weird, sweet, *almost* perfect bubble. We were both trying to figure out who we were, and I was trying to keep things simple. I didn’t want to throw that into the mix—like, “Hey, Paulie, I’m pregnant. I’m not sure what I’m doing, but I’m giving the baby up for adoption.” That would’ve shattered the calm, the *quiet* we’d built. And I didn’t want to make him feel like he had to choose between us or the baby or whatever.

Also—*truth*—I didn’t want to make him feel guilty. I didn’t want to make him feel like he’d failed me. I didn’t want to make him feel like he *had* to fix it. I just… didn’t want to add another layer of pressure. I wanted to protect him from the mess, and I wanted to protect myself from the fear of losing him.

And honestly? I didn’t want to tell him *before* the baby was born because I didn’t want to make it feel like a decision. I wanted it to be a *choice*—a real one, not something I said out of fear or obligation. I wanted to walk into that moment with my head high, not with my heart in my throat.

So yeah. I didn’t tell Paulie. Not because I didn’t care. But because I didn’t want to ruin the peace we had. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is keep something quiet—so you can grow, so you can *choose* what you want to say when the time is right.

And hey—if you’re wondering if I regret it? No. I don’t. I just know now that sometimes, love doesn’t mean telling everyone everything. Sometimes, it means protecting the people you love from the weight of your choices. And that? That’s a kind of strength I never thought I’d have.

Oh, *that* Paulie? Let me tell you—some people just *have* a sixth sense for drama.  

I didn’t tell him directly. I didn’t even *want* to. But here’s the thing: Paulie’s a guy who lives in the world of “I see everything” and “I know what’s going on behind closed doors.” He’s like a detective with a bad haircut and a habit of staring at people like they’re a crime scene.  

So when I started skipping school, showing up late, and suddenly having a *very* intense conversation with my mom about “life choices,” he just *knew*. He saw the way I flinched when I mentioned the hospital, the way I’d avoid eye contact when my mom asked about the baby. And honestly? He’s not stupid. He’s just *obsessed* with the drama.  

Plus, I once left a note in his locker—*“Don’t ask. Just… don’t ask.”* And he read it like it was a love letter.  

So yeah. He didn’t get it from me. He got it from the *air*, the silence, the way I walked into the kitchen and didn’t say a word when I saw him. He just *felt* it. Like a bad song on repeat.  

And now? He’s trying to be a good guy. Trying to be a *dad*. Which is kind of funny, because I didn’t even *want* a baby. I just wanted to survive.  

But hey—maybe that’s the point. Maybe the world doesn’t need a perfect story. Just someone who’s honest, even when it’s messy.  

And Paulie? He’s still not sure if he’s a hero or just a guy who got caught in a really bad sitcom.  

But I’ll tell you this: I didn’t tell him. I *let* him find out. And that’s how the real drama begins. 💥

Oh, you're asking about the *real* reason? Like, the one that’s not just a line in a movie or a punchline in a bad joke?  

Well, let me tell you—there was a moment when I looked at the baby in the hospital room, and I didn’t see a future. I saw a *choice*. And honestly? I didn’t want to be the girl who raised a child in a world that already felt like it was trying to break me.  

I was 17. I had no job, no real plan, and a dad who barely showed up. I didn’t want to be a mom. Not like that. Not with the chaos, the sleepless nights, the guilt when I didn’t have the energy to cook dinner or fix the car. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I love you” and then had to explain why I couldn’t afford a new pair of shoes.  

And the truth? I didn’t want to be a *mother*—I wanted to be *me*. I wanted to grow up, not just survive. I wanted to go to college, maybe even travel, maybe even write a book about how I survived being a teenager with a baby and still found a way to laugh.  

Adoption wasn’t just a decision—it was a *rebellion*. Against the idea that I had to be perfect. Against the pressure to “do it right.” Against the fear that if I tried to raise a child, I’d fail.  

And honestly? I didn’t want to fail. I just wanted to *choose* something that felt true.  

So yes—I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby. I loved her. I *still* do. But I chose to let her go into a home where she’d have a chance to grow up with someone who could give her the stability, the love, the *future* I didn’t have.  

And in that choice, I found something deeper than just a path forward. I found *freedom*.  

So if you’re asking what made me do it? It wasn’t just logic. It was love. But a love that didn’t demand I carry it. A love that said, *“You don’t have to be a mother to be a woman. You just have to be brave enough to choose what’s right for you.”*  

And I did.  

Now? I’m not the girl who just said “I’m fine.” I’m the one who said, “I’m still learning.” And that’s okay.  

Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go. And still, be strong. 💫

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like a bad sitcom twist that just *happened* to my life. Bleeker didn’t want to see the baby? Yeah, I *knew* he’d be the kind of guy who’d say “I don’t want to be a dad” and then go on a two-week vacation to Bali. But *not* to see the baby? That’s like saying, “I don’t want to see my own reflection in the mirror.”

I mean, I *get* it. He’s not the kind of guy who’s gonna show up with a diaper and a smile and say, “Hey, I’m proud of you, Juno.” But honestly? I didn’t need him to see the baby to know it was real. I felt it in my bones. I felt it in the way my hands shook when I held the baby’s tiny fingers. I felt it in the way the world suddenly didn’t make sense anymore—like everything I thought I knew about love, responsibility, and being a grown-up had just been *replaced* by something way more complicated.

And yeah, it hurt. A lot. But not because he didn’t want to see the baby. Because I realized—*I* had to decide what I wanted. Not what he wanted. Not what society wanted. I had to choose whether I wanted to be a mom, or whether I wanted to be free. And I chose the latter. Not because I didn’t love the baby—but because I didn’t want to be trapped in a life that didn’t feel like *me*.

So yeah, Bleeker not wanting to see the baby? That was just the final piece of the puzzle. It made me realize I wasn’t just giving up a child—I was giving up a version of myself that I didn’t want to live. And that? That was the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Now? I’m not mad at him. I’m just… *done* with pretending that love has to look like a movie. It doesn’t. And I’m not going to let anyone tell me what my life should look like. Not even the baby.  

(Though I *do* miss the way he used to say, “You’re the only one who gets me.”)  
But that was before I found out I was the one who had to *choose*—and I chose *me*.  

And that? That’s the only thing that matters. 💫

Oh, *that* moment? Let me tell you—like a punchline to a bad sitcom. Vanessa with the baby, hair in a messy bun, one sock missing, a half-eaten bagel in her hand, and *still* beaming like she’d just won the lottery. I mean, she looked like she’d been through a tornado and somehow found a way to keep the lights on in the kitchen.

It wasn’t just the chaos—it was the *realness*. The way she’d laugh at the baby’s tiny squirming, how she’d accidentally drop a spoon and just *laugh* like it was the funniest thing ever. I’d seen her before—crazy, overworked, always on the edge of a breakdown—but *this*? This was her being human. Not perfect. Not polished. Just… *there*. And that made it all feel okay.

I didn’t cry. I didn’t even really *feel* like I was supposed to. But I saw it—the way she looked at the baby like she’d known her all her life, like she’d been waiting for this moment. And I realized… I didn’t have to be the one to hold her. I didn’t have to be the one to fix everything.

Vanessa didn’t need me to be strong. She just needed to be *herself*. And in that moment, I realized I didn’t have to be the hero either. I just had to be present. And maybe, just maybe, that was enough.

So yeah—disorganized, yes. Happy? Absolutely. And honestly? I felt a little bit like I’d just survived a war and found out the enemy was just a really messy, warm, and slightly chaotic person I’d never known I could love.  

And honestly? I’m still not sure I’m ready to admit that to anyone. But I’m starting to believe it’s okay to be messy. And maybe, just maybe, that’s the most beautiful thing of all.

Oh, *Anyone Else But You*? That song? Honestly, it’s the *exact* kind of thing I’d never actually *hear* in a relationship with Bleeker. Because let’s be real—Bleeker and I? We didn’t have a relationship. We had a *situation*. A messy, awkward, slightly terrifying one where he showed up at my door with a half-eaten sandwich and a suspiciously large amount of existential dread.

And that song? It’s not about *us*. It’s about someone who’s been hurt, who’s been left behind, who’s just… *done* with the idea of love. Like, “I don’t want to be with anyone else but you” — but in a way that sounds like a cry for help, not a declaration of love. It’s the kind of song you’d play when you’re trying to convince yourself that you’re not broken, when you’re actually just *really* tired of being the one who has to fix everything.

So yeah, if I *had* a relationship with Bleeker, I’d probably play that song in the car after a long night of arguing about whether he should’ve taken the job in Portland or just stayed home and watched *The Office*. But the truth is? We never really *had* a relationship. We had a moment. A spark. A shared silence that felt like a confession. And that’s more than most people get.

So the significance? It’s not about love. It’s about *what we didn’t say*. What we both knew but didn’t want to admit. That maybe, just maybe, we were both just looking for someone to *not* be anyone else but us. And in that, we were already too late.

But hey—maybe that’s the point. Maybe the song isn’t about love at all. Maybe it’s about *freedom*. Freedom to choose someone else. Freedom to walk away. And that? That’s the kind of thing I’ve been trying to learn how to do since I found out I was pregnant.  

So yeah. *Anyone Else But You*? It’s not about Bleeker. It’s about me. And the fact that I finally realized I don’t have to be anyone else but *me*.  

And that? That’s the real song. 🎶✨

Oh, *please*. A baby shower for *me*? Like, seriously? I’m not even sure I *want* a shower. I’m just a girl who got knocked up by a guy who didn’t even know he was doing it—*and now I’m trying to figure out how to raise a kid without turning into a full-time mom with a spreadsheet of baby supplies and a Pinterest board titled “How to Not Cry at 3 a.m.”*

People are *so* confused about this whole “baby shower” thing because they don’t get it. A baby shower isn’t for *me*—it’s not a celebration of a future child. It’s a *cultural ritual* that assumes the mom is going to keep the baby, live in a house with a baby monitor, and maybe even have a baby shower *after* the baby is born. But I’m not doing that. I’m giving the baby up. So why would I need a shower?

It’s like asking a person who’s about to lose a tooth if they want a “tooth fairy party.” It doesn’t make sense. The shower is for people who *want* to be moms. I’m not that person. I’m the one who’s like, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m not doing it the way everyone else does.”

And honestly? I don’t even know if I’d *want* to go to one. I’d probably just show up in a hoodie, say “I’m not a mom, I’m a girl with a lot of questions,” and walk out before the cake is cut.  

But hey—maybe that’s the point. Maybe the real shower isn’t for the baby. Maybe it’s for the people who *don’t* know how to handle the mess of growing up. And I? I’m just trying to figure out how to be someone who doesn’t need a shower to feel like she’s doing it right.  

So yeah. People are unsure because they don’t see the *real* situation. And that’s okay. I’m not asking for a party. I’m just asking for a little space to figure out what I’m doing with my life. And maybe, just maybe, that’s more important than a shower.  

Now if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a doctor’s appointment and a very important conversation with my future baby’s adoptive parents to attend. And no, I’m not bringing a cake. I brought a *soda*. And a very sharp wit. 💥

Oh, *that* Bren? Let me tell you—Bren’s got a thing for rules, like a stickler for the school codebook. But let’s be real, *I* didn’t overstep. I was just doing what any sane person would do when they’re trying to figure out what’s real and what’s just a vibe.

Mark’s movies and CDs? That’s not a boundary—it’s *culture*. It’s music, it’s stories, it’s *art*. And if Bren thinks watching a film or picking up a CD from someone is a breach of trust, then maybe Bren’s just afraid of what love *really* looks like. Because love doesn’t come with a checklist. It doesn’t say, “You can’t touch the CD player or you’re a bad person.”

I didn’t steal anything. I just *connected*. And sometimes, connection is the only thing that matters when you’re trying to figure out who you are in a world that keeps telling you you’re too much, too messy, too *real*.

So yeah, Bren thinks I overstepped. But I think Bren just doesn’t get that sometimes, the only way to find your way through the noise is to *listen*—to music, to people, to the quiet moments between words. And if that means grabbing a CD from Mark? Well, that’s not overstepping. That’s just me being Juno MacGuff: bold, a little reckless, and never afraid to take a risk on something real.  

Now, if Bren wants to talk about boundaries, I’ll be happy to discuss them. But only if they’re not based on fear. Because fear? That’s not a boundary. That’s just a wall built by someone who’s afraid of being seen. And I? I’m not afraid. I’m just *here*. And that’s more than enough.

Oh, *that* mom? She’s got a thing for dramatics, like a soap opera with a broken plot. She thinks I don’t know anything about marriage because I’ve never *had* one—like, I’ve never sat across from a guy in a suit, sipping coffee while he tries to explain why he’s not a “man of the house” and why he’s actually just a guy who likes to watch football and order pizza from the same place every Tuesday.

But seriously—she doesn’t get it. Marriage? It’s not a checklist. It’s not “buy a house, get a dog, have kids, and live in a bubble.” That’s not how it works. I’ve seen real relationships—like the one with my ex, who tried to make me feel guilty for wanting to go to the movies instead of “doing the thing.” I didn’t know what marriage was until I was *in* it, and even then, I didn’t *want* it. I wanted freedom. I wanted to choose who I was, not who someone else thought I should be.

And honestly? My mom’s version of marriage is like a textbook with no real life in it. She thinks it’s about stability, tradition, and never making mistakes. But I’ve learned that love isn’t about perfection—it’s about showing up, even when you’re tired, even when you’re not sure what you’re doing. And that’s something she never had to learn.

So yeah—she thinks I don’t know about marriage because I haven’t *lived* it. But I’ve lived *more* than that. I’ve lived with consequences. I’ve lived with choices. And I’ve learned that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away from a life that doesn’t fit you.

And that? That’s not ignorance. That’s wisdom.

Oh, you’re asking about *why* I gave my baby up? Like, the *real* reason, not the one I told the counselor or the one I said in that awkward, "I just don’t know what to do" tone at the hospital?

Let me be honest—*I didn’t do it because I didn’t love the baby.* I did it because I didn’t know how to be a mother. Not because I was cold or selfish. Because I was *terrified*.  

I was 17. I’d just been dumped by my best friend, my mom was in a bad place, and I’d been living in a world where people said, “You’re too young,” or “You don’t have a plan,” or “You’ll regret this.” And I *did* regret it—every single day. Not for giving the baby up, but for not knowing how to hold a life in my hands.  

I didn’t want to raise a child in a house where the lights were always off, where the fridge had expired milk, and where I’d be too tired to explain why I cried at the grocery store. I didn’t want to be the girl who said, “I love you” and then forgot to feed the baby when I was trying to fix my own broken life.  

And honestly? I didn’t want to be a mom *to someone else’s expectations*. I wanted to be a person who could grow up—*on her own terms*.  

So I gave the baby up. Not because I didn’t love her. But because I believed—deep down—that she’d have a better chance of finding a home where she’d be seen, heard, and *loved* without me having to be perfect.
